description:
After a lifelong battle with illness, a young girl from Earth is reborn into the world of Pok√©mon as Peppa 'Pep' Carmine‚Äî the daughter of a prestigious family of Pokemon breeders. At the ripe age of seventeen, Pep's parents ship her off to the Sinnoh region, where she must attend classes at the elite Jubilife Trainer Academy. Peppa's parents have high hopes of molding her into a heiress that can live up to their expectations, but much to their chagrin, Pep isn't interested in what they think.

Give this story a shot! You won't regret it.

An ambitious, but well launched fic. Where Pokemon SIs are a dime a dozen these days, Best of the Worst sets itself apart by slowly creating a fleshed out Pokemon world that manages to give itself a sense of care and uniqueness to it.

The characters are quirky enough to stand out, but not overwhelming enough to seem fake or too trope-ish. The Pokemon are written in a way to give them a good personality without seeming too human-like. The conflicts between characters have been a bit on the nose with cliches and could use some work to be more believable as to repercurssions, but they arent enough so to turn you away from the fic.

The Pokemon world is one that has been written about many times before, but Best of the Worst's quality makes it stand out from others of similar length and age. The author should be proud of what they have managed to evoke.

All in all, a well done story that I am looking forward to seeing updates from. Something of this quality deserves more exposure and I eagerly await to see what the author manages to accomplish next!

As of 13/11/25: The author continues to show improvement and try different things with their writing. The story has managed to stay fresh and I still have this story near the top of my watchlist.

chapters.name: Prologue
chapters.content:
Things didn't really pan out quite the way I had hoped.

Sure, I never had the highest of expectations for my life, but I had always expected it would amount to more than.. this.

Today was my nineteenth birthday, and here I was spending it rotting away in a hospital bed, no family or friends in sight.

I had been sick most of my life, and while I understood that the never-ending cycle of doctors and hospital visits was exhausting, I couldn't help but be bitter that I hadn't even received a call. Once I had turned eighteen, and legally became an adult, I suspected my family just wanted to be done with it all- not that I could blame them. My parents, after all, had given up quite a bit just to keep me alive. It couldn't have been easy.

I sighed. "Things could be worse." I thought to myself. At least my nurse had brought me a cupcake.

I shifted uncomfortably, attempting to readjust myself, which always proved challenging while attached to an IV drip, among other assorted chords. I slumped back with a huff, looking down at the red Nintendo 3DS clutched in my hands. "At least I have you guys." I chuckled quietly, suddenly finding myself choking back bitter tears. I allowed myself to cry for a bit and lament my own loneliness, but I eventually took a deep breath and wiped my tears away.

Once I managed to calm down, I began flipping through my Pok√©mon team members- all of which had been meticulously bred and trained to have ideal stats and move sets. Battles were far from my favorite part of this particular game, though. This game had a feature called Pok√©Amie, which was very reminiscent of Nintendogs. You could feed, pet, and play with your Pok√©mon-- which I absolutely adored.

Nothing beat feeding the Lord of Darkness Giratina little cupcakes, after all.

"There you go," I hummed, feeding one of my treasured companions a pokepuff. The Pok√©mon on the screen wiggled and cried happily. I couldn't help but crack a smile. I continued playing for a few hours, before closing my 3DS and placing it back on its charger.

"Goodnight," I sighed to the empty room, which had now grown dim. I lowered myself carefully amidst the chords, and drifted off to sleep.

---------

Upon regaining my awareness, I realized I was no longer in my bed, but standing- floating? in what appeared to be a bright white, featureless space.

"Where.. where am I?" I wondered aloud to myself. I looked down at my hands, but instead found an aura of glowing color in their place. "What the hell is- Okay. Don't panic. This is just a dream." I assured myself.

"I am sorry." A voice boomed, reverberating through my mind. "I am afraid that this is not a dream."

"Then- what- who," I stammered. "Huh?"

"Listen." The voice replied solemnly.

After a few moments of silence, I heard noises off in the distance. The sound of frantic voices, and a shrill mechanical beeeeeeeeeeeeeep.

And then nothing.

"That was.."

"Yes, child. Unfortunately, your life has come to an end." The voice replied solemnly.

"Ah.. haha. I see." I chuckled. "That.. really sucks."

For a while, everything was quiet.
I thought back on my life, recalling good and bad memories alike. Beach trips. My favorite scented candle. My family dog. My childhood bully. Hospital rooms. Ice cream. Pokemon.

Resigning myself, I asked the voice, "Okay. Now what?"

"You seem to have processed this information rather quickly." The voice responded, betraying a hint of surprise.

"Don't get me wrong, I don't want to be dead, but I had known for some time that this day was coming." I shrugged my non-existent shoulders.

"I see. How unfortunate."

"It is what it is."

After a long pause, the voice responded again. "Tell me, child. What is it that you desire most?"

"I.. I'm not sure, really. All I ever really wanted was to live a normal life. To be happy, I guess." I pondered. "If I could have anything, well.. I..," I paused.

"I just don't want to be alone anymore."

Before me, four spindly legs stepped out of what appeared to be a glowing, golden fog. I was sure I recognized this form from somewhere, but I couldn't quite make out any distinguishing features apart from its legs-- and what appeared to be glowing green eyes that stared back at me through the haze.

"If given the opportunity, would you wish to continue living?" The form asked.

"Uh.. Do you mean like, reincarnation?" I responded.

"Precisely."

I pondered the question for a few moments. My life had been short, but not particularly easy. It could have been worse, sure. I had seen plenty of other patients whose conditions were far more painful than my own, which made me hesitant to roll the dice on another life. What if I reincarnated just to suffer all over again?

I swallowed at the thought. If the figure before me was to be believed, this could be my chance to do and experience all of the things I had missed out on in my short existence. Did I really fear pain more than I wanted to live?

"I suppose.. I could try again." I replied.

"I see. A bold decision, young one. Are you certain?" The form asked.

"Yes.. I would like to try again." I finished.

The being before me stretched a spindly legs towards me, touching where my forehead would have been. All at once, I was enveloped by a warm, golden light.

As the being spoke, I felt a wave of calm wash over me. I let my form relax into the fog.

"Very well. Rest now, child. You will awaken very soon." The being's voice echoed in my mind.

Finally giving into fatigue, I allowed my awareness to slip away from me, until there was nothing left but silence.

---------

"Peppa dear, are you awake?" Mother's voice called down the hall.

I rubbed the sleep from my bleary eyes and stifled a yawn, before snuggling back into the soft covers.

"Five more minutes," I grumbled.

"Young lady, you simply cannot be late!" Mother chided. "You wouldn't want to miss your flight, would you?"

Stolen novel; please report.

I willed my eyes to remain shut, hoping to steal just a few more seconds of delicious sleep. "I'm just.. so comfy." I muttered.

"Your Grandfather will be here to pick you up soon-- Do I need to get Mawhile?"

My body stiffened, and I immediately darted up.

"That's what I thought." Mother chuckled, now standing in the doorway to my room. Her tiny menace of a pok√©mon hugged one of her legs, giving me a smug look.

The last thing I wanted was to be dragged my by ankles through the house by Mawhile's teeth again. I shuddered.

For a pok√©mon so small, her giant maw was extremely strong. Capable of throwing a person, I regrettably had discovered on numerous occasions.

"Yeah, yeah." I huffed, lifting myself out of the bed and onto my feet. I pulled a loose sweater onto my body and shuffled past mother and her Mawhile, giving the pok√©mon a soft pat on the head.

"Mah-maw," the pok√©mon purred triumphantly.

Mawhile wasn't a bad pok√©mon; in fact, I quite liked her. She was just eager to please mother, not unlike the rest of the family. I could understand her enthusiasm, even if it often did result in me being rag dolled out of bed by my ankles.

"You're sure you've packed everything, right? Toothbrush, shampoo, underwear?" Mother asked, following me down the hallway.

"Yes, Mother. I'm sure." I yawned.

-------

As I brushed my teeth, I studied my reflection in the mirror. In this life I had been born quite the physical opposite to my previous one. I was certain that I had once been short and stocky, but in this life, I now possessed a long, gangly body- standing at about five feet and nine inches tall. Very tall for a girl, let alone a seventeen year old.

I couldn't help but smirk. I had always wanted to be tall, so I felt that Arceus really did come through for me there. I stretched my noodly arms into a pose in the mirror.
"Perfection." I muttered, before setting to the task of wrangling my messy red hair into a halfway presentable bun.

"And she's so humble, too." A voice scoffed from behind me, causing me to jerk. Behind me in the mirror stood my younger brother, Florian.

I felt my face flush.

"Admiring yourself again, I see." Florian huffed, rolling his eyes.

Florian was thirteen, turning fourteen this year. He stood at about chest height for me- he hadn't quite hit his growth spurt yet.

I reached down and ruffled his red hair with one hand. "Hey, it's important to love yourself, kiddo." I shrugged.

"Hey- cut it out!" He laughed, trying his best to sound annoyed.

I looked down at him and smiled.

"You're leaving today, right?" He asked, looking a bit forlorn.

"Yeah, sorry Flor. You'll be able to join the academy next year, though." I replied. Florian gave a bit of a half-smile in response, but I could tell that he was just trying to be mature about it.

Though this was definitely the Pok√©mon world, many things were distinctly different than I had remembered from the anime and games. Instead of setting off at ten years old, children were required to attend a 'regular' school until they were fourteen. After completing primary schooling, they then became eligible to enroll in a Trainer Academy, where they could study to obtain an official trainer license. As such, Florian wouldn't be able to join the Trainer Academy until next year, and by then I would be on my own journey. I couldn't help but feel a bit guilty for having to leave him behind.

"Well, can you hurry up? Some other people would like to use the bathroom." Florian said, crossing his arms.

"Yeah, yeah.. I'm almost done." I responded, returning to the task of making myself presentable.

When I finished, I turned to Florian and lowered myself to give him a big hug. "I'll miss you, Flor." I said, ruffling his curly red hair.

His disgruntled expression softened, betraying a sad smile. "I'll miss you too, sis."

Florian really was a good kid.

--------

I hurried down the stairs, luggage in tow, and made my way into the front parlor. Father sat on the sofa reading the morning paper and sipping his coffee. At his feet, his Ninetales was curled up and sleeping. I said nothing, silently hoping he hadn't noticed me, and took a few steps towards the door.

"Peppa." Father's voice rumbled, causing me to stiffen.

"Yes, Father?" I asked.

"Do not make a fool of yourself, young lady." He growled. "I had better not receive any calls from the Academy this year."

Before I could say anything in response, Mother chimed in.

"Oh, relax dear. It will be fine." Mother smiled, despite giving me a pointed stare. "I'm sure Peppa knows just how important this is."

I grimaced. Being a member of the Carmine family meant that many eyes would be on me during my final year, before I officially made my debut as a trainer. If I looked bad, the whole family would look bad, which was not something my parents would abide.

The Carmine Family was well renowned throughout Hoenn for their expertise in pok√©mon breeding. They had made their fortune by selectively breeding highly sought-after pok√©mon, such as Eevee, Gardevoir, Skitty, Vulpix; the list goes on. Pok√©mon bred by the Carmine family were known to possess a unique and unrivaled beauty- a highly coveted feature among Pokemon Coordinators. Their Pok√©mon were the very picture of elegance and composure-- Not unlike the family themselves.

"I.. I'll do my best." I responded, giving a fake smile.

"See that you do." Father grumbled, before returning to reading his paper.

Ninetales stretched and sauntered over to me, before pushing her head into my side. I hugged the large fox-dog, giving her a scratch behind the ears. "Niiiine." She whined.

"I'll see you soon girl," I assured her, giving her a final pat on the head.

I finished saying my good-byes and headed for the door, smiling to myself. I wasn't about to let the grumpy old man put a damper on my spirits.

This was the year I finally got my own pokemon, after all.

chapters.name: Chapter 1 - Departure
chapters.content:
"Pfft. Don't listen to your father. He's always been a bit of a stick in the mud." Grandpa sniffed, his eyes focused on the road.

As soon as I had gotten into the car, he had quickly deduced something was amiss-- he seemed to have a sixth sense for things like that when it came to his grandchildren. Admittedly, I did feel a bit deflated, but I didn't think I was that easy to read. After a bit of prodding I had told him about the unceremonious-partly hostile-sendoff my father had given me earlier.

"He's worried that I might damage the family's reputation." I muttered, my gaze focused on a few Wingulls flying off into the distance. The sun had only barely begun to rise.

It had just now dawned on me (pun intended) that Florian must have gotten up extra early just to see me off. My chest tightened at the thought. I didn't remember having any siblings back on Earth, but if I did, I was sure I'd liked Florian better. Hopefully, I'd be able to bring back a cool pokemon for him to meet.

For a long moment, I zoned out, watching the the landscape of opulent houses and buildings speed past. Little by little, the sights of the city gave way to a vista of beautiful Lilycove shores, copses of tropical flora dotting the brilliant landscape. In the distance, the looming form of Mt. Pyre stood, dwarfing everything else by comparison.

I wondered if I really could find some ghost pokemon there.

"Reputation," Grandpa scoffed, jerking me from my trance. "Listen, kid. The Carmine family name wasn't built on kissing ass,"

The annoyance in his voice was palpable.

"It was built on expertise--finesse. Skill." He motioned with one hand, flicking his wrist. "Skill that your father wouldn't know if it smacked him in the face."

I winced a little. Grandpa had never made much of an effort to hide his disdain for my father-- his own son, which likely contributed to Father's grumpy-old-bastard behavior. Ultimately, Father always put the good of the family first- and though he could afford to be a bit nicer about it, it wasn't like he was downright cruel, either.

"You just focus on yourself, kid. Become someone that you can be proud of. As long as you're happy, that's what counts. Anyone who has an issue with my granddaughter can take it up with me." He smirked back at me, giving me a thumbs up.

"Grandpa-the road!" I panicked as we swerved for a moment, eliciting a honk from a vehicle in the lane opposite to us.

Grandpa chuckled sheepishly, hurrying to correct the wheel. "Don't tell your mother about that."

I stared at him dubiously for a moment, and sighed. "Snitches get stitches." I smirked.

Grandpa rumbled out a raspy laugh.

"Atta girl! I knew I taught you right."

"...But seriously. Don't tell your mother." He muttered, his face becoming serious for a moment.

Damn. Even Grandpa didn't want to get on her bad side.

We talked a bit more throughout the drive, discussing my upcoming final year at the Academy. He asked if I was hoping for any pokemon in particular as my first partner, which I denied. Honestly, just thinking about having my own pokemon--any pokemon, made my heart pound with excitement. While I was fuzzy on some of the details of my previous world, I knew that pokemon did not exist there- at least, not in the way they did here. In my old world, pokemon were fictional creatures; only existing in video games and anime. Here, pokemon were very real--and an essential part of everyday life.

In this world, catching your first pokemon and becoming a trainer was considered a necessary rite of passage before truly becoming an adult. A rite of passage that soon enough I would be undertaking. I swallowed, wiping a bead of nervous sweat from my forehead. I was practically vibrating in my seat with anticipation at this point. Somewhere out there was a pokemon--my pokemon, waiting for me to find them.

I felt a seed of anxiety take root within me. Would I be good enough to be their trainer?

I quickly pushed the thought away-- those kinds of thoughts did not serve me. 'There's a pokemon out there for everyone' was a common expression in this world for a reason. Plus, given the sheer diversity and abundance of pokemon, I had no real reason not to be optimistic. It would all work out in the end, I assured myself.

"Wont be long now. We're almost there," Grandpa said, perhaps noticing my mounting anticipation.

We talked a bit more, before reaching a natural lull in our conversation. We fell into a companionable silence for the rest of the drive.

---------

After making our way through airport security, we were greeted by a steward who sent out a Machop to help with my luggage. It felt a bit unnecessary, as I only had but one suitcase and a small backpack, but I'd be lying if I said I wasn't grateful to be spared a few extra moments to say my goodbyes. I was really going to miss the old geezer. Asides from Florian, Grandpa was the only person here who I felt ever really believed in me.

"Make sure to call me, and your parents when you get there," Grandpa said, scratching his white, fluffy beard. "I suppose its a little late to ask, but you're sure you've got everything, right?"

"I'm sure, Gramps. Mom wouldn't let me live it down if I forgot anything important." I sighed, clutching my carry-on bag.

"You've got that right," He chuckled, and made an exaggerated, terrified expression. I mimicked while comically clutching my chest and mouthing the words, "The horror!"

Behind me, a woman cleared her throat. I ceased my miming and straightened out, shuffling awkwardly out of the woman's way. Grandpa and I exchanged a glance, before giggling to ourselves once we were sure she was out of earshot.

"Attention all passengers of the Hoenn-Sinnoh Flight 82, we will begin boarding now. Passengers in the seating rows A through B, please have your tickets ready before you board." A stewardess called over the loudspeaker.

"Looks like that's your cue, kid. C'mere." Grandpa said, pulling me into a tight hug. "I'm proud of you, Pep. I know you'll do great things out there."

I squeezed back. "Thanks Grandpa. I love you."

"I love you too, bean-sprout." He released his grip, giving me a gentle push- and a wink. "Show those Sinnoh brats what-for."

"You got it!" I flashed him my cheesiest grin and gave a thumbs up, before making my way to the gate, fumbling for the tickets in my pocket. Panicking for a half second, I turned behind me to see Grandpa still standing there, staring at me with a quirked brow, as if to say, "You better not have lost them."

"Just kidding!" I stuck out my tongue, revealing my tickets. He rolled his eyes and snorted. "Get out of here already!" He shouted back.

Turning my attention back towards the stewardess's desk, I realized the woman at the desk had seen my childish display. I cleared my throat and handed her my tickets, my face flushed with embarrassment.

"Enjoy your flight, miss." she said with a smirk.

"You too," I replied, internally facepalming as I entered the gate. Nice one, Pep. Real smooth.

---

The long flight had-so far- been uneventful. I had hoped to be seated a bit closer to the front of the plane, but truthfully I was just grateful to have gotten a window seat. I had watched from the window as Hoenn disappeared beneath me, and an endless sea of clouds now spanned the horizon as far as I could see. I had seen a few Swablu and Altaria soaring through the clouds earlier, but I supposed that our current altitude might be a little too high up, even for them.

I silently wondered if any pokemon could actually live this high up. I seemed to recall that there had been legendary and mythical pokemon that lived in outer space, at least there were in the Pokemon games from my last life- but I couldn't quite remember their names. Images of a green serpent jetting through the clouds popped into my mind. "Rayquaza, was it?" I muttered.

"I sure hope not." I jerked as the woman next to me spoke.

I had made little note of my seat-neighbor upon being seated, but now that I really looked at her, I realized that she was beautiful. The woman appeared to be in her mid-to-late thirties, sporting a mop of thick, fluffy brown hair. She wore a thick, fur-trimmed jacket- which sported a pattern reminiscent of a stony cliff-face. Matching clothing to your preferred pokemon type wasn't uncommon- even if a little on the nose. Advertising what pokemon you're going to use could be counter-intuitive in battles, but confident trainers often liked to show off- and this woman did have a certain air of confidence about her. Judging by her outfit, I would have speculated her to be a rock or ground type trainer.

"What do you know of Rayquaza, girl?" The woman's brown eyes narrowed at me.

"I-uh," I stammered. "Not much really. I've just heard stories."

"Hey, relax. You're not in trouble, kid." The woman laughed, her expression relaxing. "Are you a student?" She asked.

"Yeah- er, yes ma'am." I replied, fidgeting with the buttons on my corduroy jacket. "I'm transferring to the Jubilife Trainer Academy for my final year."

"Ho? Why so far away?" She asked, looking puzzled.

"Its supposed to be the best of the best," I replied. "At least that's what I've heard from my parents."

I knew the real reason, though. At best, I would do well, and potentially make a name for the Carmine family in Sinnoh. At worst, well-- at least I would be far away enough from home that it wouldn't embarrass my parents too much.

The woman pursed her lips for a moment. "I see. Well, they wouldn't be wrong about that."

An awkward silence set in, and I felt myself zone out again as my eyes drifted back towards the window. After a few moments, the woman spoke again. "Rayquaza does exist, by the way."

"...Huh?" I replied, coming out of my daze.

"Rayquaza," she started. "It isn't just a story. It exists."

Really? There really was a forty-foot giant sky serpent out there? Color me interested.

"Really? How do you know?" I turned, giving the woman my full attention. "Have you seen it?"

"Simmer down," the woman laughed. "And no- to answer your question- I've not seen it myself, but there are people who have."

"I guess it wouldn't really be a legendary if you could see one so casually." I mused.

"Yes, but- who knows? You might get to see it one day, if you're lucky." The woman smiled.

I could certainly hope so- or rather, maybe I shouldn't hope to see a giant space dragon, capable of leveling cities on a whim. That generally wouldn't be something a normal person would hope for. Dragons are just objectively awesome, though. What would it be like to capture such a beast? To ride it into the heavens? I sighed dreamily at the thought.

---------

I waved good-bye to the woman from earlier as I made my way through the terminal. I had been instructed prior to my flight to wait at baggage claim for someone from the Academy to collect me. After retrieving my luggage, I tentatively scanned my surroundings, but didn't see anyone that seemed to be waiting. I sat down on one of the benches, attempting to pull my gangly legs in closer so as not to obstruct traffic.

I waited for about ten minutes before being approached by a girl in what looked to be a Japanese school uniform. She wore a long white skirt that went down to her shins, and dark navy stockings underneath. Admittedly, the uniform was very cute--and tasteful I might add-- but I couldn't help but hope that I wouldn't be forced to wear a skirt.

"Excuse me, are you Peppa Carmine?" she asked, tucking a lock of jet-black hair behind her ear.

"That's me," I replied, rising to my feet.

The girl stiffened for a moment as I towered over her. I gave her a smile, trying my best to not look intimidating. (Which rarely worked.) "Er, you are?" I asked.

"Beatrice. I'm here to take you to the dorms," the girl spoke with clear composure. If she was intimidated, she definitely wasn't showing it now. "Please, follow me."

chapters.name: Chapter 2 - Arrival
chapters.content:
I followed behind Beatrice silently, taking in the unfamiliar sights of Jubilife City. The sun had long since set by now, but the city remained... bright-- obnoxiously so. What little stars could be seen in the sky were all but choked out by a thick blanket of light pollution. Lilycove City had by no means been small, but Jubilife easily dwarfed it by comparison. This city was big.

On our way we had passed a large building with a comically massive TV screen mounted on its front-- displaying the current time and weather conditions. Despite it being rather late, the streets were bustling with traffic; absolutely teeming with people and pokemon alike. More than once I had been stopped by someone offering me 'the deal of a lifetime', but Beatrice quickly shut that down and continued to hurry me along.

"Don't make eye contact with them. Just keep walking." She told me. I gave her a nod.

"Is it always like this?" I asked.

"Here? Yes." she sighed. "You'll get used to it."

We continued walking, ignoring the street vendors along the way-- which admittedly felt a teensy bit rude, but only the first few times. After the fifth or sixth person attempted to flag us down, I happily threw my manners to the wayside. Being annoying seemed like a common business practice here.

Hopefully I wouldn't be spending too much time here, apart from my stay at the Academy. While I could admit that the city itself was impressive, crowds had always made me anxious-- and the pushy street vendors certainly didn't help. Everywhere I looked, the buildings seemed to close in around me. I found my vision rapidly focusing into a tunnel with Beatrice at its center. She continued to walk ahead of me with her head held high, seemingly unbothered by the cacophony of stimuli that pelted us from all sides. I willed myself to hold it together-- Perhaps she was right, maybe I would get used to this-- though I seriously doubted it.

------

I shivered as I stared up and the hulking building before me. The Jubilife Trainer Academy cut an imposing figure, even among the rest of the cityscape. It wasn't just big, but it was ornate--featuring chiseled stone columns along the entranceway, among other impressive feats of architecture. The courtyard was decorated with a brilliant display of meticulously trimmed hedges and shrubbery, which coalesced around an impressively large fountain that featured a statue of a familiar pokemon at its center- A Lucario, if I wasn't mistaken. The Lucario was positioned in a triumphant stance, as if challenging any who opposed it. The rest of the Academy seemed to exude the same energy.

I clutched my knees, letting my luggage fall to my sides for a moment. The trek through the city had taken more out of me than I realized.

"Are you alright?" Beatrice asked, stopping in front of me.

"Yeah- I'm fine," I panted, forcing myself to smile up at her. "Crowds just make me pretty nervous."

"I see." Beatrice's eyes lingered on me for a moment, but her face betrayed nothing of what she was thinking.

Upon arriving at the dormitory, I asked Beatrice if there was a phone I could use to call my family. She led me to a landline phone, before leaving me with a note that had my dorm number hastily scribbled onto it. I thanked her, but she said nothing in return-- only giving me a polite nod before heading up the stairs. I felt a little bad that the school had sent her halfway across the city to retrieve me. I had honestly expected a teacher or staff member-- someone at least getting paid for such a tedious task. I would have to do something to thank her properly later.

I hobbled awkwardly up the stairs with my luggage, once again stopping to catch my breath upon making it to the third floor. Picking myself up, I hurried down the hall in search of my dorm room, which thankfully didn't take long to find. The siren song of sleep was calling my name.

"Twenty-four C," I muttered, looking at the note. "Yeah, seems like this is it."

I reached out to knock on the door, hesitating for a moment. I hoped I wouldn't be waking my roommate up-- though, they would probably be expecting me. Attempting to swallow my anxiety, I gingerly knocked on the door.

No response.

I knocked a little louder.

No response.

A little louder.

Still no response. Maybe my roommate was out?

I didn't want to be rude, but my feet were practically screaming at me by this point-- I was exhausted. I gulped as I tried the knob, which was fortunately unlocked. "Pardon me," I called sheepishly as I cracked the door open. Peering inside, I could clearly see that the lights were on.

"Er- Hello?" I called again, opening the door to poke my head further inside. I was met with no response, but someone else definitely lived here. Clothes were strewn about one side of the room, and a cute Chansey doll rested atop disheveled bed. Opposite that, the other side of the room appeared empty, save for a bare mattress. Presumably, that would be my bed.

I once again checked the note and number on the door, confirming that I did, in fact, have the correct room.

Oh well. I entered, closing the door behind me. I was just too tired to care.

I immediately plopped myself onto the bare mattress, and the world around me went black.

----

I awoke to the sound of footsteps entering the room, causing me to shoot up. How long was I out?

In the doorway stood a petite girl with shaggy pink hair. She wore thick, dramatic eye makeup--and a completely deadpan expression.

"You're awake." She spoke, her voice as devoid of emotion as her face. "You're the transfer student, I take it? I was told you'd be late."

"That's me," I yawned, offering a wobbly hand to the girl. "I'm Peppa. You can call me Pep, though."

"Pep it is then." She gave me a dubious look, before shaking my hand. "I'm Rita. You can call me.... Rita."

I laughed nervously. Was that supposed to be a joke?

"I had some.. family stuff to take care of last night, so I left the lights on. I didn't expect you to crash without even changing clothes, though. Long trip then, yeah?"

"All the way from Hoenn," I replied, rubbing the sleep from my eyes.

"Well, as much as I love small talk, we really ought to book it. Our teacher is.. interesting. I'd prefer not to be on her shit-list."

"We're in the same class, then?"

Rita nodded. "You missed orientation yesterday, so I was told to make sure you got to class today. You mind getting a move-on?"

"Ah, right. Sorry." I replied, scurrying out of bed. I didn't want her getting into any trouble on my account.

As I rose, I realized I had been draped with a pink, fuzzy blanket. I turned to look at my new roommate, but got the feeling that she was intentionally avoiding my gaze. I smirked. What a nice girl.

After a quick rinse in the shower, I donned my favorite outfit- My signature corduroy jacket, a cute Gulpin t-shirt, and some light-denim jeans. Tying the ensemble together was my trusty pair of (slightly scuffed) steel-toed boots. Fiddling with my bangs for a moment, I gave myself a quick once-over in the mirror, decidedly pleased with myself-- I was ready to go.

chapters.name: Chapter 3 - First Day Jitters
chapters.content:
As Rita and I made our way down the hall, I couldn't help but notice that the sea of students seemed to part to let us through. Despite my best efforts to keep my eyes down, I couldn't help but feel the stares of our fellow peers pelting us from all sides.

I swallowed, feeling a lump of anxiety forming in my throat. This was the prestigious Jubilife Academy-- surely transfer students weren't so uncommon as to illicit this amount of attention?

Battling my nerves, I raised my head as I continued to shuffle through the crowded hallway, following behind Rita closely. Some students whispered as we passed, giving furtive glances -- or straight up scowls -- in our general direction. While the student's gazes seemed to hang on me just for a moment, it was clear to see that the majority of them had their eyes fixed on Rita.

I internally facepalmed at my own self-absorption; feeling a wave of relief-- and then concern-- wash over me. On one hand, I was glad that I wasn't somehow already the object of their ire; but I couldn't help but wonder what their beef with Rita was about. She seemed nice enough to me, even if a bit standoffish.

Upon entering the classroom, I was greeted by an elderly woman who introduced herself as Mrs. Briar, and explained that she was the substitute teacher for the day. Apparently, the class's regular homeroom teacher was out sick. She pointed me to my seat, which happened to be smack in the middle of the classroom. No protagonist window seat for me, I mused. That spot appeared to be taken by Rita, who stared out the window with an uninterested look on her face. I couldn't help but internally chuckle to myself about how well that spot suited her, on account of all the brooding.

Despite Rita's insistence that we 'book it' to class, it seemed that we had been rather early, since we were among the first few students to take our seats. I yawned, watching as others steadily gathered in the classroom, taking their seats and engaging in small talk with their peers. A rather portly boy took his seat next to me, giving me a friendly smile as he sat down.

"I haven't seen you around before," the boy spoke.

"Yeah, uh. I just got in last night. I'm new here."

"Well hello, new here. I'm Tom." He grinned.

I gave a playful scoff. "Interesting choice for a first impression, Tom."

"What can I say? It's a gift. So, do you have a name or--?"

"Peppa. I prefer Pep though."

"Well, it's nice to meet you, Pep."

Tom and I chatted for a bit before class started. Fortunately for me, Mrs. Briar graciously allowed me to skip over the whole "transfer-student-introduction" bit, (Arceus bless her,) and instead opted to get right down to business.

"Now, as I'm sure you're all aware, it is customary that students in their final year be given their first partner Pok√©mon," Mrs. Briar paced as she spoke. "But today, we will be going over some basic information you need to know before you can take that first step."

"Jubilife Academy is known for its rather.. Unique approach in teaching these skills. While most schools may focus on written curriculum, we believe that hands-on experience is what truly makes a difference in our student's futures." Mrs. Briar turned on her heel and stopped. "Which is why we will not be giving you a Pok√©mon."

An air of shock and confusion filled the room as Mrs. Briar paused. Her gaze seemed to sweep across the room, giving each of us a hard glance.

"You will be capturing your first partner yourselves." She gave a shrewd smile. Puzzled looks shot around the classroom, but before anyone could raise any questions, Mrs. Briar continued.

"Now-- I'm sure you're all wondering how you're going to be capturing a wild Pok√©mon without already having a partner Pok√©mon to keep you safe; and you'd be right to ask that question. The answer is simple: It won't be safe. But you'll find out more from your homeroom teacher tomorrow."

I swallowed. I'm going to be meeting my partner Pok√©mon tomorrow.

chapters.name: Chapter 4 - Faux Pas
chapters.content:
After Mrs. Briar's lecture, the rest of the morning classes were a bit uneventful. We received basic refreshers in most courses, before being let out for lunch. Tom offered to show me to the cafeteria-- which I happily took him up on, as Rita seemed to disappear the moment the bell rang. It seems like she's just always in a rush.

"So, you said you're from Hoenn?" Tom asked, as a woman behind the counter made his plate.

"Mhm. Lilycove City, actually."

"That's where all the big Pok√©mon contests happen, right?"

"Well, in Hoenn, sure-- but Jubilife's contests are probably bigger."

"Well yeah, I guess you're right. It's just that Jubilife has so much else going on that I kind of forgot about that. I think most people here are all about the battles these days, though."

"Yeah, the city seems... Kind of intense."

Tom chuckled. "You'll get used to it."

I still don't believe that, but I do appreciate the attempt at reassurance, Tom.

The line moved forward, and I was given a tray of surprisingly good-looking food. Our lunch consisted of a salad, freshly cut fruits, and an egg salad sandwich. Simple-- but from what I recalled of school lunches in my previous life, I was always happy to receive something that actually resembled food.

As I expected from a world where all of the animals are relatively sapient, most people opted to be vegetarian. That isn't to say that people didn't eat meat, but it was much less common here. I personally had no qualms about this, as the thought of befriending and raising some Pok√©mon, only to turn around and eat others, didn't sit quite right with me.

Breaking away from the lunch line, I looked across the crowded cafeteria. Despite most of the tables being packed, there seemed to be an empty swathe cut right through the middle, where a familiar figure sat at a lone, empty table.

"Do you know her?" Tom asked, perhaps noticing the concern on my face.

"Not really, but she's my roommate. We just met this morning."

"And she didn't bite your head off?"

I frowned. "No? She was actually pretty nice."

Tom's eyes widened, but before he could say anything, I started heading towards the empty table. "I'll see you later, Tom." I called, my voice slightly straining above the cacophony of conversations taking place.

"Oh wow. This is actually pretty good," I said, swallowing a bite of my sandwich.

Rita blinked at me, her face void of any discernable expression. "Do you.. need something from me?"

"Hmm?"

"I'm asking what you want."

"I just want to eat my lunch," I replied, taking a swig of my little carton of milk.

Rita's eyes narrowed. "You don't have to follow me everywhere, you know."

I paused. "I'm sorry if I'm bothering you. I could leave if you want. I just.. Didn't like seeing you eating by yourself."

"Oh. So that's what this is." Rita stood up. "Well, you can consider your good deed for the day done then."

"Wait--" I stammered, "I didn't mean it like--"

"I don't want your pity, okay? Just.. Mind your own business." Rita sighed.

Before I could say anything else, Rita stormed off, leaving me alone at the table.

Shit. That could have gone better.

With Rita gone, the table felt like an island, surrounded by an ocean of prying eyes from all angles. As good as the food was, I doubted I could continue eating now. I wondered if this was how she felt, before I came traipsing in like a white-knight. I'm such an asshole.

The rest of the day dragged on, though I struggled to pay attention to much. I replayed the conversation with Rita in my head over and over, internally reprimanding myself. Nobody likes to feel pitied. I begrudged my own social ineptitude.

I walked slowly on my way back to the dorms, mentally rehearsing how I would apologize to Rita when I got there. By now the sun had already begun to set; golden light dappled the courtyard through a canopy of carefully pruned trees. My eyes followed a couple of Starly flying off into the horizon. I wonder if I'll get capture one while I'm here, I wondered.

Really, any Pok√©mon would be fine, as long as they were okay with having me as a trainer. My stomach churned with a combination of nerves and excitement. What kind of trainer would I get to be?

"Pardon me, Peppa." a familiar voice called, snapping me from my thoughts. Beatrice stood before me, fixing the cuffs of her sleeves.

"Oh, Hi Beatrice. Thanks again for last night." I chuckled nervously as I looked down at her.

"It was no trouble. Do you have a moment? There's something I wanted to speak with you about."

"Um, sure-" I stammered. "I'm not already in trouble though, am I?"

"No, not at all. Walk with me, please."

I did my best to keep my composure as I followed beside her. Despite her diminutive stature, Beatrice cut a rather imposing figure. She stood perfectly straight, spoke eloquently, and overall seemed to exude an air of importance.

"I couldn't help but notice you in the cafeteria today." She spoke without looking at me.

Great, she saw me make an ass of myself.

"Not that it's any of my business, but you may want to be careful with who you decide to associate with."

I paused for a moment, but kept walking. "What do you mean?"

"I'm referring to Rita Joy," she started, flipping her long hair away from her face as she walked. "I'm afraid not much good came come of associating with her."

"Okay, this is getting ridiculous. What is everyone's deal? Because it seems like bullying."

"I can see why you'd think that, but Rita is.. Well, an interesting case. She gets nearly perfect grades, never misses classes, and is from a prestigious family. You could call her a model student."

"So, what's the problem?" I asked, growing impatient.

"All of this is precisely why it came as a shock when she suddenly attacked a student last year."

"What?"

I stopped dead in my tracks. "That.. doesn't sound right." I may have just met Rita this morning, but she didn't seem like the violent type to me.

"I don't know the exact details of what happened, but another student was hospitalized last year after getting into a fight with her. There were a few witnesses who attested to seeing Rita attack the girl without any provocation."

"I... see." I paused. "Why are you telling me all of this?"

"I was advised to warn you. As the future heiress of the Carmine family, it would serve you well to choose your friends carefully, after all."

I swallowed hard-- I did not like where this was going.

"How did you know that?"

"Surely you didn't think the Academy would have sent an escort for just anyone?"

Beatrice blinked at me, and then laughed. "You are interesting, Peppa."

I looked down at her, unable to find anything to say in response.

"Mind you, I know that she's you're roommate, but it wouldn't hurt to exercise caution. People like us have too much at stake to risk being dragged down before our careers even have a chance to start."

"People like us?" My tone betrayed a hint of bitterness that surprised me when I spoke. Calm down, Pep.

"Please, you understand." Beatrice smiled.

"I actually don't--"

Before I could finish that sentence, Beatrice clapped her hands together, cutting me off entirely.

"Well, it was lovely chatting with you, Peppa. I'm looking forward to seeing how you fare tomorrow."

I watched Beatrice's back as she strode off, bile rising in my throat. I didn't have much choice in coming to Sinnoh for my final year, but I chose not to put up a fight in hopes it might get me away from all of the social politics surrounding my family-- a naive thought, in hindsight. There really was no way of escaping my father's scrutiny, it seemed.

I sighed, pushing away the thought. Dwelling on this now wasn't going to help. Whatever the old man had in store for me, I would just have to deal with it as it came. Moreover, what did Beatrice mean by 'how I fare' tomorrow? Was she referring to what Mrs. Briar said about catching our own partner Pok√©mon?

chapters.name: Chapter 5 - High Stakes
chapters.content:
I fiddled with my pencil, waiting for class to begin. Rita hadn't been home last night when I made it back to the dorm, but she had been the first to arrive to the classroom this morning. I had considered approaching her to apologize for yesterday's blunder, but decided now probably wasn't the best time. Other students had begun to pile in, and I didn't want to risk the possibility of turning it into a spectacle. There was no point in apologizing if I just ended up making her feel uncomfortable in the process.

I yawned, tears forming in my eyes. Between the guilt I felt about yesterday, and excitement at the prospect of finally meeting my first partner Pok√©mon, finding any sort of meaningful sleep had been a fruitless effort.

Today was finally the day, after all. The past seventeen years of my new life had been leading up to now.

"So how was your first day yesterday, Pep?"

I jumped as Tom spoke. I hadn't even heard him sit down.

"Well, uh. It was good, I guess." I lied.

"I'm sorry if I startled you. You looked a million miles away there. Are you settling in okay?" Tom's hazel-green eyes shone with concern.

"Yeah, why?"

"Well, I mean. Just asking. Is the.. dorm okay?"

I frowned, grasping the double-meaning of his question.

"I just wanted to see if you were doing okay is all. You know, because.." Tom's gaze flicked towards the window and back to me.

Because of Rita's supposed violent reputation.

"Its fine." I huffed, dropping my head into my arms. "I made an ass of myself yesterday, though."

"Really? What happ-"

"ALRIGHT, LISTEN UP KIDDOS." A woman's voice boomed over the din of classroom chatter, squashing it completely.

A tall woman with a commanding presence strode through the classroom, taking her place at the forefront.

"We've got a lot to get through so I'll keep introductions short. My name is Vivienne Kimber, and I will be your teacher for all things Pok√©mon this year."

The woman, Ms. Kimber- sported a thick mop of brown, curly hair, and piercing brown eyes. She wore a rugged, oversized jacket that featured a pattern reminiscent of a stony cliff face-

Wait a second.

"Now, as you all heard from Mrs. Briar yesterday, you will be capturing your first Pok√©mon today. As she may have informed you, our approach here at Jubilife Academy is a bit different than what you would normally expect."

My eyes widened in recognition. This was the same lady from the plane.

"Normally, you would just be given a Pok√©mon, right? Not here. You need to earn your Pok√©mon, just as you need to earn your place here. We aren't the best of the best for nothing, and we sure as heck aren't going to let you take it easy. I know you're all excited to meet your first Pok√©mon, but this isn't going to be a walk in the park. I expect you all to take this very seriously."

A few students shuffled uncomfortably.

"Don't think of this just as an important milestone, but also a critically important exam. As such, you will be graded on your performance. Make sure you all listen closely, this is a test you definitely want to pass."

"What will happen if we fail?" A girl asked from behind me.

"Failure to successfully capture your first Pok√©mon will result in expulsion."

The severity of her statement had been punctuated by a nearly collective gasp. All around the room jaws dropped and eyes widened. There were a few panicked exclamations and students attempting to ask questions, but they went ignored as Ms. Kimber seemed to relish the panicked response of her students.

Our teacher stood silently for a few moments, a small but unmistakably sinister grin tugging at the corners of her lips. Her eyes seemed to scan over the room, perhaps gauging our individual reactions.

Her eyes lingered on me for just a moment, sending a shiver down my spine. I wondered if she had recognized me.

After going through all that I had; being reborn into the world of Pokemon and living out the last seventeen years as a member of the Carmine family-- there was no way I could return home empty-handed. My family's expectations had weighed heavily on me since I came here, but now I found that my own expectations weighed even heavier. Though it was becoming increasingly difficult to recall my previous self, I was certain that the me I had been in the other world would never forgive the present me if I were to let this chance slip by. Graduation from the Academy practically guaranteed a sponsorship once the term ended, which meant this was the best opportunity I would have at becoming a real Pok√©mon trainer. Getting sponsored meant a monthly stipend among other benefits, which would be critical to supporting and building a team. If I was going to live out my dreams, I quite literally couldn't afford to be stopped here.

I took a deep breath. I wouldn't fail. I couldn't.

Looking over, I noticed that the color had drained completely from Tom's freckled face. Everyone else probably was having thoughts not too dissimilar to my own.

"Now, I will give you a brief explanation of how you will go about capturing your Pok√©mon. I will then escort you to the site on Route 204, where we will begin."

"If you have any questions...."

Numerous hands shot up.

"..Save them for later." Ms. Kimber coughed. "Like I said, we have a lot to get through."

chapters.name: Chapter 6 - The Barrier
chapters.content:
The tense, nervous energy that had taken hold of our class had given way to tired, agitated grumblings as we shuffled along towards our destination.

Ms. Kimber checked over her shoulder periodically, ensuring we hadn't lost anyone on our trek. At this point, we had walked for what felt like miles. The paved roads of the city had long since given way to the dirt and gravel pathways of Route 204.

I looked up, wiping a bead of sweat from my brow. By now, the sun was beating down on us from above. Judging from its position, it looked to be about noon.

Before setting off, Ms. Kimber had given us a brief rundown of what we were to expect. Upon arriving at our destination, we would be given our Pokeballs, along with some basic supplies. We would then set off on our own, and attempt to catch our first Pok√©mon ourselves-- much how the people of Ancient Hisui once did. We would then have until sundown to return to the meeting point with a captured Pok√©mon.

Apparently the Academy had been known as the "Jubilife Survey Corps" long ago, and took immense pride in that legacy. Back when people feared Pok√©mon as unstoppable forces of nature, the members of the Survey Corps were among the first to pave the way to partnership between Pok√©mon and people-- hence the significance of catching a Pok√©mon with our own two hands. The people of ancient Hisui hadn't had the luxury of being provided with Pok√©mon to keep them safe, and neither would we-- At least, that was what we had been told. In the modern age, sending a bunch of teenagers out into the wilderness without their own Pok√©mon would be immensely frowned upon, (if not outright illegal), but I was certain that the Academy must have some way of ensuring our safety. If not, I doubted that the most prominent and prestigious families would have been sending their children here for generations.

My eyes followed a couple of Jumpluff that lazily floated through the sky over head, before I promptly smacked into the person walking ahead of me.

"Watch where you're going!" A short girl with blonde ringlet-curls snapped, turning to look at me. She stiffened when she looked up and saw me looming over her.

"Ah, uh. I'm sorry." I looked down with a weak smile. "Are we stopping?"

"Yeah. Looks like it. I can't see much ahead though." She huffed.

I craned my neck to look over the throng of students. Past the wall of bodies, I was able to make out a shimmering dome-shaped structure among the surrounding forest.

"Alright everyone, pile in!" Ms. Kimber called over the crowd.

As we made our way towards the strange, iridescent dome, we were greeted by a couple of Kadabra-- each holding out a spoon respectively. Their eyes beamed with bright purple light as the duo raised their spoons high. With a mystical shing, an opening formed in the dome-- large enough for everyone to enter.

"Thankyou, Kadabra." Ms. Kimber addressed the two, but they did not respond as they continued to hold their spoons high. Just as the whole class had shuffled in, the opening in the dome sealed itself behind us.

I stood stock-still in amazement, marveling at the shimmering construct that encompassed an entire expanse of forest around us.

Is this.. a move? I don't remember any moves like this.

Wait a second. Could it be reflect? Or light screen?

I approached the wall of the dome, where we had just entered. Pressing my hand against it, I found that any force exerted against it rebounded backwards. I tried to push with a bit more pressure, but my hand was sent flying back with ease.

It must be Reflect then. But, it shouldn't be this strong. This type of scale should be impossible. How is this possible?

"Something wrong?" Tom approached from behind me.

He was dripping sweat and panting slightly-- the walk here, especially with the heat, must have been rough on him. Looking around, most of my classmates seemed to be in a similar state. I was thankful to be faring a little better, even if not by much. I silently thanked God, or Arceus-- or whoever, for giving me such a strong body this time. I didn't like to think about it, but I knew that I hadn't been so lucky before.

"Oh, Yeah! Um, sorry." I coughed. "I was just wondering what this is-- or how its even possible." I gestured towards the wall.

"That would be a barrier." A woman wearing a lab coat approached us, holding a clipboard. "Not to be confused with the move barrier. This is actually a highly advanced application of a couple of moves commonly known by Psychic type Pok√©mon."

"But.. How is it so big?"

The researcher beamed. "I'm glad you asked! We actually have a few dozen different-"

"I see you've met one of our on-site researchers." Ms. Kimber interrupted, placing her hand on the woman's shoulder. The researcher froze.

"Don't worry kids, there will be plenty of time for questions later-- but we're on a tight schedule. Lets keep it moving, yeah?" Ms. Kimber winked.

The researcher gave me an apologetic look, before sheepishly returning to her work.

I internally bristled. I really wanted to know, damn it!

Ms. Kimber led us to a clearing where a handful of tables had been set up. On each of the tables, a few dozen bags had been neatly laid out.

"Okay everybody, listen up." Ms. Kimber cleared her throat as she addressed the throng of expectant students.

"Each of you will take one bag. Inside each bag, you will find three pokeballs, a pokedex, and some basic supplies. Line up single file and begin."

One by one my classmates stepped forward. When my turn to claim a bag came, I found my hands trembling with anticipation. The bag itself seemed to have been made of high-quality material, and even featured an adjustable over-the-shoulder sling. I stepped out of the line, fiddling with one of the bag's many zippers.

Reaching inside, I fished out the Pokedex Ms. Kimber had mentioned. It sort of resembled a flip-phone from my previous world-- one of the bulky ones from the early 2000's. It featured what looked to be a camera lens on the back, most likely intended for scanning pokemon. I pocketed it and continued rummaging through the bag's contents. Inside, I found a couple bottles of water, a small pack containing some berries, and three pokeballs.

Taking out one of the pokeballs, I watched with childlike wonder as the device shrunk down to belt-clip size upon clicking the button at its center. I tapped the button a few more times, watching as it shrunk and grew repeatedly. I had no idea how the mechanics of the pokeball worked, but nonetheless, the technological wonder of the little device was not lost on me.

"First time seeing a pokeball?" Tom asked.

"No, I've seen them. I've just never gotten to hold one." I responded. "I never thought of it before now, but how do you reckon its even possible for a whole pokemon to fit inside this little thing?"

Tom ruffled his sandy-blonde hair for a moment. "I don't think anyone knows, aside from the people who make them." He shrugged.

I marveled at the thing a moment longer before slipping it back into one of the front pockets of the bag for easy access. Soon I would be getting to use it.

A grin spread across my face, and for a moment, all of my prior nerves melted away. My Pok√©mon was out there, waiting for me to come and find them.

It wouldn't be long now, and I didn't intend on keeping them waiting.

chapters.name: Chapter 7 - A Harsh Lesson
chapters.content:
I tried my best to keep myself alert as Tom and I shuffled through the forest. Light filtered in from above, dappling the leaf-covered forest floor. Some of the trees had begun changing color-- Autumn would be upon us soon. Throughout the forest, the sounds of Pok√©mon cries echoed, setting me on edge. I gripped the pokeball in my pocket tight as I sidestepped around twigs and loose stones. I needed to keep my footsteps as light as possible-- It wouldn't do to scare off any potential encounters.

My mind swirled with anxiety--I had to find a pokemon, I needed to. I couldn't afford to fail here. Everything I wanted was riding on this.

Just as I began to spiral, a cracking noise broke me from my thoughts-- above, a Chimchar was playing in the branches of a nearby tree.

Without thinking, I immediately lobbed the pokeball gripped white-knuckle tight in my hand at the little monkey. To my surprise, the pokeball was right on target-- but my stomach sank as the Chimchar looked down at me with a devious grin. I watched as the little pokemon actually caught the pokeball, and without missing a beat, launched it straight back at me. The metal ball slammed into my forehead with such force that I fell backwards.

"Augghh! You little shit!" I growled in frustration as the little monkey pokemon slapped his behind, clearly taunting me. The Chimchar pointed and laughed at me, before swinging away through the dense canopy.

"Oh, gosh. That looks like it might bruise. Are you okay?" Tom ran to my side, offering to help me up.

"I'm fine," I grumbled, taking Tom's arm. "I'll get him next time."

I took deep breaths as we continued on in silence. I needed to calm down-- as frustrating as it was, I couldn't afford to lose my cool like that again.

"So, was that your plan?" Tom asked over his shoulder as he stepped over a large branch.

"What do you mean?" I responded, my eyes still searching the canopy for the Chimchar that wounded my pride... and my face.

"Are you just going to meander around, lobbing pokeballs at the first thing you see?"

I stopped in my tracks. I hadn't really had a plan to begin with, but since he put it that way, I felt a bit silly.

Tom laughed, taking my silence as an affirmative.

"Hey, don't worry. Thats probably what ninety-percent of the class is planning on doing, too."

"Well, what are you going to do then?" I huffed, rubbing the forming bump on my forehead. If he had any better ideas, I was all ears.

Tom put his hand out, gesturing for me to stop, before placing a finger to his lips in a shushing motion.

"You hear that?" He grinned. "We're getting close."

I listened for what he was talking about, but all I could hear was the sound of Pokemon calls and leaves rustling in the wind.

"Uh... close to what, exactly?"

"Water. Running water." His grin grew cartoonishly. "Thats my plan."

"Okay?" I shrugged.

Tom sighed upon seeing my confusion. "Water means water-type Pokemon. Running water means safe drinking water. Which means even more Pok√©mon."

"Oh." My cheeks flushed. "That... does sound like a good place to start."

Of course, Pokemon would need to drink somewhere. Safe drinking water would create a place where pokemon would naturally gather. I couldn't help but feel a little embarrassed for not thinking of that-- it was certainly a better plan than... well, nothing.

Cutting our way through dense underbrush, we soon came across the source of the sounds Tom heard-- a gentle river that flowed straight through the forest. All of my prior frustration melted away as I took in the sight before me-- it was truly breathtaking, like something you'd see on a postcard. The river curved in a soft bend through thick holts of trees; I watched as fallen leaves danced across the water's surface, before making their way down a couple of gently slopping waterfalls just at the river's bend. The spray coming off the waterfalls shimmered in the sun, making small rainbow effects in the light.

Stolen novel; please report.

Tom sat down beside the river's edge, fiddling with his bag. Looking down, I noted a few shadows moving under the water's surface.

A little ways away, a Magikarp leaped with a splash, flopping back down into the water.

"Here we go," Tom said, retrieving an Oran berry from his bag. He broke the berry in half, before holding it just below the water. "Its like fishing!"

I sat down next to him, staring at my reflection in the water. "Think it will work?"

"Eh, probably. Either way, some Pok√©mon are bound to come here sooner or later. I just hope I don't lose a finger."

I gave a sheepish chuckle. "That would be hard to explain to your parents."

For a moment I could have sworn I saw Tom's cheery expression darken at the mention of his parents, but he didn't say anything more-- and I certainly didn't want to pry. For now I was content to wait in companiable silence. Now that I had calmed down, I had a good opportunity to reassess my strategy.

It wasn't long before we were greeted by the face of a particularly chubby Goldeen, as it happily snatched the piece of berry from Tom's fingers. He reached out and gave the Goldeen a gentle pat on the head, to which it gave a contented trill in response.

"Oh would you look at this beauty-- a Goldeen," Tom beamed as the pok√©mon gently nibbled at his fingers. "Did you like the berry, Goldeen?"

"Deeen!"

"You can have a little more, but not too much, okay? I don't have very much on me."

"Gol!" The chunky fish spun in a circle, fanning out her billowing fins in affirmation.

I took out my pokedex, and aimed it at the happily-splashing creature.

With a beep, its entry popped up immediately, which I read aloud:

"Goldeen, the Goldfish Pokemon. Goldeen is a water-type pokemon commonly found in rivers, lakes, and ponds. Though Goldeen are generally docile, they are capable of inflicting staggering amounts of damage with the sharp horn on their heads."

"Here, hit that button there-- it should be able to give us specific details on this Goldeen, I think." Tom gestured without touching the device, on account of his wet hands.

"Goldeen, female. Ability: Water Veil."

Goldeen eyed my pokedex curiously, perhaps wondering how the little device knew so much about her.

"Are you going to catch her?" Excitement bubbled in my chest as Tom fed Goldeen the other half of the oran berry.

"Well, that depends," The boy mused. "Would you like to come with me, Goldeen? To become a trainer pokemon?"

The fish paused for a moment before gulping down the other half of the Oran berry.

"Gol... Go-ol?" She stared up, seemingly puzzled.

"You see, that would mean catching you in this ball," Tom held out the Pokeball for Goldeen to see. "If you came with me, it would mean that we would be partners. Pokemon trainers work with their pokemon and direct them in battle. Does battling sound like something you'd want to do?"

Goldeen stayed silent for a moment, looking conflicted. "Eeen..."

"Its okay if you aren't sure. You could think about it if you want?" Tom assured the Pokemon. "If you do want to come with me though, you'll have to decide before sundown, okay?"

The pokemon trilled, as if to say "I'll consider it," before disappearing under the water. Tom watched Goldeen's shadow as she swam away.

Tom stared at the water, his face unreadable.

I stared for a few moments, unsure of what to say.

"...Did you want to catch her?"

"Well, sure I did," He replied, wiping his hands on his pant-legs. "but what its not just about what I want. What Goldeen wants is important, too."

A wave of realization washed over me. Earlier I had been so eager to lob a pokeball at the first thing I saw, and not once had I ever considered that I should ask the Pokemon what it wanted first. I felt a pit of guilt form in my stomach. No wonder that Chimchar hit me in the face. I wanted to hit myself in the face too, right about now.

After a long silence, I let my shoulders slump with a deep sigh.

"You're a good guy, Tom."

"...I wouldn't say that." Tom shrugged. "I'm just trying to be decent."

Tom was right. This wasn't a game like it had been in my old world. After seventeen years, I was so sure that I understood that. Pokemon were real-- and alive here. They had thoughts, and wants, and feelings-- and if I hadn't seen Tom's interaction with Goldeen, I could have been someone who callously trampled all over that. If not for Chimchar catching my pokeball, there was a very real possibility that I would have been.

Asking for the Pok√©mon's consent wasn't something only a good person would do-- it should be common decency. I wanted to be my pokemon's friend, not their captor. What gave me the right to force them to accept me as their trainer?

Maybe that was the point of capturing Pok√©mon this way; the point of the 'exam' itself. We didn't have the option of weakening a Pok√©mon and forcing it to join us-- we were supposed to convince it to come with us of its own accord.

I stood up with a start, slapping myself on the cheeks. The sound caused Tom to flinch.

There was no time left to lose. If I was going to catch a pokemon today, I was going to do it right. If I ended up failing, so be it. All I could do was try my best, and hope that there was a pokemon in this forest content to have me as its trainer. Steeling myself, I slung my bag over my shoulders and across my chest.

"Umm, Pep?" Tom stared at me with clear concern. "You okay?"

"Tom, thankyou. I think I'm going to go off on my own now."

"Oh-um. Alright." Despite looking confused, Tom gave me a supportive smile. "Good luck, Pep."

"Thanks. You too, man. I'll see you later."

"Later, then. Be careful out there."

chapters.name: Chapter 8 - Berry from Hell
chapters.content:
By now the sun had slightly dipped from its peak in the sky; I had estimated it to be around two o'clock in the afternoon. Far above me, the strange psychic dome-construct fainty shimmered in the sunlight. From here it was barely even perceptible-- I had to really squint to see it. I still wondered how the mechanics of it all worked, but decided that now wasn't the time to question it. The clock was ticking.

On my hike I had encountered a couple of Pok√©mon, none of which seemed all too pleased to see me. I had only narrowly avoided getting hit with a panicked Oddish's stun spore, before a group of territorial Shinx decided that I had trespassed on their property. Needless to say, I had done quite a bit of running-- by now my feet had long since been throbbing with exertion. Nevertheless, I was grateful to come away from the encounter with only exhaustion, considering it could have been electrical burns.

I stopped to catch my breath at the river's edge-- noticing a couple of Lotad lazily drifting down the river. I shielded my face the second their eyes fell on me, bracing for an attack that thankfully never came. Almost every Pok√©mon I had come across thus far had attempted to attack me on sight, but fortunately, these Lotad seemed completely indifferent to my presence.

Breathing out a sigh of relief, I decided that maybe this would be a good opportunity. Indifference was much better than aggression, so I figured that perhaps I had a shot at befriending the placid little creatures. Mimicking Tom's strategy, I called out to them--holding out a fresh berry in attempts of grabbing their attention. One of the Lotad peeked its head up, briefly inspecting the berry-- but quickly decided it wasn't interested.

"Ohoh, you're too good for my berries, then?" I jokingly huffed at the lily pad creatures, as they continued their lazy commute down the river.

Taking a seat on the grass, I watched for a few moments as the Pok√©mon floated away. Such pleasant little guys, I thought to myself.

Soon, my attention was ripped away by a loud rumble from my stomach. "Time for a break, I guess." I chuckled.

Dubiously, I eyed bright-red berry in my hands. If memory served me correctly, this was a cherri berry. Much like its name implied, it closely resembled a cherry from Earth, except much larger-- about the size of a lemon. I hadn't tried one before, but I'd seen my father's Ninetales gobble them up just fine-- so I figured, why not. At the very least I knew that they weren't toxic-- I'd heard some people used them to season their food. I internally shrugged. In a survival settling, I could probably do a lot worse.

I took a bite of the berry-- and immediately wished I hadn't.

It was hot.

So hot.

Tears welled in my eyes as I coughed the berry out onto the grass. Nothing could have prepared me for how aggressive the taste of this innocuous looking berry would be-- How could anything taste this.... anything. Within moments, the sadistic piece of produce had reduced me to a heaving, sweat-drenched mess.

It was like biting into a cherry that had been infused with the raw essence of every chili pepper on Earth, dunked repeatedly in sriracha sauce, and then marinated in the full concentrated power of the sun.

Every tastebud on my tongue seemed to wail in endless, burning torment; I coughed relentlessly as white-hot pain gripped my throat.

I was certain-- nothing could be more anything than this berry was spicy. On the Scoville scale, I would have given in a ten-billion.

I coughed and gagged, tears streaming down my face as I scrambled to empty the contents of my bag. Objects clinked and thudded as they hit the ground, scattering everywhere. I didn't care.

Finally-- my prize hit the grass with a thud. I looked at the water bottle in front of me as if it had descended from the heavens above. Without wasting a second, I snatched up the bottle, uncapping it. Water splashed my face, drenching the front of my shirt as I took greedy gulps between sobs.

It wasn't enough. Somehow, the flaming, burning hell unleashed in my mouth had only been tamped down slightly-- as if I'd tried using garden hose to put out a forest fire.

I didn't just regret eating this berry. I regretted being born.

Panicking, I desperately searched the scattered pile of supplies for another bottle-- but had no such luck.

There was little choice now. With a splash, I dunked my head into the blessedly clean looking river, gulping down as much water as I could without choking. I had to go back a couple more times before experiencing any meaningful relief.

Thankfully, the pain had finally begun to dull-- though my mouth still felt thoroughly scorched. I had a feeling I wouldn't be tasting anything for a while.

Panting, I flopped myself back onto the grass. For a while, I just laid there, trying to take deep breaths. Then the tears came.

"I'm an idiot." I laughed sardonically. "I don't have time for this."

I forced myself upright, and began to gather my dumped belongings. One by one, I haphazardly thrusted each object back into my bag.

"Stupid me," I crushed the empty water bottle. "stupid school."

Suddenly, my hand touched the partially-eaten berry. I stared down at it hatefully, as the sob I had been stifling bubbled up in my throat.

"STUPID BERRY!" I wailed, throwing the wretched fruit as hard as I could.

A couple of moment later, a Pok√©mon's cry snapped me from my tantrum. I froze as the bushes behind me rustled.

chapters.name: Chapter 9 - A Bond Forged in Berry Juice
chapters.content:
I silently cursed myself for choosing to set off alone. Just an hour ago I had been so confident, and now here I was-- cowering in the dirt.

I half expected whatever magical beast I had unwittingly thrown the berry at to come charging out of the bushes at any moment. Images of gnashing teeth and rending claws filled my mind--In the Pokemon world, it was entirely possible that the creature behind these bushes could probably zap, scorch, or drown me on the spot.

The bushes shook violently-- sending me scooting backwards as I flinched away; my eyes shut tightly as I feared for the worst.

But no attack came.

Peeking through my fingers, I slowly turned to look at whatever had popped out of the bushes. Thankfully, the pokemon that emerged hadn't been anything close to the terrifying beast my mind had cooked up. It was... small, among the smallest I'd ever seen. The 'beast' I had been cowering from barely stood at a foot tall, if that. I quickly recognized this pokemon as a wild surskit. All at once I deflated, letting out the breath I had been holding with a deep sigh.

This was still a pokemon--an anomalous being capable of wielding the forces of nature on a whim--so it went without saying that it wasn't to be underestimated. Even so, I couldn't help but feel relieved. I had seen surskit before, as they were native to Hoenn-- much like myself. (If you didn't count Earth, I suppose.)

The pokemon's shape was defined by its blue, orb-like body at its center, supported by four spindly legs. On the top of it's head/body, it sported an orange, antennae-like appendage that now skewered my thrown cherri berry. It's face featured two small, beady eyes, with little pink markings underneath that resembled blush. Truthfully, my mind couldn't have conjured a less intimidating image if I had tried. The only word that came to mind upon seeing the disgruntled surskit was, "Cute."

"Sskit! Surrss! Ssk-Kit!" The tiny pok√©mon hissed, it's adorable bug eyes blazing at me with barely contained rage.

"I-I'm sorry," I coughed, suppressing the nervous laughter that threatened to bubble up within my sore throat. "I promise I didn't mean to hit you with that."

The perturbed little bug drew closer, it's tiny body wobbling under the weight of the berry now stuck to it's head.

"Suuuursss! SSsskiti-iit!" It shrieked. I interpreted this as, "Watch where you're throwing things, you stupid human!"

The laughter died in my throat as I once again flinched, but only slightly this time. Instead of attacking, the surskit let out a pitiful cry as it lifted a leg and began furiously rubbing it against its face.

"Here, let me get that for you." I reached for the berry, eliciting a shrill hiss from the bug. Startled, it unleashed a torrent of bubbles from its mouth that stung slightly on impact. I winced under the sudden bombardment, but the attack fortunately left me with no real damage to speak of.

The cloud of bubbles quickly dissipated, revealing the surskit in clear distress. I looked on in confusion as it desperately rubbed its face into the dirt. "What is it doing?"

A gasp escaped me as my eyes once again locked onto the berry stuck to the pokemon's head.

"The juice! It's in your eyes, isn't it?"

All at once, recollections of chopping jalape√±os back on Earth flooded my mind. A blurry image of a woman--no, my mother-- reminded me to always wash my hands after handling the spicy peppers, and to never touch my face after chopping them. The image flickered, revealing the child I had once been ignoring her mother's warnings, only to end up with her face under a running faucet minutes later. My head throbbed with a dull ache as I mentally pushed the images away.

Much like how I once ate jalape√±os, a pokemon might have been able to eat a cherri berry without issue-- but that didn't necessarily mean that getting it's juices into their eyes wouldn't hurt like hell. After experiencing the wrath of the cherri berry firsthand, the poor surskit truly had my deepest condolences. I wouldn't have wished that pain upon my worst enemy-- and here I had inflicted it upon an innocent bystander.

Guilt overtook me, swallowing my prior inhibitions-- I needed to fix this somehow.
