"Please, I just want to help you," I pleaded as I inched closer to the flailing pokemon.

"SSssuurss," the Surskit protested, again hissing at me through a face-full of grime.

My heart sunk further as I watched the poor surskit frantically thrash about in the dirt; it's insectoid legs flailing wildly in the air. The pokemon wailed in distress-- It couldn't seem to dislodge the berry by itself.

"I did this," I admonished myself internally. "Even if Surskit attacks me, I've got to get that berry off of it."

Swallowing, I scooped up the Surskit, fully prepared to take another blast of stinging bubbles to the face. As quickly as I could manage, I plucked the skewered berry off of Surskit's antennae, tossing it onto the grass where it could cause no further harm.

The pokemon looked up at me for a moment, tears pooling at the edges of it's tiny black eyes. "Ssskit?"

"Its okay, buddy." I tried my best to make my voice as low and soothing as possible. "I'm going to get the juice off of you, now--so please don't shoot me in the face with anything, okay?"

Surskit gave me a long, hard stare--before surprising me with a strangely person-esque nod. Earlier, I hadn't been sure it even knew what I was saying, but I took this as confirmation that it could understand me just fine.

As I rose, I carefully cradled the surskit against my chest. Unsurprisingly, the diminutive pokemon seemed to weigh almost nothing at all.

"Heeere we go," I hummed, gently lowering the Pok√©mon into the river.

Instead of becoming submerged, Surskit stood perfectly still on the water as if it were dry land-- and I quickly set to to my task. Surskit whimpered and shifted slightly in response to my touch, but fortunately gave me no further trouble. Now that the pokemon had calmed down a bit, it allowed me to gently splash it's face with water; keeping it's eyes tightly shut as I wiped away the grime.

"Surskit, I need you to open your eyes for me, okay?" I gently cajoled the little bug. "I promise, it will feel much better when I'm done."

Thankfully, it didn't seem to take much convincing, as Surskit reluctantly opened one eye a couple of moments later.

I gently scooped water into my hand, carefully pouring it over Surskit's exposed eye.

The pokemon blinked at me a couple of times, before giving a contented trill.

"See? That wasn't so bad." A small smile tugged at the corners of my lips. "Are you ready to do the other one?"

"Skiiit!"

With Surskit's prior apprehension having all but melted away, I had an even easier time of rinsing her eyes-- she now seemed to lean into my touch, even if just a little bit. A dopey grin stretched across my face as I gave the bug a gentle pat on the head. With her mood having improved greatly, the pokemon did a little spin on the water-- happily blowing little bubbles from her mouth.

Unfortunately, just as I began to laugh, my head was again seized by a throbbing, searing pain. I winced, desperately blinking away images of my mother on Earth cajoling me in much the same way I had just done with Surskit.

Concern clouded Surskit's eyes as she paused her celebration. "Suuurss?"

"Ah- don't worry. I'm okay. Here, I've got something for you." Giving my head a shake, I pulled my jacket kept wrapped around my waist free, and offered the sleeve to Surskit to dry her face.

Surskit blinked at the jacket, and back at me, as if to say "What is that for?"

Upon closer inspection, it appeared that Surskit was already perfectly dry.

"Oh, that's right. You're a water-type, aren't you?"

I'd learned in school that water-type pokemon generally weren't effected by water the same way people are. I could only assume that Surskit's body had somehow already absobered the moisture.

Surskit tilted it's head quizzically in response to my question.

"Yeah, I guess you wouldn't really know how we classify you, huh?" I laughed, my smile returning. "Here, let me show you."

Settling back down on the grass, I retrieved my pokedex from my pocket.

Surskit's entry read:

"Surskit -- The Pond Skater Pokemon, a Water/ Bug type. Surskit are commonly known to inhabit freshwater wetlands, such as rivers, lakes, and ponds-- though they are also known to occasionally appear in puddles after rainstorms. Surskit feeds on microscopic, aquatic organisms. The tips of surskit's feet secrete an oil that enables it to walk on water. Similarly, the antennae on it's head can also secrete a sweet-tasting syrup. The scent of said syrup is capable of attracting other wild pokemon."

I whistled at the entry. "You've got all sorts of tricks up your sleeve then, huh?"

Surskit gave no response-- her gaze seemed entirely fixed on my pokedex.

Hitting the button on the side like Tom showed me, I scanned Surskit once again.

"Surskit -- Juvenile Female. Ability: Swift Swim."

"Oh, I guess that means you can swim really fast then? But you don't really seem to...really.. swim.."

A spindly blue leg tentatively poked at my leg from beside me, causing me to stiffen slightly. My breath caught for a moment as the curious bug stepped carefully over my lap-- I hadn't even heard her approach. Surskit reached one of her tiny feet out, gingerly tapping it against the pokedex's screen.

Black eyes looked back and forth between me and the screen, sparkling with wonder. "Suuurss?"

"Did you not know you had all of those abilities?"

Surskit's head shook, gesturing in the negative. "Skiii! Suuu-uur!"

I had been under the impression that pokemon were born with the innate knowledge of their species, but I really couldn't be sure. The pokedex did indicate that Surskit was a juvenile, so perhaps she just hadn't grown into all of her powers yet. I wondered if somewhere there were a pair of surskit parents searching for her.

The familiar ache returned as my mind tore between images of my parents back in Hoenn, and my parents back on Earth.

"Hey, Surskit? Do you.. have a family?"

chapters.name: Chapter 10 - First Capture
chapters.content:
Surskit looked up at me with a confused expression.

It was common for wild pokemon to live within familial units or communities, but it really depended on the species. From what I had seen in my life so far in the pokemon world, pokemon's social behaviors largely mirrored the Earth counterparts they had been based on. That is to say, pokemon that resembled dogs would be more likely to live in packs- though there were many exceptions to this. I couldn't necessarily say whether or not surskits commonly lived together, because many bug pokemon were also known to lead solo lives straight from hatching. Pokemon like Beedril or Durant would be an obvious exception, though.

"Are there any other pokemon you live with, Surskit?" I asked. "Anyone that would miss you if you were gone?"

A pained expression crept across her face momentarily, but Surskit blinked before shaking her head in the negative. "Skkkt."

"Did something happen?"

The little bug huffed and jerked her head in response. Whatever had happened, she clearly didn't want to talk about it.

"I.. see. It must be hard living all by yourself then, huh?" I swallowed. "Would you.. like to come with me?"

Surskit gave me a searching glance, as if wondering what I meant.

I slowly reached for my bag, not making any sudden movements as to startle the bug in my lap. After fishing for a moment, my fingers met the cool metal of my pokeball. I held it out for Surskit to inspect.

"See, this is a pokeball. If you let me capture you, that means you'll be my first pokemon- my partner."

"Surs?"

I took a deep breath, tamping down my own excitement. With a slow exhale, I set the pokeball down in the grass beside me.

"But its okay if you want to stay here, Surskit. Its your choice."

The blue bug stared up at me with wide eyes, and pointed a foot forward at my face. "Surrsskkiit?"

"M-Me? Sorry, I suppose I'm getting ahead of myself." I stammered. "My name is Pep, short for Peppa. I'm an aspiring pokemon trainer."

"Skiit skit!" Surskit shook her head.

"Oh, you want to know what a trainer is?"

A nod.

"A trainer is someone who works together with pokemon to battle and get stronger. I'm not really a trainer yet, but my goal is to become one-- a good one. I want to be strong, so that I can enter the pokemon league and go on my journey. I want to meet lots of different pokemon, and battle a whole lot of them too!"

Black eyes beamed up at me with excitement. "Surrss!"

"You want to battle?"

"Skiit!" Surskit chirped, pumping a leg in the air.

"Haha, you're a fiery one huh?"

The little bug beamed.

"Surskit, listen, I- I really like you, and I'd love for you to come with me- but again, the choice is yours. If you need some time to think--"

As I spoke, Surskit turned and placed a foot on the pokeball. In an instant, red light exploded in my vision, encompassing everything for a brief moment- before disappearing just as quickly.

The bug was gone.

My jaw hung slack in disbelief for a few moments, as I stared wide-eyed at the pokeball before me. With shaking hands I carefully picked up the metal sphere.

I had somehow done it- I had captured my first Pok√©mon.

"YESSS!" I cheered, pumping my fists into the air. A ways off, a flock of bird Pok√©mon fled from the noise. Whoops.

I flopped back down on the grass, drinking the moment in- no matter how unceremonious it had been. I had succeeded. I was going to be a real pokemon trainer.

I held out Surskit's pokeball.

"Here goes nothing." A toothy grin stretched across my face as I finally lived my childhood dream of calling out my very own, real-life pokemon.

"Surskit, come on out!"

In a flash of red Surskit appeared beside me, fire burning in her eyes.

"Surss! Surs surskit!"

I interpreted this as, "When do I get to battle?"

"Easy there tiger," I laughed, giving Surskit a gentle pat on the head. "I guess it was the battles that sold you then, huh?"

"Skiit!"

"Not my good looks or winning personality?"

Surskit gave me a sidelong glance.

"Ouch. But hey- I'm so glad to have you Surskit. We're going to have so much fun together!" I giggled, scooping the bug up into a hug.

Surskit trilled, spraying my face with a trickle of water in mock protest, but overall seemed content to allow me the moment.

Movement from the bushes snapped me from my giddy thoughts, however, and I felt Surskit's body stiffen against me.

"Are you done celebrating, then?" A deadpan voice called from the treeline.

"Rita?" I called back. "How long have you been there?"

"Not long," Rita replied, emerging from the brush. "I just happened to hear some idiot out here cheering."

"Ah, yeah. That would be me," I grinned sheepishly, feeling my face flush with mild embarrassment.

"Surssss." Surskit growled, breaking from my grasp to step in front of me.

"Easy there little one," Rita crouched down, speaking in a soft tone. "Its okay."

Surskit seemed to calm down, if only just a bit.

"Surskit, its okay. Rita is a friend." I assured her.

Her posture relaxed, but Surskit's eyes remained trained on Rita.

"Friend is probably a bit much." The pink-haired girl rolled her eyes.

I winced. "Rita, I understand if you're mad about yesterday- I'm sorry."

"No, you just caught me in a bad mood is all. Its fine." Rita shrugged, pushing a lock of hair from her face. "I was going to say you're an acquaintance. Not quite a friend yet, I suppose."

A rictus grin spread across my face.

"Yet?"

"Listen, don't push your luck." Rita scoffed. "I see you caught a pokemon then, yeah?"

"Yep! I caught Surskit just now- well, she kind of caught herself," I beamed. "She was on board the second I mentioned battling."

"Ho? This little thing?"

Surskit gave an indignant hiss.

"Easy. I just wouldn't have taken you for a battler is all." Rita looked down at Surskit with an uncharacteristic smile. "I'm sure you'll grow up to be plenty strong."

Surskit gave a huff, but seemed mollified for the moment.

"How about you, Rita? Did you catch a pokemon yet?" I rose, dusting myself off.

Rita blinked, pausing for a moment. "Oh, um. No, not yet."

"If you want, we could come with you and help you search." I offered. "We should still have a couple of hours before sundown."

Rita stood quietly for a moment, thinking. "You know what? I haven't had any luck so far. Why not."

"YES!" I cheered.

"Shhh!"

"Sorry. Yessss."

Once again, Rita rolled her eyes at me, but this time her face betrayed a slight smirk.

chapters.name: Chapter 11 - Confrontation in the Grotto
chapters.content:
Despite the throbbing soreness that snaked up through my ankles and feet, I found myself practically prancing along the wooded path. Rita had chastised me numerous times along our trek for making too much noise, but I found it increasingly difficult to contain my excitement. I captured a pokemon, after all! My first pokemon! I couldn't wait to show Grandpa and Florian when I returned home for the next break.

Right now, Surskit didn't seem to particularly want to come out of her pokeball to walk with me, though. When I told her that it would be a while before we could battle, she elected to 'return' herself. I didn't know why the little bug seemed so keen on battling so soon, but it was what got her to join me, so I resolved to find her an opponent as soon as possible. I had to test my skills and take my first step as a trainer after all! I practically vibrated in place at the thought.

"So, if we go this way, there should be a cave at the end of this path.." Rita trailed off, eyes focused on her map as we walked. Despite her eyes being fixed to the paper in her hands, she deftly maneuvered around fallen branches and underbrush.

"And that's where we'll find your pokemon?" I called from behind, awkwardly pushing a branch away from my face.

"You'll see. Theres a particular pokemon I have my eye on, and I have a feeling I can find it there." Came Rita's reply.

"Oooh! What pokemon?"

"You'll see."

We walked on in silence for a long stretch, which felt incredibly awkward. I found myself thinking a bit about what Beatrice had said- about Rita being a supposed 'violent delinquent.' She really didn't seem the type to me. Sure, she was a bit cold and unfriendly, but she had been nice enough to Surskit.

Despite my better judgement, I decided to just come out and ask. We had a ways to go before arriving at our destination, and I figured it would be better to hear Rita's side of the story before I formed any sort of opinion on the matter.

"Hey Rita? There was something I wanted to ask you."

"Mmm?" Rita looked over her shoulder, chewing on her fingernail. "What is it?"

"Well I've noticed people tend to stay away from you, and well.. Someone told me some things about you, and I'm not sure what to think about it."

Rita stopped dead in her tracks.

"Oh? What kind of things did they say?" Her face remained stone cold expressionless, but her tone betrayed a hint of annoyance.

"Erm. That you assaulted someone?"

Rita smirked. "What about it?"

I swallowed. "So you actually did?"

"Thats right," came Rita's nonchalant response. "And I would do it again, too."

"O-oh." I stammered. "I didn't expect such a forthright answer."

Support the author by searching for the original publication of this novel.

"I'm a lot of things, Peppa. But I'm not a liar."

With that, Rita turned away, and continued walking. I followed behind her silently, unsure of what to say. Maybe Beatrice had been right, and I've been rooming with a delinquent? I got the feeling that there had to be more to the story, but after that response, I was truthfully a bit afraid to ask and get on her bad side.

We soon arrived at our destination- a small grotto that cut into the side of a particularly steep, forested hill. By now the sun hung dangerously low above the shimmering psychic dome, and though Rita's expression remained stoic, she continued to bite at her nails. Time was of the essence.

Swiftly we crept past a few sleeping Oddish and Gloom along the way, and made our way for the entrance, flashlights ready in hand. My spare hand rested tentatively on Surskit's pokeball, where it hung clipped to my belt loop. I would have liked to get some practice in with calling out moves, but no matter what we encountered, I had to be ready.

Upon entering, my flashlight found a couple of Zubat and a sleeping Paras, but Rita confirmed that neither of which were the pokemon she had been searching for.

"Its probably a little deeper," She whispered.

We pressed on, and I became more and more uncomfortable as the walls began to narrow. Thankfully, at a certain point we reached a larger 'room' connected to a tunnel, where a bit of light trickled in from a hole in the cave's ceiling.

"Shh- there!"

In the center of the cave lay Rita's quarry, a couple of resting Gible that lay beside a veritable mound of stashed berries.

Immediately I took a few steps back.

"Rita, I really don't think thats a good idea." I spoke in the lowest register I could manage.

"What? Why?"

"Those are Gible.. Even I know that there could be a Garchomp nearby."

"Relax. They wouldn't allow such a dangerous pokemon near students."

"If...If you say so. But I really don't think its a good idea."

"Then stay here and watch, scaredy-cat."

Rita crept forward, pokeball in hand.

"And what do you think you're doing?" A voice called through the cave, sending both of our heads swiveling towards its source.

Immediately, the Gible became startled and fled.

"Augh! Why would you do that?" Rita snarled.

From farther in the cave, Beatrice and another girl I didn't recognize stepped forward into the light.

"Shouldn't you be catching a Chansey or something anyways?" The girl said, tousling a lock of blonde, curly hair.

"And what business is it of yours what I catch, Claire?" Rita growled.

"Its my business as the Student Council president to make sure that a dangerous delinquent like yourself doesn't get her hands on a dangerous pokemon." Beatrice spoke in a cool, even tone. "Thats why I've caught a Gible, to make sure that it doesn't fall into the hands of someone.. less responsible."

"Thats what this is about? You've been at this all day. What do you want from me, Beatrice?" the pink-haired girl stomped her foot, startling a few Zubat from their resting spots farther up in the cave. "Is every pokemon too dangerous?"

"Wait, they've been following you?" I asked.

Rita looked away, not meeting my eyes.

"Rita, is that why you haven't caught a pokemon yet? You guys are intentionally sabotaging her exam, aren't you?"

"And what if I am? Do you really think our school has a place for people like her?" Beatrice responded calmly.

Rage swelled within my chest, and a familiar throbbing returned to my head. I had been bullied once, in my past life. Though the details were foggy, I could recall the feelings. Even if Rita did the things they said she did, that didn't make what they were doing okay.

"You're a bully."

"A bully?" Beatrice laughed. "And what do you propose she is, attacking a defenseless student?"

"Two wrongs dont make a right!" I spat. "It isn't right for you to decide someone else's future."

"Well then, I can see we aren't going to agree on this. Why don't we settle this the old fashioned way?"

"Wh-what?" I stammered, taken aback momentarily.

Beatrice merely gestured towards my belt loop. "You've caught a pokemon, yes?"

I gave a slow nod.

Beatrice's eyes met mine, burning like dark cinders. "If you're to be a real trainer then, what do you say we settle this with a battle?"

chapters.name: Chapter 12 - First Battle
chapters.content:
Steeling myself, I gripped Surskit's pokeball tight with a shaking hand. Squaring off opposite of me, Beatrice stood without any cracks in her perfect icy veneer. Her diminutive form cut a long shadow against the cave's wall; her jet black hair seemed to meld with the shadows in a way that set me on edge.

It goes without saying that I would have preferred time to practice or even learn what moves Surskit has in her arsenal before battling, but there was nothing for it- I just had to make do.

"Rita, will you stand as referee? Surely you can get that right?" Claire taunted.

"Enough," Beatrice snapped, causing Claire to visibly straighten.

"Whatever," Rita replied. "Peppa, you don't have to do this. You just caught Surskit, and neither of you are experienced in battles yet. She could get hurt."

"Dont worry," Beatrice cut in. "We'll make sure to pull our punches."

I couldn't help but bristle.

"Surskit will be fine." I snarled. "Its Beatrice you should worry about."

"Ohoh? I like that attitude." Beatrice smirked.

"Alright, the rules are simple. A clean one-on-one battle. The battle ends when either pokemon are unable to continue." Rita explained as we took our positions. "Please call your pokemon."

"Drifloon." As Beatrice spoke, a spherical form of ghostly energy rose from her shadow, materializing into a drifloon in front of her. If not for the situation, I probably would have fangirled over how cute the pokemon was. Drifloon's body was basically a purple balloon with two black eyes and an "X" for a mouth. Two string like arms hung from its body, and a small cloud rested atop its head. Admittedly, Drifloon was probably among the cutest ghost pokemon there were.

"I thought you said you had a Gible?" Rita asked.

"I never said I had only one pokemon," Came Beatrice's response. "Drifloon are native to this area, we see them at the Valley windworks quite often."

"Surskit, come on out!" I called, holding out Surskit's pokeball. In a flash of red, Surskit materialized.

"Are you ready for that battle, Surskit?" I asked.

Fire burned in the little bugs eyes as she pumped a leg in the air. "Surrrs!"

"Ready?" Rita called. "Begin!"

"Drifloon, astonish!" Beatrice barked out before I could react, and her Drifloon bounded forward. In an instant Surskit was slapped with one of Drifloon's arms, which caused her to momentarily flinch.

"Gust!" She barked again. Drifloon bobbled backward, and unleashed a torrent of wind that threatened super-effective damage against Surskit.

"Surskit, dodge!" I yelled, but was a second too late. Surskit leapt through the air, and though she manage to avoid the brunt of the attack, she had been clipped. Surskit hit the ground on her side with a painful thud.

"Surskit! Are you okay?" I rushed forward to her side.

"Surs! Skkkttt!" Surskit hissed, stopping me. With only a slight wobble she rose, her eyes trained on her opponent.

"Alright, if you're sure." I nodded. With that, our fight resumed.

"Surskit, use bubble!" At my command, the little bug released a torrent of the stinging bubbles I had been hit with only hours prior. Unfortunately, the stream of bubble scattered uselessly, allowing for Drifloon to easily dodge without Beatrice issuing a command.

"Fla-fla-flooon." The cheeky balloon pokemon seemed to chuckle, clearly mocking Surskit.

"Skkkt-ttt-tt!" Surskit hissed, and without warning she rushed forward, recklessly charging at her opponent.

"Surskit no!" I cried, but it was too late.

Beatrice wasted no time in seizing the opportunity. "Drifloon, use gust!"

My poor bug had fallen for Drifloons taunting** and got right up in its face. Another gale formed in front of Drifloon and surged forward, hitting Surskit head-on at point blank range.

Surskit flew backwards, smacking into the wall of the cave, before hitting the ground with a pitiful whimper.

"Surskit is unable to battle," Rita called, her expression unreadable. "Beatrice is the winner."

"Surskit.. I'm sorry." I scooped up my battered bug. "You did a good job. We just need more practice."

"Skk..ttt." Surskit let out a quiet chitter, weakly pumping her foot in the air. The poor thing still had fight in her yet.

"Haha, yeah. You're a fighter." I gave Surskit a half-hearted smile, before returning her to her pokeball.

"What was that about 'Its Beatrice you should worry about', Peppa?" Claire mocked. "Surely you didn't expect to win with that bug?"

"Shut up," I snarled. "You can mock me, but don't you dare mock Surskit."

"Maybe you'll learn something from this, Peppa Carmine." Beatrice strode forward. "But I doubt it. Drifloon, return." Drifloon once again vanished, presumably taking its place in Beatrice's shadow once more.

"Now. Since you've lost, Rita can return to the meeting point. Empty handed." Beatrice stated in a matter-of fact tone.

"What? We never agreed on that." I protested.

"But didn't we? I said we'd settle it with a battle." Beatrice smirked. "Its settled."

"Peppa, its fine." Rita interjected before I could speak. "Lets just go."

Swept up in the heat of the moment, I agreed to a battle without even agreeing on the stakes- and now Rita was paying the price for that. I lamented my own stupidity- if only I had trained a bit beforehand, or not let Beatrice get a rise out of me in the first place. Worse yet, Surskit got hurt because of my own ineptitude, just as Rita had warned me. If only I had listened. Who did I think I was to fight someone else's battle?

"Rita.. I'm sor-"

Before I could get the words out, the cavern began to shake.

"GRRROOOAAAARRRrr" A fearsome voice thundered, sending loose stones skittering down the side of the cave wall.

My head snapped to Rita, who's usually stoic face was now plastered pale with fear.

"You don't think.." She uttered, as the rumbling drew closer.

"GRAAAAAOOORHhh"

A flock of panicked Zubat came screeching from farther in the cave, rushing past us. I covered my face as wings smacked my body; the pokemon didn't even attempt to avoid us in their haste.

"Beatrice!" the haughty blonde now clung to her friend's side. "We need to go!"

Beatrice's expression remained calm, despite her clearly trembling hands. She cleared her throat.

"Don't panic; make your way towards the exit, hurry!" she ordered, and we obeyed.

Beatrice and Claire ran ahead of us through the snaking tunnels of the cave. As we ran we were flanked by a deluge of panicked pokemon; a few Paras skittered along the walls while I struggled not to trip over a group of fleeing Sandshrew.

"GROooARR!!" The rumbling drew closer yet.

"Hurry you two!" Beatrice called from ahead. "We're almost there!"

As we bounded around a corner, I smacked into a large boulder that had been presumably dislodged from the ceiling that now blocked our path. I scrambled to climb over it, but failed to get a grip on the hard stone.

"We're stuck! Help!" I shouted ahead.

"Hold on! Buizel, go!" Claire called out.

A torrent of water sprayed over me from behind the boulder, shimmering uselessly across its surface.

"Claire, leave them!" Beatrice barked.

"What?!" Rita and I shouted simultaneously.

For a few moments there was silence, save for the rumbling that drew ever closer.

"I'm sorry." Came Claire's response. "We'll get help!"

"Wait no--" I started, but it was no use. The sound of the girl's footsteps drew farther and farther away.

‚ÄúI think they left us behind.‚Äù I blurted.

Rita swung her face at me, eyes wide and eyebrows high.

My mind swam. Why had Rita lied to me?

As Gabite reared its clawed arm back to strike at the Grimer once more, Grimer once again unleashed another spray of foul-smelling gas point-blank in Gabite's face. For a moment the Gabite faltered, taking a step back. The pokemon's body momentarily became surrounded in a thin purple miasma- Gabite had been succesfully poisoned. Now the battle would be a matter of holding the Gabite off until it succumbed to its poisoning- though with the damage Grimer had already sustained, that would not be an easy feat.

Once again the two pokemon resumed the cycle of striking and dodging- blows glanced off of Grimer's body, slowly chipping away at it. At this rate, Grimer would be the one to fall first. As if tiring from this cycle, the Gabite once again bellowed a furious roar- fierce white energy gathered around its claws, as it sought to deliver a final blow. From what I could remember, I assumed this move to be Slash.

"Grimer minimize, evade!" Rita cried, but it was too late. The move found its target, sending Grimer flying back into the tunnel wall.

Rita rushed to return her pokemon, but Grimer slowly shambled upright oncemore.

"Guuhh...rime." The pokemon once again moved forward, chunks of slimy mass falling off its body in small clumps.

"No, Grimer! You've done enough!" Rita protested.

The Gabite snarled, clearly intending to finish the job.

Without thinking, I reached into my bag and lobbed the first thing I could find at the charging pokemon, which happened to be a berry. It spattered across the top of Gabite's head harmlessly, but I had succeeded in distracting it momentarily. The Gabite turned to me, its eyes blazing with barely contained fury.

All at once the cave shook, sending a spray of pebbles and dust flying onto the narrow battlefield. I coughed, rubbing the dust from my eyes.

"And what do we have here?" A familiar voice called from the source of the crash. The boulder had been blown to bits, and in its place now stood large pokemon-- Rhydon, if memory served. Ms. Kimber stepped from behind the menacing Rhydon, meeting our gazes with a nonchalant smile.

"I see, a Gabite, huh?" she mused. "I had heard that there would be Gibble present for students to capture, but one of them must have evolved."

"Rhydon, go." She waved her hand, and the gray tank of a pokemon rushed forward, striking the Gabite over the head with one of its thick arms. Gabite abrubtly fell face-forward into the dirt, and did not move again.

Ms. Kimber threw a pokeball at the downed Gabite, and in a flash of light, the pokemon disappeared. The pokeball hit the ground with a metallic thump. I stood awestruck as the pokeball rocked back and forth a couple of times, before confirming the capture with a satisying 'click'.

"Aughhhh," I deflated instantly, allowing myself to slide down the tunnel wall momentarily. At this point, I had a headache from how long my heart had been pounding in my ears.

"You two are unharmed, right?" Ms. Kimber asked as she approached. "Asides from this one." She gestured at the shambling blob Rita now cradled in her arms.

"Yes," Rita responded without looking up.

"Your Grimer must have fought hard to last that long against a Gabite. I'm glad I got here in time." Ms. Kimber scratched her head. "But I don't remember Grimer being on the list of possible encounters?"

Rita froze, still not meeting our teacher's eyes, before returning Grimer to its pokeball.

"That pokeball isn't one of the ones we issued either. Care to explain?"

"I will explain everything," Rita started. "Just.. please don't take him away."

chapters.name: Chapter 14 - Past Mistakes
chapters.content:
"A year ago, a pokemon was brought to the Pokemon Center with extensive injuries. I had heard from one of my sisters that he had come from our school's campus."

Pain clouded Rita's eyes as she spoke.

"He was... not much more than a scrap of slime at that time. I still don't know how he survived, but if I had to guess it was because he was determined to pull through. I felt horrible‚Äîit was my first time seeing a pokemon in that state, you see. He was so weak."

Ms. Kimber gave Rita a sympathetic nod. "Its okay. Take your time."

"Well, when I spoke to the students who had brought him in, they told me that someone had done this to him‚Äî Someone from our school. I was furious, I needed to know why. When I asked who it was, they had described an upperclassman who I was familiar with; a boy from the Battlers Club."

"I seem to recall something like this, though I wasn't present at the time." Ms. Kimber hummed.

"The next day at school I approached the boy in the stairwell before classes. I asked him why he did it. And do you know what he said?" Rita's face twisted into a mask of uncharacteristic rage. "He said he was exterminating a pest."

I grimaced. It was certainly true that many held pokemon like Grimer in that regard, but to seek to exterminate one.. the thought made my stomach churn.

"I was so angry, I didn't even think; I just saw red. When I shoved him backwards, I hadn't even meant to push him down the stairs." Rita's fists clenched. "But I don't feel bad about what I did. After seeing Grimer in that state... No, anyone who could hurt an innocent Pok√©mon in that way deserves what they have coming to them."

"Ah, I see. While I cant condone violence, I cant say I blame you. Seeing that at your age must have been shocking, even for a member of the Joy family." Ms. Kimber responded. "If I remember correctly, your family pulled strings to reduce your expulsion to a suspension."

"Yes, that's correct." Rita's shoulders slumped. "After I pushed him, everyone was looking at me like I was a monster. They still look at me that way now. Sometimes I wonder if expulsion may have been better."

"Unfortunately, you did break the rules of this exam, so there still may be time for that yet." Ms. Kimber frowned. "You haven't explained why you brought Grimer with you today."

"I'm sorry‚Äî yes, I am prepared for the consequences. You see, due to Grimer's status as an invasive species in most areas, my family was struggling to find somewhere to relocate him after he recovered enough to be moved from the intensive care unit. We asked a few poison specialist trainers if they would be interested in taking Grimer, but most of them hadn't been interested in rehabilitating a pokemon with such extensive injuries. As a result, my family decided to keep him in our home."

"The problem was that Grimer, well... Grimers naturally have a rather foul stench. Keeping him in our home proved to be a bit of a challenge, but I had grown attached to him at this point. The way he pushed himself to recover inspired me; I couldn't let my family resume talks of getting rid of him. I begged my parents to let me keep him, even though I legally couldn't have a pokemon yet. And well, they eventually caved. Though Grimer is technically registered to my mother at this time, I have been solely responsible for his care."

"I had never intended to use Grimer in today's exam, but since the incident, I can't stand being away from him. I cant trust that something wont happen to him again."

"So you intended to capture a pokemon today without using Grimer to legitimize your status as a trainer?" Ms Kimber cut in.

"Yes. Once I became a legally registered trainer, I intended to have Grimer traded to me." Rita nodded. "I would do anything to be his trainer."

"I see. Tell you what," Ms. Kimber hummed, taking a few steps towards the entrance. "Give me Grimer's pokeball."

Rita flinched backward, holding Grimer's pokeball behind her back.

"Hear me out first, kid." Ms. Kimber started. "I will return Grimer after the exam ends‚Äî You have one hour to catch a pokemon, legitimately. If you succeed, I won't say anything. You'll be a real trainer, and Grimer will be none of my business. If you fail, well‚Äî I'll just return Grimer to your family."

Rita paused, taking a moment to think over Ms. Kimber's offer.

"Why would you help me?" She asked.

"Because, I have a soft spot for trainers like you. The kind that would do anything to protect their pokemon." Ms Kimber gave a warm smile.

"Rita, I think you should do it." I interjected. "It'll be hard but I think we can do it. Theres no rule that we cant work together, right?"

"Thats correct, but seeing as you've already caught a pokemon, you'll need to come back to the meeting point with me so we can get you registered as a trainer."

I shot Rita an apologetic look.

"Its okay, Peppa. I can do this." Rita spoke, and I wasn't sure if she was assuring me or herself. "You need to get Surskit looked at, anyways."

"Ah, a Surskit? Not a popular first catch." Ms. Kimber turned to me.

I shrugged. "Surskit is awesome."

"Oh, I'm sure." Ms. Kimber winked. "Lets go get your friend looked at then."

"Good luck, Rita." I reached a hand towards the pink-haired girl. "I wish that I could stay."

Rita scoffed lightly, but shook my hand back. "Don't worry. I'll see you later, Pep."

With that, I followed Ms. Kimber through the dense forest, daring not to look behind me. As nervous as I was on Rita's behalf, I had full confidence that she could manage. She had battled so competently against the Gabite, and without Beatrice and Claire in the picture to sabotage her chances, there was no reason to not be optimistic.

By the time we had returned to the meeting point, the sun had sunk low above the shimmering dome. The handful of Kadabras I had seen upon arrival still hummed dutifully with psychic energy.

Most of the other students had made it back by now, save for a handful. I saw Beatrice talking to a group of girls who were presumably showing off their new captures, but I didn't bother with approaching her. By now my feet screamed with every step, and truth be told, I was too tired for any more confrontation at this given moment.

Ms. Kimber ushered me to a makeshift triage station, before leaving me in the care of a Nurse Joy took Surskit's pokeball. The nurse also looked over me briefly before returning to tending to the other pokemon.

"Pep! Over here!" Tom called to me from across the crowd.

Before I could move, the portly boy jogged over to me, holding a rather aloof-looking Lotad in his arms.

"I wanted to show you my pokemon!" Tom beamed.

"Oh, nice! A lotad." I yawned. "I had seen some floating down the river earlier, but they didn't pay me any mind."

"Yeah, they are chill guys." Tom started. "Are you okay? You look really tired."

"Yeah, I'm okay. I ran into.. Well, some trouble, but I managed. Nurse Joy has my pokemon right now. I'm waiting for her to be done so I can get registered."

"Why don't we get you some water, and you can tell me about it while we wait?"

"Ugh, bless you Tom." I allowed my shoulder to sag with exhaustion. "Water sounds great right about now."

chapters.name: Chapter 15 - An Official Trainer
chapters.content:
I internally praised Arceus as the cool water soothed my sore, partially-burned throat. Tom and I took a seat in the grass while we waited for Nurse Joy to be done with Surskit. While we waited, I filled Tom in on the details of everything that had transpired, though I elected to leave out as many of the details about Rita as I could. It wasn't my place to tell her story, after all. Tom's hazel eyes stayed locked on mine the entire time I spoke; giving me his full attention. I really did get the impression that Tom was a considerate sort, after all.

"Wow, so you really battled the Student Council President?" The boy asked, his sandy-blonde hair waving in the late-afternoon breeze.

"Mhm. And lost miserably." I added.

"Still, how did it feel to have your first battle?"

"Honestly? I was so nervous. I knew I would make mistakes, but seeing Surskit rush in and get hurt.. It was hard."

Tom said nothing other than offering a quiet "Mm," in response.

"Peppa Carmine?" Nurse Joy called across the crowd of students. "Is Peppa Carmine present?"

I shot up, waving my hand high in the air. "I'm here!"

"Your pokemon is all set!"

I eagerly pushed my way through the crowd towards the triage station. There, Nurse Joy cheerfully handed me Surskit's pokeball. I was surprised by how quickly she had worked, on account of how many students were present. As I readily prepared to release Surskit, Nurse Joy stopped me.

"If you'll wait just a couple of minutes, I'm also all set to get you registered now."

"Oh‚Äîsorry. Okay."

"If I could just have you step up to this desk.."

The process of getting registered was relatively simple. Nurse Joy asked me a few questions and entered my information into what resembled a tablet from Earth. Once done, she had me take a quick picture, and a nifty little contraption on the desk spat out my Trainer ID card. The card itself wasn't much different than a regular ID card, but featured an iridescent watermark of a pokeball, marking my status as a registered trainer. I fiddled with the thing for a second, marveling at how the watermark caught the light, before slipping it into my wallet.

I thanked Nurse Joy for her help, and made my way back to Tom, who looked to be chatting with a few other students.

"Oh, Pep! We were just showing off our new pokemon," Tom called. "Come show us yours!"

The group's eyes lingered on me as I approached, filling me with a sense of apprehension. Around the circle, a boy stood with a Chimchar on his shoulders, another girl had a Shinx‚Äîanother had a Starly, and so on. I looked around the crowd, and found no bug-type pokemon to speak of. I internally prepared myself for the comments that would no doubt be levied my way.

Here goes nothing. I unclipped Surskit's pokeball from my belt loop.

"Surskit, go!"

In a flash, my little bug appeared, fiery as ever. "Skkktt-tt-tt!" She hissed at the surrounding pokemon, as if issuing a challenge. The reactions from the surrounding pokemon were a mix of confusion and open hostility.

"Woah there little one! Lets calm down," I scooped the rambunctious bug into my arms. She allowed it with minimal protest, but gave me a quiet huff before climbing up onto my shoulder.

"Oh.. uh, a bug.." The girl with the shinx muttered.

"Whats wrong with bugs?" I asked.

"Well.. they're um.."

"I think Surskit is cute." Tom interjected.

Surskit preened under Tom's praise.

"Seriously though, whats wrong with bugs?" Despite my better judgement, I chose not to let the comment slide.

"Well, they are the weakest type," The boy with the Chimchar added.

"Says who?" I bristled.

"Well... Everybody?"

Tom's eyes darted between me and the boy nervously.

"Look.. I'm not trying to hurt your feelings, but some pokemon are just better than others." The boy gave me a smug smirk and shrugged. "Like Chimchar, here."

"Liam!" Tom snapped. "Theres no need for that."

"I think all pokemon are good if you train them right." I frowned.

"Sure, but a surskit isn't going to hold up much competitively." Liam stated in a matter-of-fact tone.

"Surss! Skktt-ttt!" Surskit hissed indignantly from my shoulder.

"Don't listen to him, Surskit. I think you're plenty strong." I gave my bug a pat on the head.

An awkward tension filled the air as the group exchanged glances. As much as I wanted to pursue the issue and convince everyone that Surskit is the best, I would have to pick my battles. It wouldn't do to issue another challenge without training first. I would just have to be content to show them once Surskit and I got some meaningful training in. For now, I resolved to eventually make this 'Liam' guy eat his words.

"Pep!" Rita's voice called, snapping me from my thoughts.

Bless Rita for giving me an out to this conversation.

"Rita, you're back!" I jogged to meet her, ignoring the stares of my peers. "How did it go?"

"Good, thankfully. I managed to snag an Oddish just in the nick of time. The little guy couldn't resist my berries." Rita's deadpan expression revealed a slight smile. I got the impression that this was her version of 'beaming with pride'.

"Let me see!"

"I will‚Äî but later," She leaned in close to whisper. "I still need to go get Grimer."

After retrieving Grimer's pokeball, we made our way to the triage desk to get all of Rita's pokemon checked out. While there Rita was also registered as a trainer. Presumably, Rita had been the last to return because as soon as we finished, Ms. Kimber gathered the class up to prepare to leave.

"I am proud to announce that none of you have failed today," Ms. Kimber addressed the class. "Which means you are all now registered trainers. I expect you all to abide by the rules of the Pokemon League, and to treat your pokemon, as well as your fellow trainers, with the dignity and respect that they deserve."

"As for your pokemon's care- We will be giving all of you a weeks supply of pokemon food, but after that, it will be your responsibility. We will have a brief refresher course tomorrow on pokemon care and nutrition. As far as your grades for this exam go, they will be posted within a weeks time. All of you will be individually graded based on the surveillance footage we have."

I grimaced. I had expected that they had had some method of surveilling us, but this only served to remind me that somebody would see my mishap with the Cherri berry.

"You will be permitted to walk back to campus with your pokemon, but keep in mind that once we arrive, your pokemon will only be allowed out of its pokeball in designated areas. Any questions?"

The throng of students was unusually silent. Everyone must have been as tired as I was.

"Great, lets head back!"

chapters.name: Chapter 16 - Training Buddies
chapters.content:
Golden light shone brilliantly off of the cityscape as Jubilife came into view. Though my feet ached, I enjoyed the walk back from Route 204 far more than I had on the way there. At some point Surskit had become tired, and though I offered her pokeball, she seemed to prefer to cuddle up inside of my bag. Rita and I had chatted a bit along the way, and she introduced me to her Oddish, who she now carried in her arms. I found the little grass-type adorable; three leaves adorned its 'head', or body for that matter‚Äîthough one of the leaves seemed to be a bit crumpled in a way that stood out to me as unique.

Upon arriving in front of the dorm building, we were again approached by Beatrice and Claire. Beatrice's Drifloon bobbled behind her in the light, while Claire's Buizel walked on foot by her side.

"I see you didn't fail after all," Beatrice remarked.

"What do you want, Beatrice?" Rita ground out. The Oddish in her arms looked up at Rita with a confused expression.

"Just to congratulate you. I was glad to hear that you both made it back safely." Beatrice gave a slight, haughty smirk.

"Sure," I spat. "You left us to die."

Claire grimaced. Despite her earlier behavior, she offered no snide remarks to speak of this time.

"Left you to die?" Beatrice scoffed. "No, I went and got help like any respectable member of the student council would have."

"What I would like to know, however, is how you managed to hold out. I'm told you somehow managed to fend off an enraged Gabite?"

"Ms. Kimber defeated the Gabite," Rita corrected her. I nodded in agreement.

Beatrice pursed her lips, keenly aware that she wouldn't get a straight answer from either of us.

"Well. Let's see if your luck continues." With that, Beatrice stalked off, her pokemon bobbing behind her sleepily.

"..Sorry." Claire mumbled, before jogging after her friend.

Rita and I exchanged a glance.

"Well at least Claire seemed to feel bad." I offered.

Rita looked unconvinced.

After Rita and I had both had turns in the shower, I filled the bathtub with cool water for Surskit. She seemed to enjoy skittering across the water, no matter how small the surface area of it was. I sat with my head propped up on the side of the tub, watching my bug happily splash and skitter about. Despite my weariness from the day's events, watching my very own pokemon filled me with a sense of pride and elation. I truly couldn't wait to show her off to my family.

A feeling of dread settled in my stomach upon recalling the other student's reactions to Surskit. What if my family saw her the same way?

A knock at the door pulled me from my thoughts.

"Come in!" I shouted over my shoulder.

"Sorry, am I interupting? I wanted to get ready for bed," Rita said from a crack in the door.

"No, not at all. I'm just watching Surskit enjoy herself."

"Surss!" Surskit happily trilled.

"She really seems to like the bathtub, huh?" Rita mused.

"Yeah. She's been at it for a while. I thought she'd get tired of it by now, but it makes sense that a water type would want to be near water."

We fell into a companiable silence for a moment, as Rita continued to comb her hair.

"Long day, huh?" I yawned.

"Yeah.. A lot happened." Rita sighed.

"How are you holding up?" I turned to Rita.

"Honestly? I'm still a bit shaken."

"From the whole Gabite thing?"

"We could have died, Pep." Rita placed the comb on the edge of the sink. "We could have died and they left us. I knew that Beatrice had it out for me, but I didn't think she'd stoop that low."

"Its probably better that she didn't find out about Grimer, though." I replied. "She probably would have found some way to use it against you."

"True," Rita grumbled. "But I'm angry. I just wish there were some way to get back at her, you know?"

"You could always challenge her to a battle," I started. "Though that didn't work out so well for me."

Surskit bristled for a moment.

"Sorry Surskit‚Äî It wasn't your fault. We just need some more practice." I smiled at my bug.

"Do you think I could win?" Rita asked, folding her arms.

"With the way you battled that Gabite? Totally, Rita. You and Grimer both rocked."

Rita gave a slight smile.

"Why don't we train tomorrow, after classes?"

I started up at her, wide-eyed. "You want to train together?"

"Ugh, dont make it weird." Rita scoffed. "But yeah. I think we'll improve more if we both have someone to practice with."

I felt the corners of my lips curl into a devious grin. "Training buddies." I whispered.

"Okay‚Äî I'm going to bed. Goodnight, Pep." Rita rolled her eyes, before making her way towards the door.

"Oh‚Äî And Pep?" Rita spoke with her back turned to me. "Thankyou. For having my back earlier."

The girl closed the door behind her without giving me a chance to respond.

Classes seemed to drag on throughout the day as I anticipated my upcoming training session with Surskit. Other than chatting with Tom a bit and Ms. Kimber's refresher course on Pokemon care, nothing of much note happened.

After classes had finally ended, I met with Rita, and we made our way to the school's designated training areas. The area was about the size of two football fields, featuring multiple dirt 'arena' areas. Unfortunately for us, all but one of the arenas had been completely full with trainers who, much like us, were clearly eager to train their newly caught pokemon. Truthfully, I had hoped for something a bit more private‚Äî eyes followed Rita and I as we made our way to the sole empty arena.

We released our pokemon and engaged in some light stretching, before setting to the task at hand.

"Alright Surskit, lets start by seeing your moves." I called to my little bug.

"Surss!" She happily trilled, before launching a Water Gun directly into my face.

I took a step backwards from the force but was otherwise unhurt. "Okay very funny‚Äîso you know Water Gun." I grumbled, feeling my face flush. "Can we try that again, without hitting me in the face?

"Skktt-tt-tt-tt!" Surskit seemed to laugh.

Rita looked away as I turned to her, as if holding back a similar chuckle.

This time, Surskit demonstrated her Water Gun again for me, without any of her previous antics. Following that, she released a barrage of directionless bubbles that seemed to float in all directions.

"That looks like Bubble," Rita started. "But I dont think its strong enough to do any damage."

"Yeah, we tried that one during the fight with Beatrice, remember? It ended up not hitting Drifloon at all."

Surskit momentarily looked dejected.

"Dont worry, we'll work on it." I started. "Do you have any other moves?"

"Surs!" Surskit's body flashed with a clear white, Normal-type energy, before zipping forward a few feet.

"Oh! Thats quick attack!" I clapped. "That's a useful one!" Quick attack had been a priority move in the games, meaning it always hit first. I doubted it would work the same way here, but either way, having a reliable method to close gaps or escape would be invaluable.

For Surskit's final move, she secreted a sweet-smelling liquid from the tip of her antennae that seemed to draw the attention of all the surrounding pokemon. We determined this move to be Sweet Scent. I didn't think it would require any training, as it seemed just be something Surskit's species could innately do, but I figured it may be useful in the future for attracting wild pokemon.

Moving on, Rita and I watched as Rita's Oddish went through a similar procession of showing off her moves. Oddish seemed to know Absorb, Growth, and Acid.

Oddish and Surskit played happily in the sun while Grimer demonstrated his moves, most of which I had seen yesterday. Grimer knew Poison Gas, Pound, Harden, and Minimize. Based on what I presumed his level to be, he should have known Disable or Sludge, but it seemed as if he hadn't learned either yet. My guess was that the way pokemon learned moves in this world was probably completely different.

I suggested the moves to Rita, but she eyed me dubiously.

"How would you know what Grimer learns?" She asked, genuinely sounding confused.

"Oh uh‚Äî I saw a tournament on TV with a Grimer that used those moves." I lied.

"Oh. Makes sense," Rita responded. "I'll keep those in mind."

My heart raced slightly as Rita returned to her pokemon.

Now that I had seen Surskit demonstrate her moves, it was clear to me what needed focus. I had a strategy in mind, and it needed some serious work.

chapters.name: Chapter 17 - More Training
chapters.content:
My plan required a few different components to work, but the first priority was to work on Surskit's offensive moves.

"Alright Surskit, I'm going to need your attention, okay?"

"Surss!"

"So you know how your bubble attack sort of went, well.. everywhere?"

Surskit looked at the ground, clearly thinking.

"What we want to do is get your bubbles to move in more of a straight line‚Äî like your water gun. I want you to try to use it again, but this time try to condense it more."

"Skktt-tt." My pokemon nodded.

Again, Surskit fired off a bout of bubbles, but they fizzled off in multiple directions.

"Hmm. What if we try to work on water gun first? We could try to get you used to the feeling of increasing the pressure and narrowing it's scope. Here, aim for that tree over there with your water gun again."

Surskit jumped up, firing off her water gun at the nearby tree. The attack hit the tree in a sort of broad splash.

"I think I see what the issue is," Rita chimed in. "Surskit needs to get used to building up the water's pressure."

"Thats probably why her bubbles go everywhere too." I agreed. "Alright Surskit! Try holding in the water before you launch it. I want you to try to focus on building pressure, and make your mouth smaller when you shoot it."

"Surss-ki-tit-it!"

Surskit fired off another water gun, and this time the splash was marginally smaller.

"Good! Keep practicing that for a while, try to get the splash as small as you can!"

The tiny bug seemed to beam. I felt lucky to have a partner pokemon that was such a hard worker.

While Surskit worked on water gun, Oddish worked with Grimer to learn how to build up poison type energy. I suspected that Rita was looking to have Oddish learn Poison Powder.

While our pokemon trained, I decided to put a different plan in motion.

"Rita, can you come here for a sec? I beckoned to my companion.

"Yeah, whats up?"

"I think we should run laps while our pokemon train." I told her.

"No thanks." Rita smiled.

"But how can we call ourselves trainers if we don't train ourselves?" I posited. "It doesn't feel right to just do nothing while our pokemon work so hard. "

"I'm not doing nothing," Rita started. "I'm taking mental notes. Plus, we already had P.E. today. I'm not doing any more running than I have to."

With that Rita walked off, and continued to watch her pokemon train. Guess its just me then, I shrugged.

As much as I talked a big game about running laps, I was admittedly winded halfway through my second‚Äî but I pressed on, my eyes following Surskit as I jogged around the dirt arena. Once I had finished, I was surprised to see that Surskit had improved by impressive amount‚Äîespecially considering that today was her first day training. There was definitely a ton more work to be done, but her repeated use of water gun had begun to make a small indent in the tree's bark, signaling that the blast radius of her attack was indeed getting smaller and more forceful.

This book's true home is on another platform. Check it out there for the real experience.

By the time the sun had begun to set, we decided to call it for the day.

A week came and went, and Rita and I followed much the same routine. Our pokemon trained, I jogged, and she didn't.

As I walked from my afternoon class, I noticed a group of students crowding in the hallway. Curious, I went to see what all the hubbub had been about. As I pushed my way through, I was greeted by a long list of names and numbers pinned to a board. Our test results!

I was pleased to find that Rita and I had faired reasonably well despite all that had transpired, since our names were listed somewhere around the middle-of-the-pack. Tom's name was listed just below my own. My mood immediately soured upon seeing Beatrice's name in the top spot, though I wasn't surprised.

As I made my way to our usual training spot, I noticed a battle taking place in the arena adjacent to it.

Tom and his Lotad squared off against the arrogant Chimchar trainer from the exams. I think his name was Liam?

"Lotad‚Äî water gun!" Tom shouted, and the little lily pad-creature obeyed. The water gun surged forward, but Lotad's aim was off, and the move was easily dodged by his opponent.

"Chimchar, get in close!" Liam commanded. "Use scratch‚ÄîRepeatedly!"

The fiery chimp jumped up and landed in right Lotad's face, overwhelming him with scratches. Tom's Lotad cried out in pain as the attacks landed.

"Dodge, Lotad!" Tom bellowed, but it was no use. Everywhere Lotad tried to dodge, Chimchar was there, refusing to let up in his assault.

"Good, keep overwhelming him!" Liam cheered.

Tom stood, watching Chimchar's attacks land one after the other, but they were clearly becoming sluggish. Lotad was in a bad way, but had successfully held on long enough to tire Chimchar out.

"Lotad, water gun!" Tom called again, seizing his opportunity. This time, Lotad's water gun fired off from point-blank range, hitting the monkey square in the chest.

Chimchar reeled back, panting. The repeated uses of scratch had taken their toll, along with the super-effective damage from Lotad's attack.

"Chimchar, are you KIDDING me? Finish him off!" Liam shrieked. "Use ember!"

I blinked in astonishment. Did he always talk to his pokemon like this?

Though Chimchar's ember did little to hurt Lotad on account of his water typing, the small blast was just enough to send Lotad reeling back. Closing the gap, Chimchar got off a couple more scratches that sealed the deal‚Äî Lotad was down.

Tom's expression was unreadable as he returned his pokemon. "Good match," he started, as he walked towards his opponent with an outstretched hand.

Liam looked at Tom's hand, and back up to him. "My winnings?" Liam cocked his head.

Tom reached for his wallet, handing a few Pokedollars to his opponent. "Here."

Without a word, Liam sauntered off‚Äî his exhausted Chimchar scrambling to follow behind him.

"That guy seems like a real winner," I remarked, as I approached Tom.

Tom's shoulder's slumped as he looked at the pokeball in his hand. "He wasn't always like that."

"Is he your friend?" I asked.

"Sort of‚Äî Well, he used to be. We grew up in the same area, so we went to elementary school together. Since he's gotten his Chimchar though, he's been acting different. He's won a bunch of battles, and I think it's going to his head."

"The way he treats his pokemon.. Is a bit concerning." Tom continued.

"Does he always act that way?"

"Lately? Pretty much. We actually got into an argument about it because I said that he was pushing Chimchar too hard. He challenged me to a battle, and well... You saw how that went."

"So you've tried to talk to him already," I muttered.

"Well, yeah. He just doesn't listen to me, is all. That fight was his way of deciding who was right about it, if that makes any sense. In his eyes, I'm weak, so my opinion doesn't matter."

"You're not though," I started. "That was a pretty close battle."

"He probably doesn't see it that way." Tom shrugged.

"Hrrm.." I hummed, thinking for a moment. "Why don't you come train with me and Rita?"

"I'm sorry?" Tom asked.

"Yeah! You could come train with us until you feel confident enough to challenge Liam again."

"I‚ÄîUhm. Would Rita even be okay with that?" The boy stammered.

"Oh, I'm sure she would be. There's nothing Rita hates more than people who mistreat pokemon. Besides, Surskit could use a sparring partner."

"If you're sure its okay," Tom decided. "Lotad and I could use the help."

"And maybe once you win, Liam will listen to some sense!" I beamed.

Tom sighed. "One can hope."

Tom stiffened as Rita approached our usual training spot.

"What's up?" She asked, blowing a bubble with her chewing gum.

"Tom here wanted to know if it was okay if he joined us for training." I started.

"H-Hello," Tom fidgeted next to me. "I don't believe we've met properly. I'm Tom."

"I've gathered." Rita replied in a clipped, but neutral tone. "What's going on?"

Tom cleared his throat sheepishly, before explaining the situation to Rita. The girl's expression darkened a bit at the mention of Liam mistreating his Chimchar.

"I see.." Rita trailed off for a moment, seemingly lost in thought for a moment. "..And why are we not beating this guy into the dirt right now?"

"Figuratively, or literally?" I asked.

"Take your pick."

"Ah-ah- Figuratively please!" Tom sputtered. "He's still my friend! He just.. isn't acting like himself lately."

Rita gave him a searching glance for a moment.

"So you want to beat him so that he listens to you and takes it easier on Chimchar, then?"

"That... about sums it up, yeah." Tom sighed.

"Well, I'm on board. Give that guy a good kick in teeth." Rita gave Tom a thumbs up. "Does your Lotad still need patching up? I've got some supplies on me."

"Yes‚Äî Thank-you so much!" Tom responded. "I really appreciate it."

"Don't mention it." Rita replied. "Seriously, don't. I don't want people thinking I'm doing charity work."

"Oh, haha. Okay." Tom gave Rita a nervous laugh.

Rita quickly set to work tending to Lotad with a couple of spray-potions she had in her bag. Within minutes, the proof of Lotad's previous fight faded. She even gave him a spare Oran Berry she had, as a treat. Once Lotad recovered, we immediately got down to business with our training.

Out of curiosity, I pulled out my pokedex and aimed it at Tom's Lotad.

"Lotad‚ÄîThe Water Weed Pokemon. A Grass/Water type. Lotad lives in ponds and lakes with clean water. Lotad are generally seen as a benevolent pokemon, as they are sometimes known to ferry small pokemon that cannot swim across water."

Hitting the side button, I pulled up the more specific information I wanted to know.

"Lotad‚Äî Juvenille, Male. Ability: Rain Dish"

"Hmm," I hummed.

"Something wrong?" Tom asked.

"No‚Äî I was just curious about what ability Lotad has. Seems like both of our pokemon have rain abilities."

"What's Surskit's ability?"

"Swift Swim. At first I thought it had something to do with swimming, but it actually makes her faster during rain. I don't think it rains often enough here for it to really be useful, though‚ÄîUnless.." I trailed off.

"Unless?" Tom quirked a brow.

"Unless we got our pokemon to learn Rain Dance. I'm pretty sure they both can learn it, but that's probably a ways off. For now, we're better off training Water Gun."

Tom nodded thoughtfully.

"Can you get Lotad to use Water Gun real quick for me? Surskit and I have been practicing on that tree over there." I pointed at the tree.

"Sure. Hey Lotad, could you use water gun on that tree?" Tom asked his pokemon in a gentle tone.

"Tad!" The pokemon squawked happily, before launching a water gun that missed the tree entirely.

"So, aim is something to work on!" I chuckled. The pokemon seemed to give me the equivalent of a sheepish shrug.

"Don't worry Lotad, you're probably just nervous." Tom assured his kappa-like friend. "Try it again for me, okay buddy?"

The pokemon gave a nod, again launching a water gun that this time met its mark. The attack hit the tree in a broad splash, much how Surskit's water gun did when we had started training.

"Okay, so let me show you something." I started. "Surskit, your turn! Hit the tree for me, okay?"

"Skiiit!" She trilled, launching a water gun of her own. Surskit's water gun hit the tree in more of a 'jet'‚Äî similar to a strong garden hose, but with an overall more focused blast. Upon seeing her work, Surskit gave Lotad a triumphant look. She was definitely gloating a little.

"Easy there, hotshot." I smiled, giving my pokemon a pat on the head. "We still have a lot of work to do."

Surskit jerked her head away from me in a playful "Harumph!" like motion.

Tom stepped toward the tree, before running his fingers over the small divot Surskit had made. "I see."

"We've been working on narrowing the scope of Surskit's water gun little by little," I spoke evenly, trying to temper the pride in my voice. "By making the blast smaller, it seems Surskit is able to put a little more force behind it."

"Sound like something you wanna try, bud?" Tom asked.

Lotad looked from Tom, to the tree, and back. "Lo-oh!" The pokemon croaked with dubious optimism.

After training on the tree for a bit, we decided to have a bit of a mock-battle to work on our pokemon's aim. Since Rita's pokemon had been training together almost exclusively on account of their shared typing, Tom's prescence presented us with a unique opportunity to get some sparring in.

"Lotad, water gun!" Tom ordered.

"Ta-ad!" The little lily-pad creature croaked, firing off a water gun that went wide, and was easily side-stepped by Surskit.

"Aim for where you think she's going to be, not where she is!" He called.

"Keep dodging, Surskit." I smiled.

One by one, Lotad kept firing off water guns that failed to meet their mark. To his credit, he was progressively getting closer‚Äî but Surskit is a decently speedy little bug. Just as it looked as though she was about to be hit, she would effortlessly stepped out of the way.

Until she didn't.

I don't know if maybe Surskit was getting cocky or bored from dodging attacks, but eventually Lotad succeeded, hitting her square in the face.

"YES! Great job, Lotad!" Tom cheered.

"Skkiiit!" Surskit hissed, before firing off a water gun of her own without it being ordered. The water gun zipped through the air before hitting its mark, sending Lotad reeling back a few inches.

"Hey! Easy, Surskit." I chided her, and she looked up at me with an apologetic glance. My little bug had an attitude problem‚Äî and she was done being target practice.

"Sorry, I think she's a bit cranky because its almost dinner time," I looked to Tom. "I think we should call it there for today."

"No worries‚Äî and, agreed. Lotad has had a long day, and I don't want to push him too hard."

chapters.name: Chapter 19 - Call from Home
chapters.content:
I don't know what I expected. I knew I couldn't avoid it forever, but no matter how much time passed, I still didn't feel ready.

Upon returning to the dorm building I was informed by the dorm manager‚ÄîA rather nervous looking older woman‚Äîthat there was a call for me.

My heart thumped wildly in my chest as I made my way to the video-phone terminal. I looked over my shoulder a few times to make sure nobody was near‚ÄîI was sure to get chewed out for not calling sooner, and I preferred not to be overheard.

Sucking in a sharp breath, I dialed the number and waited for my call to connect.

"Ding dong ding...~Click!"

"Hello?" Florian appeared on the screen, concern written on his face.

"Hey Florian, I'm sorry that I haven't‚Äî"

"Pep!‚Äî" Florian adjusted his tone to a whisper. "Its good to see you Pep, but you have about five seconds."

"Oh god." I sighed, mentally preparing myself.

"PEPPA CARMINE! IT'S BEEN TWO WEEKS AND YOU HAVEN'T BOTHERED TO CALL?!" Mother's voice came screeching through the line before I could see her on the screen.

As expected I received a proper earful; I must have apologized twenty times before Mother finally calmed down. Once she did, I was able to catch her up on most of the happenings since arriving at the academy, save for some specifics I intentionally omitted. She listened intently, but her brows remained knit in evident frustration with me.

"So are you going to show us your pokemon?" Mother huffed.

"I want to see!" Florian squeezed in beside her.

I froze for a moment, remembering the reactions some of my fellow classmates had to Surskit. What would they say knowing I caught a bug as my first partner?

I gave my head a shake. This was my parnter. Whatever they thought didn't matter‚ÄîI was proud to be Surskit's trainer, and I needed to act like it. Steeling myself, I unclipped Surskit's pokeball and released her.

"Skiit!" My bug excitedly trilled, clearly expecting dinner.

"No, not yet, Surskit. Theres someone I want you to meet, first."

I held out my arm, and Surskit climbed up and onto my shoulder. With a deep breath, I turned around for Florian and Mother to see.

"Mother, Florian‚Äî This is Surskit," I started. "Surskit, this is my mother, and my brother Florian. Remember when we talked about family? They are a part of mine."

"Aww, its adorable!" Florian cooed at my bug.

Surskit eyed Florian's image on the screen with clear disinterest. Normally I would have expected her to preen under praise, but she must have just been too hungry to care.

"Ah, a surskit." Mother spoke in a clipped tone. "We have many of those here."

I cringed.

"You see them often when it rains... Say, Peppa dear.. Have you caught any other pokemon by chance?" Mother's expression betrayed a hint of concern.

"Not yet.. Why?" I quirked a brow at her.

"Well, uhm." Mother cleared her throat. "It might serve you well to catch, well‚Äî a different pokemon. Preferably before.." Mother's voice trailed off.
