"What do you mean? What's wrong with Surskit?" I asked, growing irritated.

Surskit glanced at the screen and back at me, her expression unreadable.

"Well, nothing, dear. I'm sure Surskit is perfectly lovely, but‚Äî" Mother froze for a moment, Looking away from the screen.

"I'm sorry dear, forget what I was saying. Your father would like to speak with you."

I took a deep breath as Mother and Florian stepped out of the frame, and Father appeared, sitting down with his arms crossed.

"Peppa, nice of you to call." He rumbled out, his deep voice dripping with disdain. "I see you've caught a pokemon for yourself."

"Y-yes, Father. This is Surskit." my voice came out in something of a squeak. "Surskit, this is my Father."

Looking over at the pokemon on my shoulder, I noticed Surskit's gaze had remained fixed on me.

For a few moments, Father simply stared at me, seemingly lost in thought.

"Father?" I asked, anxiety burning in my lungs.

"I would like for you to explain to me," He started, "Why you've chosen a bug for your partner pokemon."

I swallowed hard.

"I don't understand your question."

Father's brows furrowed deeply, and for a moment I swore his eyes matched his fire-red hair.

"Let me rephrase my question. Would you care to explain to me, why you've not only selected a bug‚Äî But a bug you could have found in our back yard, no less?"

"I-I‚Äî" I stammered.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to answer. Just listen. Since you seem to have forgotten, in two weeks‚Äô time there will be a tournament held at your school. There will be many eyes on all such tournaments, including those of sponsors. I expect you to find a pokemon more suited to our name, and to not deliberately embarrass the people who put you in that school. Do I make myself clear?‚Äù

"But-"

"Good. I look forward to seeing you win."

Before I could object, Father stalked off, leaving Mother and Florian standing behind the screen, looking clearly disquieted.

The rest of the call was a blur.

"Augh!" I yelled, kicking at the air. "He didn't even let me get a word in!"

Surskit looked to me, and back to the video-phone terminal‚Äî Before 'punching' at the screen with her feet.

"Wait, Surskit‚Äî What are you doing?" I stood bewildered as my little bug harmlessly assailed the machine.

"Skit! Skit!" She hissed with each strike.

"Oh, I get it. You don't like the machine because it made me sad?"

"Surs!" She nodded, before returning to her assault.

I couldn't help but smile. At least you have my back.

Once again, I lifted Surskit up and back onto my shoulder.

"There's someone else I want you to meet, and I think you will like him."

Surskit grunted out her annoyance.

Once again, I dialed a familiar number.

"Ding dong ding...~ Ding dong ding..~ Click!"

"Who is this and how did you get my number?!" Grandpa chuckled, stroking his beard.

"Its your favorite grandchild!" I answered.

"Favorite grandchild? I don't have one of those." He rolled his eyes playfully.

"Sure you don't Grandpa." I laughed. "Anyways, theres someone I want you to meet. Say hi, Surskit." I gently nudged my pokemon.

"Skiit!" Surskit hissed at the machine once again.

"Ohoh, a Surskit‚Äî And a feisty one too." Grandpa's voice rumbled as he adjusted his glasses. "Interesting choice, bean-sprout."

"I know," I groaned. "I already got an earful from Father."

Grandpa winced.

"I can imagine. How are you holding up, dear?"

"Honestly? I'm angry. Surskit is an amazing pokemon, but everyone keeps writing her off as just 'a bug'. I don't understand what the issue is with bugs to begin with." I huffed.

"Well, they are generally regarded as the worst type, hun."

"What? Why?" I asked.

"You see, bugs enjoy earlier evolutions than most pokemon; and for that reason they can be good for beginners, but once they evolve, that's it. There isn't much room for growth later down the line, so they often get passed up in favor of stronger pokemon. They're also usually pretty frail compared to others, and have quite a number of weaknesses."

From what I remembered of Pokemon games from Earth, what Grandpa was saying was true, but only half the story in my eyes. Even back in my old world, I had always been of the belief that any pokemon could be good as long as you used them correctly. While bug-types weren't always a 'meta' pick, they could quite often be very solid depending on how you built them and the rest of your team. The amount of disdain people had here for bug-types seemed wildly disproportionate to me.

But game knowledge aside, this was a real, thinking and feeling creature. To me, competitive viability was much less important than the bond I had with Surskit. She could be the weakest pokemon, and her feelings would still matter. The way that people disregarded her on account of her rarity and typing truly had begun to make my blood boil.

"..I think all pokemon are good pokemon." I sighed.

"I know, bean-sprout. Don't worry. I'm sure Surskit will make a fantastic partner." Grandpa winked.

With that, we talked a bit more before saying our goodbyes. It was getting late, and I didn't think Surskit would abide my chatting any longer.

chapters.name: Chapter 20 - Bug Research
chapters.content:
As I laid in bed, I replayed the conversations I had with my family over and over in my head‚Äî I was doubtful that sleep would find me tonight. Not only had father called Surskit an embarrassment, but there was also a tournament supposedly coming up that I was expected to win. How Father knew, I simply chalked up to connections.

If Father was to be believed, catching another pokemon may soon become paramount. Rita, Claire, and Beatrice all had two pokemon as far as I was aware, and within two weeks time, the rest of the class would no doubt follow suit. While I knew I needed to start giving my next capture some thought, there was no way I would be giving in to Father's demands and replacing Surskit. Absolutely out of the question‚Äî I would just have to train hard and show everyone how awesome Surskit is.

There was also my conversation with Grandpa to consider. He was right‚ÄîBug types do tend to evolve much earlier than other pokemon, and though I had no way of knowing how far off an evolution for Surskit would be, it would serve me well to be prepared.

Once Surskit evolved, she would become a Masquerain, and thus lose her Water typing‚Äî becoming a Bug/Flying type instead. Assuming things worked similarly to the Pokemon games, (which from what I had seen so far, I had to assume they did,) this meant that she would lose her 'STAB' (Same Type Attack Bonus) for water gun. That isn't to say she wouldn't be able to use it anymore, but it would likely see a significant decrease in damage. That said, having a reliable counter to fire types in a pinch would no doubt be invaulable once she lost her water typing, anyways.

Either way, it was time for Surskit to begin training a different move now. I wasn't sure what moves Surskit could learn off the top of my head, so for now, I settled on possibly training quick attack, and maybe even working on her bubble attack as well. Hopefully with any luck, there would be a move that saw Surskit utilizing her bug-type energy that we could work on, but that would require some studying on my part.

With a plan in mind, I tossed and turned a bit longer before finally drifting off to sleep.

Classes sped by the next day, as I spent most of the day lost in thoughts of training. There was still the problem of capturing another pokemon, but I decided that I would go looking during the upcoming weekend. Today was Thursday, so that gave me enough time to study and hopefully find Surskit a new move to practice first. I let Rita and Tom know that I would be busy today, so after classes finished, I made my way to the school's library.

The library was an impressive sight, and served as a staunch reminder of the school's winding history. Rows and rows of bookshelves went on nearly as far as I could see, and in the center of the library stood an impressively embellished fireplace‚Äîalmost on the verge of being gaudy‚Äîthough it wasn't currently lit on account of it still being summer. The library also featured a few tables, as well as more private study nooks that hugged the walls of the room. Upon entering, I made my way to a front desk where a rather bookish looking girl sat behind a computer.

Stolen from its rightful place, this narrative is not meant to be on Amazon; report any sightings.

"Hello, need any help finding anything today?" She asked, not looking up from her screen.

"Oh, uh. If you could just point me in the direction of books on bug-type pokemon?" I replied.

For a moment, it was silent, save for the girl's rapid clicking at her keyboard.

"All type-based reference materials are divided up in their own sections, you'll find them over there." She pointed.

"Thank-you." I gave her a nod, and made my way over to the types section.

Upon finding the bug-type section, I thumbed my way through a few different titles before landing on one that interested me‚Äî A dusty old journal that seemed to be a trainer's record of training bug type pokemon. I also grabbed a book on known bug types, and found my way towards one of the study nooks.

Admittedly, I probably could have looked through the pokedex, but as it was a newer invention at this time, I expected I'd find more information by reading the old fashioned way. It wasn't too long ago that all pokedexes were on paper, anyways.

I flipped through the hard-cover book on bug types until I landed on Surskit's entry.

The book had all the information the pokedex had relayed to me, as well as some other interesting trivia. At the bottom of the page was a section with Surskit's known moves.

The section read:

Surskit's Known Moves:

Water Gun

Quick Attack

Sweet Scent

Soak

Bubble Beam

Agility

Mist

Haze

Baton Pass

Sticky Web

I sucked my teeth. I had hoped for a wider selection of bug type moves, but I supposed this gave us enough to aim for at the moment.

On the next page, there was a list of moves learnable by Technical Machine that featured a few moves that caught my eye: Struggle Bug, and Bug Buzz namely. TM's did exist in this world, but they were a bit beyond my means at the moment‚Äî I had heard of some selling for nearly 40,000 Pokedollars a piece. I made a mental note to myself to look into TMs later, presumably once I had a sponsor; and wrote down the list of learnable moves on a sheet of paper.

Flipping through the dusty journal, it seemed to contain the accounts of a trainer from decades ago that trained exclusively bug-type pokemon. The trainer's journal entries consisted of their general day to day, as well as some other information here and there on bug-type nutrition and other random bits of information. I was just about to put the book back when something caught my eye‚Äî an entry about the author catching a surskit. While having battled the surskit, there was mention of the pokemon having used a move similar to bite.

I looked back at my written list of Surskit's learnable moves, and found no mention of bite. Flipping back to the hard cover book, there was mention of Bug Bite being one of the learnable moves by TM.

The bug-trainer's journal seemed pretty clear that this was a wild Surskit though, and I wasn't even sure how long TMs had existed for in this world, for that matter.

A grin stretched across my face. Perhaps there was a way for Surskit to learn a bug move without a TM, after all.

chapters.name: Chapter 21 - Bug Bite
chapters.content:
When I arrived at our usual training spot, Rita was already there with her two pokemon. Well, I say two‚ÄîGrimer seemed to be lazily watching Oddish train. Despite the steely determination he had shown against the wild Gabite, it seemed Grimer had little interest in doing anything that didn't involve eating garbage during his day to day.

I had pointed this out to Rita once, to which she responded: "Eating pollutants is part of Grimer's job, it helps protect the natural order."

Still, the impressive little blob creature did save my life, so I was all for the little guy getting as much garbage as he could stuff himself with. He seemed to be thoroughly content with it, with Rita taking him out to the dumpsters every day after school let out so he could feast.

I said "Hi" to Rita and set to work training with Surskit. Tom was notably absent, so I figured either he was busy or would be coming later. Either way, I went ahead and got cracking.

"Okay Surskit, you know how you channel water-type energy to use water gun? I want you to try to do that, but with bug-type energy. Try focusing it around your mouth."

Surskit looked up at me, befuddled.

"I know, I know. Just try it." I gave my bug a pat on the head.

Surskit stood stone-still with eyes shut tight for a few moments, before giving a quiet "Puuhhh," sound as if she had been holding her breath.

"Hmm, Okay." I started. "Rita, I may need your help for this."

"Yeah? What do you need?"

"Do you think Grimer would be okay with being bitten?" I cringed a bit as the words came out.

"What?" Rita stared at me in her expressionless manner.

"I'm trying to get Surskit to learn bug-bite, but I think she needs to practice it on something. I didn't want to ask Oddish to do it, because if she succeeds it will be super-effective damage." I responded.

"So you decided the poisonous blob was the better choice?" Rita asked, quirking an eyebrow.

Surskit looked at Grimer, and than back to me with a dubious look.

"When you put it like that, it does sound silly." I facepalmed.

"Here, I have a better idea." Rita said, reaching into a large backpack on the ground beside her. After digging for a few moments, she produced a small plushie of a Chansey. I fought the urge to smile.

"Don't say anything. We were giving them out at the Pokecenter." Rita glowered.

"Is that where the one on your bed came from?"

Rita punched me in the arm, which admittedly hurt a lot. I chuckled my thanks before placing the doll in front of Surskit.

"Okay Surskit. I want you to bite the doll."

"Surs?"

"Yeah, I know it sounds weird. Just trust me, okay?"

Surskit gave me an adorable little nod, before taking a few steps forward. She gave the doll a small chomp, and looked up at me expectantly.

"Good!" I praised her. "So what I want you to do is to try to gather bug-type energy again, around your mouth if you can‚Äî and then bite the doll."

Surskit tilted her head at me slightly as I spoke, but quickly set to work with another attempt.

Again, she stood stock-still before giving a quiet sputter.

Focusing bug-type energy took a lot more out of her than I would have expected, given the fact that she is a bug-type. I decided that my little bug had earned herself a break twice over.

Surskit and I watched Rita's pokemon train for a bit, while Surskit munched on some berries. While we watched, Tom arrived a heaving mess‚Äî profusely apologizing for having been late.

‚ÄúI-I‚Äôm so sorry. I went‚Ä¶ to the library‚Ä¶ after classes and‚Ä¶ lost track of time.‚Äù He sputtered, clutching at his knees.

"Hey, relax! Surskit and I were just taking a break." I gave him a pat on the back.

"What did I miss?" Tom straightened, catching his breath.

"I'm trying to have Surskit learn a new move‚Äî Bug-bite. It was slow going at first, but I think we're making some progress."

"Thats great! I was actually reading up on moves for Lotad. When you said you were going to the library yesterday, I figured it would be a good idea to do some research myself."

"Find anything?" I asked.

"Not a lot, no. Most of the moves were TM moves, and I doubt I could convince my parents to give me what I'd need for it. For now I think I'll have Lotad train the moves he already knows."

After chatting a bit longer, Tom set to training with Lotad. Once Surskit had recovered, I decided to make one last push with Surskit's training for the day.

On the next attempt, the bug-type energy seemed to come a bit easier, after about a minute of Surskit focusing. Once again, it petered out before she could move.

Surskit looked at the ground, seemingly dejected.

"Hey, its okay, buddy." I assured her. "I didn't expect it would be easy. We just need to keep trying."

"Surs." Surskit gave a curt grunt.

"Don't be like that." I kneeled down in front of Surskit to look her in the eyes. "This is a move you normally wouldn't learn this way, so we're experimenting a bit. I promise that you're doing great. Plus, if you succeed, that'll mean you're in the top percentage of Surskit!" I gave my bug a wink.

"Skiit-ti-tit!" Surskit beamed at me with newfound fire in her eyes.

The next attempt saw marked improvement, with Surskit's charging time decreasing by about half. This time, she managed to take a few steps towards the doll before losing grip on the energy.

With each subsequent attempt, Surskit seemed to redouble her efforts. She wanted to be in the top percentage of Surskit, and she wanted it bad.

After another thirty minutes or so, Surskit had finally done it‚Äî With wobbling legs, she managed to land a bite on the doll. Unfortunately, the energy dissipated just as she chomped down.

"SKKT-T-TT!" Surskit hissed in frustration. If I spoke pokemon, I'm sure I would have heard some choice words from my little menace.

I made sure to praise her plenty before packing up for the day.

The next day saw a veritable downpour from the skies. Rita informed me that it would rain for the rest of the day, so while she decided to stay indoors and study, I decided this was a prime time to train with Surskit. In the rain, Surskit would be in her element, after all. I donned a my bright yellow rain poncho, and made my way for the training field.

My feet made wet shlooping sounds as I trudged my way through the muddy training field. All of the plots were empty save for one‚Äî our usual training spot.

Tom stood in the rain thoroughly soaked through, as his Lotad dutifully trained with more vim and vigor than I had seen from him prior.

"That's it, Lotad! Water gun, again!" Tom called.

Lotad's water gun shot out at the tree in a condensed jet, successfully making the divot in the tree's bark that much deeper.

I gave a steady clap as I approached.

Jumping slightly, Tom turned to me. "I didn't see you there, Pep."

"Sorry if I started you. Lotad's water gun looks great!" I shouted slightly over the rain.

For a moment, Tom stood silently as the rain bounced off his coat.

‚ÄúPep, can I battle you?‚Äù

chapters.name: Chapter 22 - Pep versus Tom
chapters.content:
Tom and I squared off at opposite ends of the muddy arena. I didn't know why Tom was so intent on battling, but I wasn't going to pass up the perfect opportunity to test out Surskit's Swift Swim ability.

With a trill, my bug appeared on the battlefield opposite Tom's Lotad.

Since we didn't have a referee, we agreed to begin on the count of three.

"One..
..Two..
..Three!"

"Lotad, astonish!" Tom was the first to issue his order.
Lotad bounded forward, but before he could get within striking distance, Surskit was already off‚Äî zipping around him with relative ease.

"Great! Surskit, use quick attack!" I called.
Surskit glided across the wet ground like a figure skater, zipping around Lotad in a circle before landing a direct hit that saw Lotad staggering backwards.

"Keep it up!" I cheered. With an effortless grace, Surskit zigged and zagged across the battlefield, landing one blow after the other. Lotad didn't have a moment to react before Surskit was already behind him from another angle, ready to bowl him over.

Truthfully, I felt a little bad. That was until I saw Tom smile.

For a moment I was confused, as it seemed as though Surskit was steamrolling Lotad with little resistance‚Äî but then I remembered Lotad's ability.

While Surskit had been exerting energy with every blow, Lotad's Rain Dish had been continuously healing him. At this rate, Surskit would exhaust herself before Lotad would fall.

Tom must have planned for this.

"Surskit, we're changing gears! Conserve your energy!"

Surskit skidded to a halt opposite her opponent, panting slightly. Sure enough, she was winded.

"Don't give her time to rest! Absorb!" Tom fired back.

Deep green energy coalesced around both pokemon for a moment, marking Lotad's absorb as a clean hit. Within seconds, a fraction of Surskit's energy had been drained from her, while Lotad looked healthier than ever.

I sucked my teeth. The attack itself wasn't super-effective, but Tom knew Surskit was tired and used it to his advantage.

The author's tale has been misappropriated; report any instances of this story on Amazon.

As Surskit wobbled slightly, Tom once again pressed the attack.

"Astonish!" Tom shouted over the intensifying rain. "Don't let her recover!"

Once again, Lotad bounded forward, this time meeting his mark. Surskit staggered backward, flinching from the sudden attack. Before Surskit could regain her bearings, Lotad hit her again. This cycle repeated a couple more times, and Surskit was definitely looking worse for wear.

"Surskit, you have to break away from him! Use quick attack to get some distance!"

As Surskit attempted to dart away, Lotad for once was faster. Another absorb landed, serving to exhaust Surskit even further.

Surskit's quick attack unfortunately saw her skidding face first into the mud.

"Surskit, are you okay?!" I cried.

"Ss..Skit!" Surskit once again rose on shaking legs. She wasn't out of the fight just yet.

"If you're sure." I gave my bug a nod.

"Lotad, lets finish this!" Tom once again shouted with an uncharacteristic determination.

Surskit stood motionless as Lotad once again began to close in. Just as he came within striking distance, a yellow-green energy began to coalesce around Surskit's mouth.

She was going to try to land a bug-bite.

"Wait for it-" I ordered. "Now! You can do it Surskit!"

With a snap, the previously still bug got right in Lotad's face, chomping down hard on the brim of his lily-pad 'hat'.

Lotad staggered backward with a cry, having taken serious damage from the super-effective move.

In the heat of the moment, Surskit had successfully pulled off a bug-bite. But there was no time to celebrate just yet.

"Lotad, get some distance and absorb!" Tom shouted, looking shaken from the unexpected turn.

"Don't let him! Quick attack, into bug-bite!"

With renewed confidence, Surskit once again zipped across the battlefield, sending water spraying in a trail behind her.

There was precious little Lotad could do as Surskit came careening into him. With another snap, Surskit once again chomped down on Lotad, and this time the attack saw him fall.

"Lotad, no!" Tom cried, rushing to his friend's side.

"You did it Surskit!" I cheered. "You're in the top percentage of Surskit, for sure!"

Surskit trilled triumphantly, pumping a 'foot' in the air, before staggering forward. The fight had taken a lot out of her.

"Get some good rest, okay?" I smiled, returning my partner to her pokeball. When I turned around, Tom had done the same.

"That was a close fight," I said as I approached my friend. "Is Lotad okay?"

"Yeah, he's alright." Tom spoke without looking at me.

"Good match." I extended my hand out to Tom with a grin. "I think our pokemon both fought well!"

Tom sighed, before giving my hand a shake.

"Good match." He replied weakly.

There was an awkward pause as Tom looked at Lotad's pokeball.

"Uhm.. Are you okay?" I asked.

"Yeah, sorry Pep. I just.. I wanted to make sure I was ready to take on Liam and his Chimchar, but now I'm not so sure." Tom's shoulders slumped with a heavy sigh.

"Are you kidding? You did great! If it weren't for Surskit working out bug-bite at the last second, you would have won for sure." I gave Tom a pat on the shoulder.

"You think so?"

"Totally. Theres no way Surskit would have been able to dish out enough damage. Your strategy of waiting to tire her out really paid off!"

Tom gave me a weak smile.

"Alright. Thank-you, Pep. Really."

"Don't mention it. But lets get out of the rain before we both catch a cold."

chapters.name: Chapter 23 - Honey
chapters.content:
Tom and I went our separate ways once we made it back to the campus. On my walk back to the dorm, I started thinking. It was concerning how important the battle seemed to him, though I admit it was also bit comforting to know that I wasn't the only one feeling anxious about battling. Upon returning to the dorm, I removed my wet shoes and coat and hung them up to dry.

"Rita?" I called.

No response. I wondered where she had gotten off to.

After a shower and some warm pajamas, I flopped onto my bed with a huff. Lately I had found it rare to be alone with my thoughts, but as I settled into the silence of the room, I realized that there was a lot on my mind.

Thoughts of the upcoming tournament fought for dominance among others‚Äî capturing a new pokemon, my family's expectations, Surskit's success with bug-bite, having been almost been killed by a wild pokemon weeks prior, and so on.

Not to mention the whole, "Being reborn in the world of pokemon," thing. I usually did my best to avoid thinking about that at all, instead opting to focus on the life in front of me‚Äî but in quiet moments like these, it was hard not to at least a little.

Where I once had been a sick kid rotting away in a hospital room, I now was the future heiress of the Carmine family estate‚Äî and an honest-to-god pokemon trainer. That certainly came with a fair amount of whiplash, even after seventeen years.

I sighed deeply, clutching my pillow tightly in my arms.

There was nothing for it. For now, I would do what I had always done and focus on the present moment. What could I do in the short term?

One thing was certain; I needed to catch my next pokemon.

I had a few ideas already on how I could find one.

Route 204, (where I had caught Surskit,) was situated in the middle of Jubilife City and Floroma Town. Though in the games it was much smaller and less wooded, one thing stayed the same‚Äî it was host to many different pokemon. If I weren't restricted by time and transportation, I would have opted for the Eterna Forest, but the winding route would do just fine for my purposes.

With that in mind, I decided to prepare for tomorrow's excursion.

The following day, the torrential rain had fortunately let up. The walk to Route 204 had been much more pleasant than I remembered. I hadn't made much note prior of the brilliantly colored flowers and berry bushes that littered the trail‚Äî but now I had the time to fully appreciate them. I took in a deep breath, savoring the floral scents mixed with that of morning dew.

Breaking off the trail, I returned to the site where the exams had been held. There was no trace left of the impressive shimmering dome that had been erected by the researcher's psychic pokemon. I wished I had gotten the chance to ask more questions about that.

Moving on, I continued to press on through the sparse forest. It was time to put my plan to the test.

In the Pokemon games, Sinnoh featured a unique way to find and capture pokemon‚Äî Slathering honey on trees and waiting for wild pokemon to take the bait. In the games, this method was introduced as a way for the player to attact rare and unique encounters. I wasn't sure that I would find anything particularly rare today, but it certainly couldn't hurt to try. For the purposes of my experiment, I had purchased a bottle of Florama brand honey earlier this morning.

Eventually I came across a large tree I felt was a suitable test subject, and got to work slathering the sweet, golden honey across its bark. Once finished, I unclipped Surskit's pokeball from my belt and released her.

"Skii-iiit." Surskit yawned, stretching her legs out.

"Good morning, Surskit!"

"...Surs?" Surskit blinked with bleary eyes, taking in the surrounding area.

If you spot this narrative on Amazon, know that it has been stolen. Report the violation.

"Thats right, we're back where we met," I gave her a gentle pat on the head. "Can you guess what we're doing here?"

Surskit stared up at me silently, before giving a confused trill.

"We're catching another team member!" I beamed.

"Skii-iit?"

"Don't you want another friend to play and train with?" I asked.

Surskit hopped up and down excitedly. "Surs! Skit-ti-tit!"

"I thought so," I smiled at her. "Could you help me out with something then?"

Surskit tilted her head inquisitively.

"I need you to use sweet scent for me, do you think you could do that?"

Surskit nodded in the affirmative, and after she concentrated for a few moments, an almost sickly sweet-smelling scent filled the air.

"Great, now come over here." I motioned for Surskit to follow.

Crouching down, Surskit and I hid behind some nearby bushes. Now, it was time to wait.

After about an hour, Surskit grew bored of fiddling with twigs and leaves, and curled up for a nap. As I watched my pokemon sleep soundly beside me, my own eyelids began to grow heavy. A few times I felt my gaze drifting downwards, before snapping back to the tree.

I slapped myself on the cheeks to shock myself back into wakefulness. Today was going to be a long day.

I gasped as my eyes snapped open to the sound of chittering.

Something was eating the honey.

I clamped a hand over my mouth hoping whatever it was hadn't heard me. With a gentle nudge, I shook Surskit awake and placed a finger over my mouth in a 'Shh' motion.

"Surrs?" Surskit yawned, not taking the hint.

The chittering noise stopped. I held my breath for a few seconds, until the sound resumed.

"When I do this," I made the 'Shh' signal again. "It means be quiet." I whispered.

Surskit gave me a curt nod.

Peaking over the bushes, I got a look a good look at my quarry: A plump Spinarak who was happily shoveling globs of honey into its mouth. The contented green spider made small trilling noises as it ate, its little legs carefully stepping around the sticky parts of the tree bark.

It was so cute I wanted to scream.

I watched on in fascination as it continued to eat, before Surskit let out a low hiss. It didn't take long to figure out why, as a few seconds later the forest around us seemed to fill with the sound of aggressive buzzing.

Beedrill.

Before I could move, a stinger rocketed through the trees and stuck itself in the tree's bark, right next to the feasting Spinarak. Startled, the Spinarak began to flee, but it was too late. Three Beedrill descended from over the treetops, closing off Spinarak's path to escape.

"Spii!" The pokemon cried defiantly, despite its legs clearly trembling.

Next to me, Surskit seemed to bristle.

I looked to my pokemon and back to the scene in front of me. I felt bad for Spinarak, but I didn't like our odds against three Beedrill. I froze up entirely, trying to decide what to do.

Before I could come to a decision, however; the Beedrill acted first. One Beedril swung its drill-like arms at the Spinarak, while the poor spider barely managed to dodge.

As the Spinirak landed, a second Beedrill was already waiting. The large bee slapped Spinarak down from the tree. Spinarak hit the ground with a thud.

As the third Beedril descended to presumably 'finish off' the now motionless Spinarak, my body moved on its own. I darted forward from the bushes, cursing under my breath.

"Skiit!" Surskit cried from behind me.

I scooped the green spider up into my arms, before a searing pain sunk into my shoulder.

I had been stung.

Cursing, I feebly attempted to bat the oversized bee away with my good arm, while it buzzed menacingly.

Suddenly, a jet of water rocketed forward, causing the bee to stagger. I wasted no time getting behind Surskit.

"Surskit, we need to run." I panted as hot red blood dripped down my arm, staining my shirt.

"Sktt-t-t!" Surskit hissed in defiance. My little bug was incensed, and fully intended to take on all three Beedril herself.

"No way! We're running!" I stomped my foot.

Surskit ignored me, firing off another water gun at the Beedrill that stung me. The pokemon hissed, prompting the other two to descend.

One Beedrill charged Surskit, while another shot poisonous stingers in her direction. The stingers stuck themselves about half an inch into the dirt as Surskit maneuvered around them.

"Please, Surskit!" I pleaded. "Its not worth it!"

Just as I said that, the third Beedrill descended upon me, wildly swinging its arms.

"Please!" I cried out again, shielding the wounded Spinarak as I desperately attempted to flee from my pursuer.

Another water gun came zipping from Surskit's direction, hitting the third Beedrill in the back.

In an instant, Surskit zipped to my side. Her beady black eyes darted around wildly as she anticipated the attacks that threatened to come from all sides. Suddenly, her gaze snapped to me, and she gave me a nod.

Before I could interpret it, Surskit unleashed a torrent of bubbles larger than I had seen from her previously. She was distracting the Beedril so we could run.

Without hesitation, I pushed myself to run harder than ever before. Thankfully, the adrenaline had long since kicked in. Surskit sprinted at my side, firing water guns and bubblebeams at our pursuers.

A few times I staggered from the searing pain in my shoulder, but I pressed on until the sounds of buzzing had long since faded, leaving only the sound of blood pumping in my ears.

Once we made it past the treeline, my vision began to blur. A pulsing, burning sensation had spread from my shoulder, and I was now growing dizzy. I didn't dare stop walking though, because I feared if I did I would collapse on the spot.

Once we made it back to the trail, I spotted a group of people‚Äî they were the last thing I saw before everything went dark.

chapters.name: Chapter 24 - Pokemon Center
chapters.content:
My consciousness had faded in and out a few times, but I was vaguely aware of being carried. I wasn't sure how much time had passed, but eventually, I awoke to the familiar sounds of machinery beeping. I could feel a wire attached to my arm, and a dull discomfort in the top of my hand.

"Vitals are good. No, she hasn't woken up yet." A voice spoke.

"I don't understand why you wont let me just wait here."

"I understand how you feel, but like I said; even you have to follow protocol."

Slowly, I opened my eyes to see Rita and a Nurse Joy arguing.

"Uhm... Hello?" I croaked out. My words came out throaty and hoarse.

Both Rita and Nurse Joy snapped their focus to me.

"Oh, looks like you're awake." The nurse spoke. "How are you feeling?"

"Terrible. Everything hurts." I shivered.

"Ah, yes. You took quite a bit of Beedrill poison, you know?" The nurse squinted at me. "What exactly were you doing out there?"

"Thats what I'd like to know." Rita scowled.

"Catching a.. The pokemon!" I shot upright. "Where is Surskit? And Spinarak!"

"Easy, settle down." The nurse pushed me back into a laying-down position. "You shouldn't be moving so quickly."

"Please.. I, The Spinarak was hurt and‚Äî"

"Shhh. It's okay now. Relax." The nurse place a gentle hand on my shoulder. "The Spinarak is fine, he sustained only minor injuries. Your Surskit was exhausted, but otherwise okay. We are holding her pokeball for you."

I sighed in relief. "That's good. Can I see them?"

"Can you worry about yourself for a second?" Rita cut in.

I stared at Rita wordlessly for a few seconds. She stood with her arms crossed, holding my gaze.

"I.. uhm, okay." I stammered, breaking our staring contest.

"How much do you remember of getting here?" Nurse Joy asked.

"Not much.. I was running from the Beedrill, and Surskit was holding them off. I made it out of the forest and... that's it, really."

"A group of trainers saw you collapse on the path back to the city." Nurse Joy started. "They brought you and your pokemon here. Thankfully Pokemon Centers like ours are equipped with anditodes‚Äî you had a pretty high fever when you came in, on account of all the poison."

"I.. see." I coughed. "Are they still here? I'll have to thank them."

"No, we had to send them away about an hour ago. It's past visiting hours‚Äî you've been asleep for a while."

I sat silently, processing what Nurse Joy had said.

"I'll leave you two for a bit. Make sure to get plenty of rest, okay?" The kind nurse turned and exited the room, shutting the door behind her.

Just as the door closed, Rita was in my face.

"What the hell were you thinking!" She yelled, gripping me by the collar of my hospital gown. "You could have gotten yourself killed!"

"I-I'm sorry!" I stammered.

Rita took a deep breath, and released my gown from her grip.

"No. I'm sorry. I just‚Äî When they brought you in, you looked real bad, y'know." Rita took a few steps back, facing away from me.

‚ÄúRita, I‚Äôm so sorry! I needed a new pokemon for the tournament so‚Äî‚Äú I clapped a hand over my mouth.

Rita turned, narrowing her eyes. "What tournament?"

‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ I shouldn‚Äôt tell anyone. Even you.‚Äù

Rita crossed her arms, glaring daggers at me. "I swear‚ÄîIf you don‚Äôt tell me what I almost lost you for, Peppa Carmine, I‚Äôm going to finish the job."

‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ Okay,‚Äù I took a breath. ‚ÄúBut you can‚Äôt tell anyone.‚Äù

"I spoke to my family a few days ago, and my father told me that there would be a tournament held in about two weeks. I don't know how he knows, but he expects me to win."

For a moment, Rita's gaze softened, but only slightly.

"Okay. That explains what you were doing out there." She sighed. "But what I don't understand is why you didn't ask me or someone else to come with you."

"What do you-"

"What I mean is, you shouldn't be wandering around the wilderness alone, Pep!" She snapped. "I would have came with you!"

"You would have? I asked.

"Yes! It would be better than seeing my friend get killed by wild Beedrill!"

A silence hung in the air for a few moments.

"...I'm your friend?" I asked.

"Pep, what did you think? Yes you're my friend, you IDIOT!" Rita stomped her foot. "Nobody else tolerates me except for Tom‚Äî and he's always got a look like he'll crumble into dust if I look at him!"

I stared, wide eyed for a few seconds, before breaking out into a sob.

"I was so scared!" I wailed. "I thought it would be fine since we caught our pokemon there!"

Rita froze up, her expression shifting into an uncomfortable grimace.

As I sobbed, she placed a stiff hand on my shoulder.

"Easy. I'm sorry for yelling."

Rita stood silently with me while I cried, seemingly unsure of what to do.

Eventually, I managed to calm down.

"I-I'm sorry." I sniffled. "I didn't want you to see that."

"I wont tell anyone."

"Promise?"

"I promise." Rita gave me a solemn nod.

By the next morning, my fever had broken and I was given the all clear to be discharged from the center. Thankfully, Rita brought me a change of clothes since the clothes I wore coming in were pretty much ruined.

The first thing I did upon receiving the rest of my belongings was release Surskit from her pokeball.

"Surs! Sursssskiiititit!" My pokemon cried as her gaze swept over me wildly, presumably checking for injuries. When her eyes fell upon my bandaged shoulder, she froze.

"Easy, easy. I'm okay." I assured her. "I'm so sorry to worry you, Surskit."

"Skiiit." Surskit let out a morose whine, before snuggling up in the crook of my arm.

"It's not your fault, Surskit. Its mine. I should have known better‚Äî I shouldn't have put you in danger.

Rita cleared her throat from the doorway.

"I shouldn't have put us in danger." I corrected myself.

Surskit clung to my arm, seemingly unwilling to let go. I found myself choking back tears upon seeing my pokemon so torn up.

"It's okay, Surskit. I'm alright." I assured her, my own voice beginning to waver.

After a bit of comforting, Surskit finally relaxed.

"Do you want to go see Spinarak?" I asked, wiping my eyes.

Surskit looked up at me, blinking away tears. "Surrs?"

As Rita and I entered the clinic, a familiar nurse was already waiting for us.

"Oh, good to see you back on your feet." She smiled at me. "You're here to see Spinarak, I presume?"

"Yes, and thank you. For taking care of me." I responded.

"Oh, no worries‚Äî But I do have to say, please be more careful next time. You would have been in real danger if those trainers hadn't spotted you."

Rita grunted her agreement.

"Yes ma'am‚Äî I understand." I nodded respectfully.

Nurse joy turned, taking a few steps down the corridor. "Spinarak is just this way, follow me."

Rita and I followed closely behind Nurse Joy as we walked down the winding hallways. The back of PokeCenters were a lot bigger than I had ever expected.

After walking for what felt like forever with my injury, we came upon a door. Nurse Joy stopped, before turning to us.

"Now, before we go inside, I'll warn you both to be cautious. Spinarak is still a wild pokemon, so don't make any sudden movements or loud noises, okay?"

Rita and I both nodded, and Nurse Joy opened the door.

Inside, the plump Spinarak was happily munching on a bowl of Poke-chow. He didn't even look up as we entered the room.

I approached the spider slowly, crouching down to get closer to eye level. "Hello, Spinarak." I whispered.

The pokemon looked up at me for a moment, seemingly confused. I held out my hand, and Spinirak came a bit closer.

Recognition flashed across Spinarak's eyes as he took in my scent.

"Spiii!" The pokemon cried, before climbing halfway up my leg. Startled, I fell backwards onto my butt.

Rita and Nurse Joy both took a few steps forward, but stopped as I started laughing.

"H-hey!" I giggled as Spinarak skittered up my body. "Your legs tickle!"

Spinarak stopped at my shoulder, sniffing at my bandages. He looked up at me with a troubled tilt of the head.

"Its okay, little guy. Don't worry‚Äî I'm just glad you're safe." I smiled at the excited spider. "There's someone I want you to meet, okay?"

Spinarak sat in my lap as I reached for my Surskit's pokeball. I let him sniff that too, before releasing Surskit.

"Spii, spiii?" Spinarak chirped as Surskit materialized in a flash of red light.

For a moment, the pokemon eyed eachother cautiously, before giving eachother a couple of sniffs.

Spinarak ran a couple of circles around Surskit, before giving her a gentle nudge.

Surskit seemed taken aback by this, but surprisingly allowed the spider to cuddle up to her. Surskit froze and looked at me with an expression that read, "What do I do now?"

I smiled as I sat criss-cross on the floor watching the adorable display. Even Rita couldn't help but let out and "Aww," upon seeing the affectionate spider nuzzle Surskit.

"So, Spinarak‚Äî I have a question for you." I spoke, clearing my throat.

Spinarak turned and plodded over to me, once again climbing into my lap.

"You see‚Äî I'm a pokemon trainer. Surskit is my partner," I started. "We train together to get stronger, and we battle together, too."

Surskit puffed herself up triumphantly with a trill.

"I was wondering, would you like to join my team?" I asked. "Its okay if you don't want to, or need some time to think about it."

Spinarak again tilted his head at me, seemingly confused.

Suddenly, Surskit began to chirp.

"Surss, skit-tit-surs," She warbled.

"Spii? Spi-narr,"

The two pokemon continued to converse for a couple of minutes, before Spinarak turned to me; his eyes glimmering with excitement.

"Spii spii!" Spinarak trilled, again climbing up my chest.

"O-okay! I think thats a yes!" I beamed at Rita.

"Looks like it to me." She gave me a small, barely-there smile in typical Rita fashion.

I reached for my bag, and produced a pokeball. Unshrinking it from clip size, I held it out to Spinarak.

"If you join my team, that means I'll have to catch you with this. Is that okay?" I asked the green spider.

"Narakk! Spii!"

With a nod, I pressed the pokeball gently to Spinarak's head, and the spider disappeared in a flash of red. The ball shook twice in my hand, before giving a satisfying 'click'.

It took all of my effort to stop myself from jumping up with excitement.

"YES!!" I raised my good arm high, holding Spinarak's pokeball up in the air.

Surskit happily trilled, running circled around me.

"Shhh," Nurse Joy shushed me. "This is still a hospital."

"Oh, sorry. Yesssssss," I whispered.

Rita playfully rolled her eyes.

"So, I guess we wont be having to relocate him," Nurse Joy started. "Onto the matter of your bill."

I froze. "Wait, what?"

chapters.name: Chapter 25 - Pep's Day Off
chapters.content:
After a rather awkward phone call with my mother, the matter of my bill was squared away.

Still, I left the Pokecenter with my head held high, despite the slight limp. I had successfully captured a new team member. I couldn't wait to get back to training and see exactly what Spinarak could do. Rita had forbade me from training today, however; I was to take the day off of school and focus on recovery. The school had foruntately already been notified of my cirmcumstances.

Honestly, I felt fine enough to return to classes, but I wasn't going to pass up a free day of relaxing at home.

Until I realized how utterly bored I was. But I didn't have to be, didn't I? I had pokemon!

Once I had settled onto my squeaky mattress, I released Surskit and Spinarak from their pokeballs.

"Surss!"

"Spinaa!"

My pokemon chirped in unison.

"Hey guys!"

Spinarak wasted no time crawling up and settling his plump little body into my lap.

"You're a cuddly one, huh?" I chuckled.

Surskit looked at me expectantly, as if to say, "Uh, that's my spot?"

"Haha, sorry Surskit." I gave her an apologetic smile.

"Skkttt." She grumbled out an annoyed hiss.

"Oh‚Äî You know what! I didn't scan you with my pokedex yet, Spinarak." I reached over to my nightstand, grabbing the device. Aiming it at Spinarak, I gave the button a click.

"Spinarak ‚Äî The String Spit Pokemon.

Spinarak hunts by weaving a sticky, but incredibly sturdy trap of web‚Äî where it waits for its prey motionlessly. This web has been likened to a 'second nervous system'‚Äî as Spinarak are able to infer a great deal about their trapped quarry based upon the web's vibrations. Some fisherman have studied Spinarak's webs in an attempt to create new fishing technology."

"Quite a fierce hunter you are then." I gave Spinarak a pat on the head.

Clicking the side button, I pulled up the more specific information I was after.

"Spinarak ‚Äî Juvenile Male. Ability: Insomnia."

"Insomnia, huh?" I cocked my head at the spider.

"Spii?"

"If I remember correctly, that means you cant be put to sleep by other pokemon. That'll definitely come in handy."

Just as I spoke, Surskit rushed up and gave Spinarak a poke before darting off to a corner of the room.

"Ski-skiit!" She warbled challengly.

With a trill, the chunky spider skittered away and gave chase.

I watched with a smile as my pokemon zipped around the room, playing their game of tag.

That was until moves got involved. Just as Spinirak got close to catching Surskit, Surskit used quick attack and slammed face-first into my nightstand, knocking off all of the small dresser's contents.

A picture frame I had containing a photo of my grandfather and myself had shattered. Both pokemon flinched from the sound of breaking glass.

"Surskit, are you okay?" I asked, stepping carefully around the glass shards littered across the floor.

Surskit looked up at me with apologetic eyes. "Suuurss.."

Crouching down, I picked up the broken frame and set it back on the nightstand. The picture itself was undamaged, to my relief. I let my gaze linger on the photo for a few moments, before turning to my pokemon.

"It's okay, Surskit. I know it was an accident." I reached out, giving her a reassuring pat on the head.

The tale has been taken without authorization; if you see it on Amazon, report the incident.

"Why don't I get this cleaned up, and we can get some fresh air?"

The school's courtyard was huge‚Äî almost the size of a small park. I picked a bench off to the side, and released my pokemon.

My bandages felt hot under the afternoon sun, but I was pleased to see my pokemon getting along so well together. Spinarak and Surskit had resumed their game of tag, with far less breaking things involved.

After a while of watching my pokemon play, I was approached by Ms. Kimber. I felt my body straighten as she approached.

"Shouldn't you be resting?" Her gaze settled onto me.

"Ah‚ÄîUhm, well yes." I stammered. "Its just.. I wanted to give my pokemon some time to play. They have to spend so much time in their pokeballs while I'm in classes, so I figured since I had the day off, some fresh air would be good for them."

Ms. Kimber nodded thoughtfully for a moment, before taking a seat on the bench beside me.

"I hope you don't mind." She said as she sat down.

"Not at all." I replied stiffly.

"I actually was looking for you," Ms. Kimber started. " you see‚Äî I'm an old friend of your father's. We went to school together way back when."

"Oh.. Is that so?"

"I thought I had recognized you on the plane‚Äî you're the spitting image of him, you know that?"

I fought the urge to groan. "Yes, I've heard that before."

"Anyways, that isn't what I wanted to talk about." Ms. Kimber sighed. "You seem to be at the center of trouble often. I acknowledge that the Gabite being within the bounds of the exam area wasn't your fault, but.. What you pulled with the Beedrill, it can't happen again."

"Yes ma'am." I nodded.

"I just want you to understand‚ÄîYou could have gotten you and your pokemon killed."

"I know," I responded solemnly, staring at my feet.

"Don't worry. Your father got himself into plenty of trouble as a young trainer too, y'know."

"Did he?"

"He's never told you?" Ms. Kimber seemed genuinely surprised.

"No. We.. don't really talk much."

"I.. see. Well if you ever need anything; to ask for advice or if you have any questions‚Äî you can always come to me. I'd hate to see you get hurt again out there."

"Thankyou, Ms. Kimber."

"Please; just Vivienne or Kimber when we aren't in class. Truthfully, I hate how stuffy the "Miss." sounds."

Our conversation once again fell into a lull for a few moments, while Kimber's eyes watched my pokemon play their game of tag.

"I am curious though, what are your goals after you graduate?" She asked, breaking the silence.

"Aside from taking on the Pokemon League Challenge, I hadn't really given it much thought." I replied.

"I see. Have you given any thought to the type of team you want to build?"

"A little, but.. I don't know, really. I was so happy just to catch Surskit, and now Spinarak.. I've just sort of been taking things as they come."

"Mm. So catching two bug types wasn't intentional?"

"No‚Äî but I'm happy that I did. I think bug types are awesome." I huffed. "It bothers me that no one else seems to think so."

"Sorry‚Äî that isn't what I meant. I had just assumed you were going for a mono-type team is all."

"Mono-type?" I asked.

"Yes, as in, one type only. Many trainers choose to build well rounded teams of multiple types, but a rare few stick to their favorite. Like me, for example."

I quirked an eyebrow. "What type do you train?"

"Ground types. They've been my favorite since I was a girl." Kimber smiled warmly. "Say, would you like to meet my partner pokemon?"

I nodded.

Kimber rose, her shoulder-length brown hair fluttering in the breeze. Unclipping a black and gold pokeball from her belt, she released her pokemon with an effortless grace that left me starstruck.

"Go, Flygon!"

Materializing from red light, the Flygon stretched its wings‚Äî cutting an imposing figure. The green dragon looked to be about six or seven feet tall. Red, goggled eyes sparkled with intelligence, as the impressive creature nuzzled its trainer affectionately.

Surskit and Spinarak ceased their playing, eyeing up the massive pokemon that now stood before me with looks of bewilderment and wonder.

"This is Flygon," Kimber started. "I caught him as a Trapinch when I was around your age. I actually grew up in Lavaridge town, you know. Not too far from Hoenn's desert."

"I didn't know you were from Hoenn," I breathed out, taking in the sight of the massive pokemon.

"Yes, I was actually on the way back from visiting my old gym when you saw me on the plane."

"You used to be a gym leader?!" I shot up.

Kimber gave a slightly smug smile. "You bet I was. That was a long time ago, though."

"I hope you'll forgive me for how this comes across, but you really don't seem that old."

"Well I'll take that as a compliment!" Kimber laughed.

"Do you ever miss being a gym leader?" I asked.

Kimber gave me a thoughtful look before replying.

"Sometimes, but I think that teaching is my real calling. I already went as far as I could go with the battle circuit; I'm happy to be where I'm at."

Just as Kimber replied, Flygon seemed to notice the two bug type pokemon looking him over. Amusement shone in his eyes as he struck a battle-ready pose, seemingly showing off.

"Gohhnnn!"

Surskit bowed up in response, puffing herself up in an attempt to look larger. Spinarak scurried away and hid behind my leg.

Both Kimber and I couldn't help but chuckle.

"You'll have to forgive him, he's always been one to showboat." Kimber gave a lighthearted laugh. "Anyways, I'll leave you to it. Remember that you can always come to me if you need anything."

"Thankyou, uhm.. Kimber." I awkwardly nodded my appreciation.

"Ready to go, Flygon?" Kimber asked, again approaching her companion.

Flygon leaned down, allowing Kimber to climb onto his back. The woman mounted her pokemon with a practiced poise. Kimber gave her companion a pat on the shoulder, and one beat of the creature's wings sent dust sprawling in all directions.

"Oh‚Äî And make sure to get plenty of rest!" Kimber called over the sound of Flygon's wing beats. In a split second, the two were off. I watched with barely contained amazement as Flygon soared, seemingly shearing the clouds within seconds.

I watched until Flygon was little more than a dot in the sky, before reaching a certain conclusion for myself.

I wanted to be a trainer like her.

chapters.name: Chapter 26 - Business as Usual
chapters.content:
After my pokemon tired themselves out, I returned to the dorm room to rest. Truthfully, I was exhausted. I had wanted to go to the library and get some studying done, but my injury was taking its toll.

A few hours later, the sound of the door clicking shut woke me from my nap. Rita had returned to the dorm room, looking rather solemn.

Before I could ask what was wrong, she flopped onto her mattress with a heavy sigh.

"Pep, we need to talk." her voice came, muffled by her fluffy pink covers.

"Okay," I yawned. "Is everything alright?"

"They announced the tournament today," Rita started, flipping over onto her back. "All of us have to participate."

"Oh.. How did it go over?" I asked, sitting upright.

"About as well as you'd expect. Tom looked like he was going to puke."

"Poor guy." I grimaced.

"I know." Rita sat upright, clutching a pillow.

"What I wanted to say was that I think we should train separately for a while." The girl spoke without meeting my gaze.

"What? Why?" I asked.

"Because, Pep. We might have to go up against each other in the tournament.. If that happens, well. I'm not going to pull any punches, y'know?"

"Ah. That's okay." I smiled. "I wouldn't expect anything less."

"I'm sorry, Pep. I know you really want to win too, but there's too much riding on this. If I do well, I could get sponsored." Rita looked at me, her usual emotionless visage morphed into one of concern. "I...I don't want to work in the Pokecenter for the rest of my life."

"Rita, really; it's okay." I gave her a toothy grin and a thumbs up. "If it comes down to it, I wish us both the best of luck. I won't be pulling any punches, either."

"Yeah." Rita gave a weak smile, before stalking off to the bathroom.

Despite what I had said, I really hoped I wouldn't have to face off against my friend.

The following day, I attended classes as usual. I suffered a few stares and sidelong glances upon my return, but nobody really said anything about my bandaged arm. I ate lunch with Rita and Tom, and after classes let out, made my way to the training field.

The field was packed to the brim with students and their pokemon training. I spotted a few familiar faces‚Äî Liam and his Chimchar, along with Claire and her Buizel. When I arrived at our usual spot, Tom and Rita were both nowhere to be found.

I sighed inwardly, before releasing my two pokemon.

Surskit stretched her legs in preparation for today's training, while Spinarak watched her confusedly.

"Spinarak, can you come over here please?" I beckoned the tubby spider over.

"Spii!" My obedient spider waddled over with a trill.

"So today I need to see your moves, do you think you could show me what you know?" I knelt down to look Spinarak in the eyes.

This book was originally published on Royal Road. Check it out there for the real experience.

"Spii-spiin!"

‚ÄúSpinarak went through a rotation of a few moves. Poison Sting, String Shot, and Absorb flew out, but then a fourth came too:

Bright green bug-type energy gathered around Spinarak, taking the form of faux-insects. With a mental command, the 'insects' flew off, infesting and harassing a single spot on the ground.

I clapped my hands. "Infestation!" Truly a useful move at early levels. Once it hits a target, the effect of the 'infestation' would linger for a while, doing damage over time. Even though I was sure Spinarak was more of a physical attacker than special attacker, the extra damage tics would come in handy for sure.

The last move Spinarak showed off was Scary Face‚Äî Spinarak had puffed himself up, revealing the face-like markings on his back. If I remembered correctly, this was a move that could lower the opponent's speed.

Once he was finished, I gave Spinarak a gentle pat on the head. "Well done."

Rising, I again addressed both of my pokemon.

"Okay, so the plan for today is to maximize both of your strengths." I started. "Surskit, I want you to keep using quick attack, and see if you can increase your speed. Your agility is a huge asset, so I want to capitalize on that as much as possible."

"Spinarak, I want you working on learning Bug Bite. It might be difficult, but Surskit managed it, so I think you can too. We're going to work on gathering bug type energy at your mouth, before releasing it with a bite. Surskit, can you demonstrate?"

I produced the now raggedy poke-doll from my bag, placing it in front of Surskit.

With a nod, Surskit gathered up bug-type energy, before releasing it with a snap on the abused doll.

I thanked Surskit, and turned to address my spider once again.

"Think you can do that?"

"Spiin!" A determined look flashed across Spinarak's eyes.

All at once, bug-type energy gathered around Spinarak's mouth, effortlessly. With a snap, Spinarak perfectly recreated the move, with even more force than Surskit had put behind it.

I stood, dumbfounded. Surskit looked incensed.

"You're a quick learner," I started, noticing a chunk had been taken from the Pokedoll. "I guess we can scratch that one off the list."

Surskit huffed, turning away from Spinarak and I.

"Come on, don't be like that Surskit. Spinarak was already used to handling bug-type energy." I knelt down, attempting to comfort my bug.

"Skttt." She hissed in annoyance, before using a quick attack to speed away.

I watched after her as she zipped back and forth, giving her all to her training. I supposed that she wanted to make sure she couldn't be beaten at her speed, at the very least.

After Spinarak's success with bug bite, I had him work on his aim with string shot and poison sting. I made a mental note to return to the library as soon as possible to research the moves Spinarak could potentially learn.

"I feel like I'm going to make a huge joke of myself." Tom groaned, taking a bite of his sandwich.

"Come on, Tom. You and Lotad have improved so much!" I projected my voice slightly over the din of the cafeteria.

"Well, with only one pokemon.." Rita trailed off.

"Not. Helping." I elbowed Rita gently, before taking another bite of my lunch.

"I want to catch another pokemon, but I'm not sure where to go‚Äî I don't want to go somewhere dangerous and end up like you, Pep." Tom gulped down another bite. "Speaking of, how's your shoulder doing?"

"A lot better than it was before. It's still pretty sore, but overall not too bad. That Nurse Joy really did a great job patching me up." I smiled.

"You're from the Joy family, right Rita?" Tom asked.

"Yeah, why?" Rita asked, giving him a look like she didn't want to talk about it.

"Were you related to the Nurse Joy that patched me up?" I interjected.

"Yeah; she's my cousin. I'm related to most of the Nurse Joys here in Jubilife."

"You don't want to be a Nurse Joy, then?" Tom asked innocently.

"No, not really." Rita spat. "And I'm a little tired of everyone asking."

"I'm sorry." Tom spoke. "I don't mean to pry, I was just curious."

"It's okay."

Rita took another bite of her food, leaving us both in an uncomfortable silence, save for the plethora of conversations happening all around us.

"Anyways, I could come with you to catch another pokemon." I spoke, quickly changing the subject.

Tom and Rita both looked at me like I was crazy.

"Pep, I really don't think thats a good idea‚Äî" Tom started.

"No. Are you out of your mind?" Rita cut him off. "You're still in no condition to be going out into the wild. I'll go with him."

"B-but‚Äî What?" Tom sputtered. "No, no. I couldn't possibly trouble you, Rita. I'll figure something out."

"I'm offering." Rita spoke plainly, her expressionless gaze boring into Tom.

"Are you sure?" Tom looked like he might fade away into a fine mist.

"Yeah, it's no trouble. I may even look for a third party member while I'm at it."

"I want to go..." I deflated a bit.

"Next time." Rita assured me with a soft smile. "Provided you don't find some way to get yourself injured again."

"Oh no. I'm good at that." I grinned.

"I know." Rita said flatly.
