chapters.name: Chapter 27 - Gone Fishin'
chapters.content:
Rita was bored‚Äî Unimaginably so. When she had offered to come with Tom to hunt for pokemon, she had pictured something a little more exciting than well, this.

Tom had taken her to Route 218‚Äî a route just west of the city. The two sat on the precipice of a marina, salty ocean air lapping at their skin.

The boy sat at the water's edge with a well-kept Poke-Rod and tacklebox, waiting for a bite. He had sat silently, motionlessly‚Äî for what felt like hours. In reality, it hadn't been that long, but that didn't change the fact that every second seemed to drag on. Those were seconds she could devote to something useful, like training or studying.

Still, when the boy handed her a poke-rod and some bait, she hadn't had the heart to refuse. She would try things his way‚Äî Tom was a nice enough guy, after all. Where most of her other peers would stare or whisper behind her back, Tom seemed genuinely uninterested in that sort of behavior. He was timid, sure‚Äî but the two had gotten a bit closer through their shared friend in Pep. Rita had to respect Tom standing up to his friend with the Chimchar, too.

The surface of the water rippled momentarily, and for a moment Rita prayed that something‚Äîanything, would happen to break her free from this watery purgatory.

But it was not to be.

Tom still eyed the water unflinchingly, but allowed his posture to relax. Beside him, the boy's sleepy-eyed Lotad watched the ripples on the water's surface, mimicking his trainer's unmovable gaze. There really couldn't have been a better partner for him, Rita thought to herself.

"Isn't this relaxing?" Tom spoke, snapping Rita from her thoughts. "I love the smell of the ocean."

"Um.. Sure." Rita lied. For her, it was anything but. Every second that ticked on made her want to jump out of her skin. She couldn't remember the last time she had sat still for this long, asides from her classes.

"So, where did you learn to fish?" Rita asked, desperate for something worth talking about.

"Oh, well, I'm actually from Canalave City, you know. I grew up on boats with my dad and brothers." Tom answered. "We did a lot of fishing when I was a kid. Mostly just catching and releasing Magikarp, though."

Rita raised an eyebrow. "Any run-ins with Gyarados?"

"Well, here and there but the Gyarados around those parts are used to fishermen," Tom brushed his sandy-blonde hair from his eyes. "We usually would throw them some food and they'd be on their way."

Just as Rita opened her mouth to speak, something began to tug at her line. She turned to Tom, panicked.

"What do I do?!"

"Easy, easy." Tom reached around, grabbing the Poke Rod with a firm grip. "Hold it steady, don't freak out. Just reel her in slow."

Rita took a breath, and began reeling in the line.

Little by little, a blue shape crowned through the water's surface.

"Pull!" Tom commanded.

With a yank, the pokemon at the other end of the line was revealed‚Äî a rather perturbed looking Tentacool.

"Tehnnn! Tenta!" The pokemon hissed, clearly unhappy that its lunch had been interrupted.

Rita instinctively reached for Grimer's pokeball, but Tom stopped her.

"Try this instead." The boy grinned, producing a handful of brightly colored berries from his coat pocket.

"What?" Rita gasped.

"Try feeding her, Rita. She's probably just hungry."

With a gulp, Rita took a berry and held it out to the pokemon‚Äî Shutting her eyes as she did.

She expected the pokemon to bite, to lash out‚Äî to do something, but nothing came. Instead, the Tentacool eyed her suspiciously, not making any moves.

Right. This was just a pokemon, after all. Rita worked with pokemon regularly while volunteering at the Pokecenter. What am I letting myself get so worked up over? She thought.

Taking a breath, Rita knelt down to reach eye level with the Tentacool, offering it the berry once more.

"It's okay, I'm sorry if I scared you." She spoke in a hushed tone.

Tom looked on, nodding approvingly.

Gingerly, the pokemon took the offered berry in its tentacle, before raising it to its mouth. It munched away for a few seconds, before giving a contented "Co-coool."

The tale has been taken without authorization; if you see it on Amazon, report the incident.

Relaxing, Rita sat cross-legged from the pokemon, and offered it another berry. The pokemon again took her offering, this time eating with less hesitation.

As Tentacool ate, Rita slowly reached for her pokedex, before aiming it at the creature.

"Tentacool ‚Äî The Jellyfish Pokemon. A Water/Poison Type.

Tentacool generally spend their lives drifting along the waves of shallow seas, using its toxic feelers to stab unsuspecting prey. As such, Tentacool can often be considered a hazard to anglers and swimmers. A Tentacool's body is comprised almost entirely of water, and as such is prone to drying out. Trainers of Tentacool must take special care to keep their pokemon hydrated."

"Ten-ta?" The pokemon warbled, eyeing the pokedex cautiously.

"Sorry, I just wanted to learn more about you." Rita smiled, pocketing the device. "You're a really fascinating pokemon, Tentacool."

The jellyfish did a little twirl, sending saltwater spraying gently in all directions.

"Tenta-ten."

"I'd love to ask you to come with me, but," Rita frowned. "I'm not sure there's enough water where I live."

The Tentacool looked up at Rita, confusedly.

"The school actually has a small aquarium for water types," Tom started. "It wouldn't be impossible. Plenty of water-type trainers find ways to get around it."

"I suppose." Rita sat silently, thinking for a moment. "Would you like to come with me, Tentacool? I'm a pokemon trainer. We could train together, and get stronger. If you don't want to it's okay‚Äî I wouldn't take you away if you're happy here."

A determined look flashed across the pokemons eyes, before it gestured to Grimer's pokeball. "Tent-tenta!"

"I think it wants to battle you first," Tom spoke.

Rita's heart skipped in her chest momentarily. "And if I win I can capture you? You're sure?"

"Co-cool! Tenta!"

The Tentacool bobbed in the water, its eyes not leaving Rita for a second.

"Ready?" Rita asked, a bead of sweat dripping from her temple.

The pokemon gave a brusque nod.

Rita thought for a moment, considering whether now would be a good time to test her Oddish out in battle‚Äî but decided against it. Given Tentacool's poison typing, there wasn't a whole lot the little shrub could do to damage it. Grimer just had a bit more coverage in the way of moves, as he had been training alongside Rita for far longer.

"Go, Grimer!"

The oozey creature materialized, floating atop the water's surface. Grimer rocked gently with the waves, eyeing down his opponent.

The Tentacool made the first move, diving under. Grimer was at a clear disadvantage in this situation, but both pokemon and trainer kept their cool with a steely determination.

Tentacles shot out, wrapping Grimer in their toxic grasp‚Äî though Grimer was mostly unaffected.

"Minimize, Grimer!" Rita called.

Grimer shrunk down, easily slipping from Tentacool's grasp.

Tentacool gave chase, cresting over the waves as Grimer floated away.

"Now! Mud slap!"

Ground-type energy materialized around Grimer momentarily, before coalescing into a ball of mud. Just as Tentacool got close enough to threaten Grimer with another grab, Grimer released the energy, slapping tentacool directly in the face for super-effective damage.

Tentacool flew backwards, before retreating beneath the waves again.

"Okay Grimer, when Tentacool comes back up, use pound."

"Griii." Grimer nodded in acknowledgement.

After a few moments, a disturbance in the water's surface alerted Grimer. Grimer moved to attack, but instead was hit with a circular projectile of water.

"Water pulse!" Rita gasped as her pokemon reeled back, staggering.

Grimer's movements became erratic, he looked all around as if searching for something.

Confusion.

"Grimer! Listen to my voice, you need to relax!" Rita called out desperately to her pokemon.

Grimer moved towards the sound of Rita's voice, before being hit with another water pulse‚Äî being sent staggering back once more.

As Grimer rocked back and forth with the waves, he tried desperately to hit and punch at the air‚Äî hoping to hit an opponent that wasn't there.

"Snap out of it Grimer!" Rita cried.

But it was to no avail. Tentacles once again wrapped around Grimer, squeezing his oozey body tightly.

As Tentacool's grip tightened‚Äî something snapped in Grimer's head, and awareness came flooding back to him. He once again used minimize to slip away.

"Grimer! Are you okay?"

"Griiiihhhmme." The pokemon bellowed, enraged that it had been confused by its opponent.

"Alright. Lets do this."

Grimer skidded across the water towards Tentacool once more, threatening to pound the jellyfish in the face.

Tentacool reeled back, preparing to fire off another water pulse. Water-type energy gathered in a ring, before firing straight towards the encroaching Grimer.

"Grimer dodge, then disable!"

Grimer briefly plopped under the waves, dodging out of the way of Tentacool's attack. Surfacing again, a glittering white light shone in the ooze's eyes as well as the rivaling pokemon, marking the successful use of disable. Tentacool would no longer be able to fire off Water Pulses.

"Yes, great job!" Rita praised her blob.

"Griiihme!" The pokemon belched, sending forth a noxious cloud of fumes.

Having had enough of this, Tentacool surged forward, lashing out with its tentacles.

"Grimer, mud slap, again!"

Grimer didn't move as the Tentacool charged towards him. Instead, he leaned back‚Äî waiting. As the Tentacool came within striking distance, he once again fired off a mud-slap, sending a wet snapping sound reverberating off the water. A clean hit.

As Tentacool reeled backwards, Grimer pursued it with a pound. After a series of hits, the battle was over.

Tentacool floated weakly, having been beaten.

"Great job Grimer!" Rita called out to her pokemon, before returning him to his pokeball. "Get some good rest, now."

Crouching down along the waters edge, Rita once again spoke to the jellyfish, who now was looking worse for wear.

"Are you still sure you want to come with me? I know what we agreed on, but I want to make sure you're really okay with this."

"Tehntaa." the pokemon once again gave her a nod.

"Thank you. I promise I'll take great care of you."

With that, Rita threw a pokeball‚Äî a pink and white heal ball that matched all of her others.

The pokeball rocked a few times with the waves, before sealing shut with a 'click'. The capture had been successful.

"Congratulations!" Tom clapped.

A small smile crept across Rita's face, as she pulled the wet pokeball from the water.

"Thanks Tom. I'm starting to think that fishing maybe doesn't suck."

Just as Rita turned to look at Tom, she noticed that there was another pokemon sat next to his Lotad‚Äî A rather content looking Glameow, with berry juice plastered across its face.

"Uhm... Tom?" She asked.

"Oh, uh. I think she came for the snacks." Tom said, giving the Glameow a scratch under the chin.

chapters.name: Chapter 28 - Back to the Library
chapters.content:
I seethed with jealousy as Rita regaled me with all the details of her encounter with Tentacool and the subsequent battle. I was happy for her, sure‚Äî but after hearing about how Tom managed to get a pokemon to follow him home, I felt like I had missed out on a great opportunity to capture a third party member.

Oh well. I had my hands full training Spinarak and Surskit as it was‚Äî I wanted to get the two of them tournament ready before anything else. While my friends were away, I had taken the time to gather more information on the tournament‚Äî it seemed the matches would be one-on-one, but our pokemon would no doubt get tired after repeated matches. Students who had managed to capture and train more than one pokemon would naturally fare far better. After doing some reconnaissance around the training grounds, it seemed that a good portion of my peers were still scrambling to capture a second party member‚Äî which, thankfully, put me a bit ahead of the curve. I could only hope that it would be enough.

After parting ways with Rita, I once again made my way for the library. She had wanted me to stay and rest longer, but I was itching for something to do‚Äî and truthfully couldn't afford to waste any more time on my injury.

I entered the grandiose library, this time knowing exactly where I was going. As I made my way to the bug type section, I ran into an unfortunately familiar face. Beatrice stood, flipping through a book on local bug types. She seemed thoroughly engrossed in her book, as she hadn't yet noticed me.

I cleared my throat. "I would have figured you were too good for bugs."

With a start, Beatrice snapped the book shut, evidently caught off guard.

"Ah, Peppa Carmine. Pleasure to see you again." Beatrice responded coolly.

"Yeah, a pleasure. Just like that time you left us to die." I snarled.

"Please, this is a library. Keep your voice down." The girl spoke in a hushed tone. "Plus, I didn't leave you to die. I went and got help, like any student would be advised to do."

"Sure." I muttered. "Tell yourself that."

Beatrice fell silent for a few moments, before once again turning to address me.

"If you didn't need anything, could you leave? I'm trying to get some research done."

"Yeah. So was I." I folded my arms.

With a heavy sigh, Beatrice once again resumed flipping through her book.

Stepping around her, I searched for the book I had used previously, and after a few moments found it. As I turned to walk away, I couldn't help but glance over Beatrice's small shoulders. It seemed she was looking at an entry about female Combee.

"Combee, huh?" I eyed the entry in the book with interest.

You could be reading stolen content. Head to Royal Road for the genuine story.

Instantly Beatrice spun around, looking up at me with a baleful stare. "Its none of your business!"

"Shhh," I put a finger over my mouth. "This is a library."

For a moment, the corners of Beatrice's mouth twitched like she wanted to say something, but she instead turned and placed her book back on the shelf.

"Enjoy your studies," She spoke evenly, before stalking off, taking her miasma of haughtiness with her.

A wave of satisfaction crept over me knowing that I had ruffled her feathers. Still, I couldn't help but wonder what sparked Beatrice's interest in a bug type‚Äî especially after she had looked down on Surskit.

From what I could recall of Combee, they were one of the exclusive pokemon that could only be caught using honey on trees, back when the original Sinnoh games came out. This was particularly annoying because once you slathered the honey on the trees, you would have to wait six real-life hours before finding an encounter‚Äî and the odds that you would find one were abysmally low. To make matters worse, only female Combees could evolve. You could wait hours and hours, and once you finally found your quarry, realize that it couldn't evolve due to its gender. I shuddered, thanking Arceus that I was no longer at the mercy of RNG.

Vespiquen‚Äî the evolution of Combee ‚Äî fit a sort of 'queen bee' archetype, and as such featured moves that only it could learn: Attack Order and Defend Order. While Vespiquen wasn't really a 'meta' pick due to its bug typing, it did feature some of the most decent stats when compared to others of its type.

I snorted‚Äî Of course Beatrice of all people would want a queen bee pokemon. Regardless, I had no doubt Vespiquen would be a good addition to most any team‚Äî I would have to keep my eyes peeled for Combee next time I went looking for pokemon.

Settling down with my book, I flit through the pages for a bit until I found an entry on Spinarak. Researching Spinarak's learnable moves would be vital, and Spinarak himself had already proven to be a quick study.

Thumbing through the pages, I quickly came upon a list of known learnable moves‚Äî some of which Spinarak had already demonstrated, such as Infestation, String-shot, and Poison Sting. The list itself was much longer than Surskit's.

The first few moves of interest that I came upon were X-Scissor, Shadow Sneak, Screech, and Sticky Web. X-Scissor would be a good overall damaging move to have in our arsenal, while Shadow Sneak would allow Spinarak to sneak around and get some cheap hits in. Not to mention, the move's ghost typing would be a good counter in case I had to face off against Beatrice and her Drifloon. Screech and Sticky Web in tandem would also be a nasty combo for lowering our opponent's speed, as well.

As my eyes made their way down the page, I also noted moves such as Poison Jab and Leech Life, but I decided not to bite off more than I could chew at this point‚Äî it wouldn't do to overwhelm my poor spider.

My plan was already beginning to take shape in my mind. All that was left was to train my pokemon, and hope for the best.

Cool wind whined in my ears as I exited the library, heralding the arrival of storm clouds that loomed over me about as much as the upcoming tournament. Relying on my mono-type bug team could very well be a mistake, but I was content to try. I knew there were better, safer bets‚Äî but there were no other pokemon I wanted to train with more than Surskit and Spinarak. Surskit had pushed herself so hard for me, and had even saved my life‚Äî and while Spinarak was a new addition, the sweet little spider had taken to training so quickly. No matter how things panned out, there was no way the two of them could ever let me down.

Still, anxieties clouded my mind when I thought of the expectations being levied onto me. Maybe that's what Ms. Kimber felt before her first big tournament. There would be so much capable competition, with teams that were much more cohesive by default. Eyes that pried from all sides, searching‚Äî evaluating. If she had a chance, if she managed to do as well as she did‚Äî to go as far as to become an official Gym Leader, maybe I would have a chance as well.

chapters.name: Chapter 29: The Tournament Begins!
chapters.content:
Days and nights blurred together as I repeated the cycle of attending classes and training, without much else in between. In the blink of an eye, nearly an entire week had passed.

During the course of the last week, Surskit had improved her speed significantly. Training her aim with water gun had paid off, and as a result, she had become quite accurate with her Bubble-beam attack as well. As for Spinarak, he mostly focused on learning new moves. He had picked up Sticky Web easily enough, as spinning webs seemed to be one of those abilities his species innately knew‚Äî much like Surskit and her Sweet Scent. Originally, I had him try to learn Shadow Sneak, but learning to handle ghost-type energy within a week seemed infeasible. Instead, we had changed gears and attempted to get him to learn X-Scissor instead. This came a bit more naturally to Spinarak, as he seemed to comprehend the general idea behind the move ‚Äî but he had only managed to pull it off once during our training.

Either way, I was happy with my pokemon's progress, as well as my own. After getting the all-clear from Rita, I resumed light exercise alongside my pokemon. It just didn't feel right to sit and watch them train while I did nothing, injury or not.

All of our progress, all of our effort‚Äî it all came down to now.

I drew in a long breath, eyeing the locker room door. Any second now, my name could be called over the loudspeakers, and it would be my turn to go out there before a crowd of onlookers and prove that I deserved to be here. A bead of sweat dropped from my forehead‚Äî causing me to hastily wipe my brow with my sleeve. I fixed my hair a few more times, before taking another deep breath‚Äî trying in vain to force myself to relax. If I survive this, maybe I'll survive my father chewing me out for eternity, too.

Casting my nervous gaze around the locker room, many of my peers seemed to be faring about the same as I. One girl seemed to be giving herself a quiet pep-talk in the mirror, while another just a few feet away seemed to be comforting her anxious Marill. The only familiar face I had seen today was Rita, but she must have gotten sent to a different locker room, because she was nowhere to be found here.

An obnoxiously exuberant chime blared from the speaker on the ceiling, causing everyone in the room to freeze. I gripped Surskit's pokeball white-knuckle tight as the tune played.

"Peppa Carmine, please make your way to training court 1-A. I repeat, Peppa Carmine, please make your way to‚Äî"

I felt the blood in my face drain as the cheerful voice spoke my name. I silently cursed as I stood, my legs wobbling underneath me.

Calm down, Pep. Calm down. You can do this, I internally repeated to myself as my steps came one after the other.

As I pushed my way beyond the door, a wall of noise assaulted my ears‚Äî and with each step down the narrow hallway, grew closer and closer. I almost wanted to turn around, to pretend I wasn't here. But no‚Äî I had worked hard for this moment, and so had my pokemon.

Pressing on, I entered the school's exhaustively large gymnasium, where a sea of people crowded the rafters. From all sides I was bombarded by stimuli ‚Äî talking, laughing; lights, cameras flashing. The tournament had turned out to be a much bigger affair than I had previously expected. All around me, trainers and their pokemon had gathered across several training courts. Pushing past my nerves, I found my way to the court labeled 1-A and stood at one end of it. Across from me, I recognized my opponent to be Liam‚Äî The boy with the Chimchar that Tom had wanted to face off against. Unfortunately, things never seemed to work out the way we want them to‚Äî It looked like I would be beating Tom to the punch on this one.

Liam eyed me up and down, a smug smile playing at his lips.

"Carmine, yeah?"

I nodded.

"Its too bad you got me first. This is going to be a short tournament for you." Liam smirked, brandishing a pokeball at me.

My eyes flit to the left just above the battle court, where a man with a large camera stood among the crowd on the balcony-like rafters. This was being recorded‚Äî it wouldn't do to lose my cool.

Instead, I ignored Liam entirely, choosing to focus only on my breathing for a few moments.

A rather burly looking referee stepped onto the court between us, holding a microphone in one hand.

"In the blue corner, and hailing from Lilycove City‚Äî Peppa Carmine!" The man spoke.

Support the creativity of authors by visiting Royal Road for this novel and more.

A wave of cheers from the audience caught me off guard. I sheepishly grinned and waved back.

"In the red corner, and hailing from our very own Jubilife City‚Äî Liam White!"

The cheers that came following Liam's name drowned out the whole stadium momentarily‚Äî Marking him as a clear favorite.

"Now I'll go over the rules for both of our participants." The referee cleared his throat. "Today's battles will be one-on-one. The battle is over when either pokemon is unable to continue, or otherwise when I call it. The use of items is forbidden. Understand?"

Both Liam and I nodded our agreement.

"Alright. I'll ask you both to select and send out your pokemon."

Without a moments hesitation, Liam sent out his pokemon‚Äî and in a flash of light, a Monferno appeared. It looked like Chimchar had evolved.

I sucked my teeth. An evolved pokemon right off the bat wasn't ideal, but I couldn't let that intimidate me. I just had to believe that Surskit could handle this‚Äî and so I sent her out. My bug appeared on the court with a determined "Skktt!"

"Three.."

As the referee began the countdown, Monferno began flexing his arms at Surskit in some sort of taunt. Surskit hissed her annoyance, but otherwise kept her cool. I was proud of her for not immediately charging him. My feisty little bug had really come so far in such a short amount of time.

"..Two,"

"..One! Begin!" The referee called.

"Monferno! Mach Punch!" Liam commanded.

"Don't let him catch you!"

Monferno lunged towards Surskit with frightening speed, threatening to nail her with a heavy fist. Fortunately, Surskit moved just a hair sooner, narrowly dodging the blow. Monferno's fist connected with the ground, sending dust flying.

"Surskit, Bubble-beam!"

We absolutely had to get some damage in on Monferno first. He didn't look to be very tanky, but his speed had startled me. If we hadn't spent so much time focusing on building up Surskit's speed, I worried that Monferno's initial blow would have seen Surskit going down before the match could start.

As Monferno turned to face Surskit, he was slammed with her Bubble-beam square in the chest. A direct hit, for super-effective damage no less.

I grinned. "Good! Stay on the move Surskit!"

Surskit gave me a brief nod, before dodging out of the way of another blow.

"Monferno, feint!"

As Surskit dodged a blow from the left, Monferno feinted right, this time catching Surskit off guard. The blow connected, sending Surskit flying backwards with a thud.

I gasped. "Are you okay?"

"Skkkt!" Surskit hissed, giving me a nod as she struggled to her feet.

"Yes!" Liam cheered. "Don't give her a chance to get up!"

"Surskit! Water gun at Monferno's feet!" I cried out to my bug, who barely had a chance to stand up before the much larger pokemon set upon her again.

Surskit's attack sent water spraying into Monferno's face, causing him to stagger backwards for a moment. Fire types would naturally have an aversion to water, after all‚Äî and luckily my quick thinking had paid off. Once again, Surskit was on the move and putting distance between herself and her opponent.

"Monferno, what are you doing?!" Liam roared, outraged. "You had her right there! Don't tell me you're scared of a little water?"

Monferno's shoulder's sagged slightly, but only for a moment.

"You shouldn't talk to your pokemon like that!" I yelled.

"Mind your own business! Monferno‚Äî Use Mach Punch! Again!"

Monferno again sprinted for Surskit at an alarming speed. Without my ordering it, Surskit began to leave a trail of white light zipping behind her‚Äî she had once again used Quick-Attack to evade.

The gap between Surskit and Monferno began to tighten, and it was clear that Monferno would catch up soon enough.

I bit my lip. We needed to end this game of cat-and-mouse.

"Surskit, stop!"

Surskit came to an abrupt halt, sending Monferno toppling over her.

"Monferno, what the hell?!" Liam growled. "Are you serious? Get her!"

Monferno lunged at Surskit oncemore, but it seemed like his heart wasn't really in it anymore. Surskit easily dodged, shooting a confused glance back at me momentarily.

Poor Monferno, I thought to myself. He was looking tired‚Äî and not just physically. I almost regretted having to give my next order.

"Surskit, Bubble-beam!"

Once again, the torrent of bubbles slammed into Monferno's chest, seeing him sway on his feet. The pokemon fell to one knee, before shakily standing up again.

"You're an evolved pokemon, are you seriously telling me you can't handle that bug?" Liam jeered.

Booing erupted from the audience as Liam taunted his own pokemon. The referee looked like he wanted to say something, but didn't.

I grit my teeth. It would be better for everyone involved if I just ended this.

"Surskit, water-gun! Let's finish this!"

Monferno lunged forward with another half-hearted swing, but before he could close the gap, he was hit squarely with Surskit's Water-gun‚Äî which sent him sprawling.

Monferno did not rise again.

"There you have it folks‚Äî Peppa Carmine will advance to the next round!" The referee called, trying to hype up the audience.

There were some cheers, but it was clear that not many people were feeling the hype after that display.

"Now, I'd like for the two of you to shake hands." The referee gestured to Liam and I once we had finished recalling our respective pokemon.

I stepped forward, but only because I didn't want to look like a bad sport in front of everyone. "Good match," I ground out, extending my hand to Liam.

Liam took my hand and yanked me towards him, tightening his grip to a near painful degree.

"Good match," he sneered, gripping harder. He clearly intended to hurt me.

A fire ignited in my chest as I pulled him back towards me, tightening my own grip around his wrist.

"I just want you to know, Liam‚Äî you didn't lose because of Monferno. You lost because you're a terrible trainer."

Liam's face twisted into a mask of rage, but before he could say anything else, the referee stepped in, pulling us apart.

"Okay, thats enough." The referee whispered away from his microphone. "Seriously. Don't cause a scene."

Liam stared me down for a few seconds longer, before stalking off to the locker rooms.
